#### Suppress the Check In Dialog in the Vault Client

# Suppress the Check In Dialog in the Vault Client

When suppressing the Check In dialog box, you can specify how the corresponding vault operation affects the related files.

The Check In operation is performed using the specified settings without prompting the you.

1. Select Tools > Options.
2. On the options dialog box, select the Check In check box in the Dialog Suppression section.
3. Click Settings for the Check In dialog box.

   The Settings for Check In dialog displays.

   ![](../images/dialog-suppression-check-in.png)
4. In the Settings for Check In dialog box, specify if you want to keep the file checked out for further editing and whether or not to delete the local copy of the file once it is checked in to the vault.
5. Select the Include Children check box to apply the vault operation to all files on which the selected file depends.
6. Select the Include Parents check box to apply the vault operation to all files that depend on the selected file. If Include Parents is turned on, you can specify whether or not only the direct parents of the file are included or all parents of the file.
7. Select the Include related documentation option to apply the vault operation to the related drawing files.
8. Select the Include links option to apply the operation to files collected from links to files, folders, items, or change orders.

   Note:

   This option is available only in Vault Professional.
9. Click OK.
10. In the Options dialog box, click OK.

#### Suppress Item Dialogs in the Vault Client

# Suppress Item Dialogs in the Vault Client

You can suppress certain Item Dialogs to streamline your workflow.

## Suppress the Edit Item dialog after performing an Assign/Update Item action

By default, when an assign or update item action occurs, the Edit Item dialog automatically opens. You can configure your Vault settings so that the Edit Item dialog does not open after selecting Assign/Update Item.

1. Go to Tools > Options to open the Options dialog.
2. Select Edit item dialog after Assign Item to suppress the Edit Item dialog after assigning items.
3. Select Edit item dialog after Update Item to suppress the Edit item dialog after updating items.
4. Click OK to save your changes.

## Suppress the Associated Items Dialog after performing a Go To Item action

By default, when a Go To Item action is performed, the Associated Items dialog displays if more than one item is associated with the selected file. This dialog can be suppressed.

1. Go to Tools > Options to open the Options dialog.
2. Select Associated Items dialog to suppress the Associated Items dialog after performing a Go To Item action.
3. Click OK to save your changes.

## Suppress the New Item-Select Category Dialog

By default, when a new item is created in Vault, the Select Category dialog displays. You can suppress this dialog so that the default category is selected whenever a new item is created.

1. Go to Tools > Options to open the Options dialog.
2. Select New Item-Select Category dialog to suppress this dialog whenever a new item is created.
3. Click OK to save your changes.

* [Dialog Suppression](GUID-2CB87AE4-681B-4B4F-B939-C539367275CF.htm)

#### Suppress Dialogs in the AutoCAD Vault Add-in

# Suppress Dialogs in the AutoCAD Vault Add-in

You can suppress the Check In dialog in the AutoCAD Vault Add-in.

The following dialog boxes can be suppressed:

* Check In
* Check In dialog on file close

Each dialog has settings associated with it. You can specify default values for these dialogs and choose whether or not the dialogs actively prompt you while working with files in a vault.

## Change Suppression Settings for the Check In Dialog Box

When suppressing the Check In dialog box, you can specify how the corresponding vault operation affects the related files. The Check In operation is performed using the specified settings without prompting you.

1. Select Vault Options from the Autodesk Vault ribbon.
2. In the Options dialog box, click Settings for the Check In dialog box.
3. Select the Create DWF Attachment check box to create and attach a .dwf file to the design file being checked in. The .dwf attachments are only created for files that have changed or for files that do not have .dwf files published already. Select the Apply to all Files check box to create .dwf files for children. This option is on by default.

   Note: The paper clip icon is not displayed for automatically published .dwf files.
4. Click OK.
5. In the Options dialog box, click OK.

## Change Suppression Settings for the Check In Dialog Box when Closing a File

When suppressing the Check In dialog box, you can specify how the corresponding vault operation affects the related files. The Check In operation is performed using the specified settings without prompting you.

1. Select Vault Options from the Autodesk Vault ribbon.
2. In the Options dialog box, click Settings for the Check In dialog box.
3. Select a Visualization Attachment preference:

   * Select the Create during check-in option to create and attach a .dwf file to the design file being checked in from the local workstation. The .dwf attachments are only created for files that have changed or for files that do not have .dwf files published already.

     Note: The paper clip icon is not displayed for automatically published .dwf files.
   * Select the Send to Job Server option to send the visualization publishing task to the Job Server, where the .dwf file will be created at a time specified by the Job Server Queue settings.
   * Select the Do not create option to disable sending the visualization task to the Job Server or creating the visualization file during check-in.
4. Select the Apply to all Files check box to create .dwf files for children when checking files in from the local workstation or through the Job Server. This option is disabled when the Do not create option is selected.
5. Click OK.
6. In the Options dialog box, click OK.

**Related Information**

* [Dialog Suppression](GUID-2CB87AE4-681B-4B4F-B939-C539367275CF.htm)

**Parent page:** [Suppress Dialogs](GUID-21DA6F61-72D1-455D-B734-FD3B21AEC84B.htm)

2. In the Options dialog box, click Settings for the Undo Check Out dialog box.
3. In the Settings for Undo Check Out dialog box, specify if you want to replace the local file with the version currently stored in the vault. Select Replace local copy to reset any changes that were made to the local copy of the file.
4. Select the Include Children check box to apply the vault operation to all files on which the selected file depends.
5. Select the Include Parents check box to apply the vault operation to all files that depend on the selected file. If Include Parents is turned on, you can specify whether or not only the direct parents of the file are included or all parents of the file.
6. Click OK.
7. In the Options dialog box, click OK.

**Related Information**

* [Dialog Suppression](GUID-2CB87AE4-681B-4B4F-B939-C539367275CF.htm)

**Parent page:** [Suppress Dialogs](GUID-21DA6F61-72D1-455D-B734-FD3B21AEC84B.htm)


#### Suppress Dialogs in Other Vault Add-ins

# Suppress Dialogs in Other Vault Add-ins

Depending on your particular add-in, one or more of the following dialog boxes can be suppressed.

* Check In
* Undo Check Out
* Check In dialog on file close
* Check Out dialog on file open

Each dialog has settings associated with it. You can specify default values for these dialogs.

## Dialog Suppression

2. Click Settings to specify whether or not to include child and parent files when the dialog is suppressed, as well as attachments.

### Configure Exclude Path Settings in the Inventor Vault Add-in

# Configure Exclude Path Settings in the Inventor Vault Add-in

Use the Exclude Paths settings in the Inventor Vault add-in to exclude folder path for large datasets, such as Revit files and point cloud files, during check in to Vault.

You can add, remove, or modify the excluded path under the Exclude Paths settings.

This feature is only available in the Inventor Vault Add-in. Only administrators, configuration administrators, or users with Vault Set Options permission can modify the Exclude Path.

Note: Excluding the folder path may lead to the loss of data during check in to Vault.

## Add a folder path

1. Click ![](../images/icon-add-folder.jpg) to add a folder path you want to exclude. The "Add Folder Path" dialog box opens.
2. Enter the folder path or click ![](../images/icon-ds-result-context-menu.png) button to browse the folder location. The 'Browse for Folder' dialog box opens.

   Note: You can enter multiple paths into the Folder path field. Right-click on the Folder path field to paste the copied path.
3. Navigate to the folder you want to add to the excluded paths list and click OK.
4. Click OK to save the changes.

## Remove a folder path

1. In the Excluded Paths list, select the folder path to remove.
2. Click ![](../images/icon-remove.png) to remove the selected path.

   Note: Deleting a folder path from the excluded paths list only removes the item from the list. The actual folder is not deleted.
3. Click OK to save the changes.

## Edit a folder path

1. In the Excluded Paths list, select the folder path to edit.
2. Click ![](../images/icon-edit.png) to modify the selected path. The "Add Folder Path" dialog box opens.
3. Edit the folder path or click ![](../images/icon-ds-result-context-menu.png) button to browse the folder location.
4. Click OK to save the changes.

**Parent page:** [Configure the Vault Environment](GUID-597293A4-CC5B-49A8-80C7-AB20E42EFB4D.htm)

### Configure Open File Behaviors

# Configure Open File Behaviors

Determine whether Inventor, AutoCAD, and Revit files are opened by the latest version, the last run version, or the version of the CAD Application that saved the file.

For example, if AutoCAD 2023 and AutoCAD 2024 are both installed on a machine, and you want files that were saved in AutoCAD 2023 to always open with AutoCAD 2024, you can configure Vault to always launch AutoCAD 2024 for all .dwg and .dxf files.

Vault supports 2021, 2022, 2023, and 2024 versions of CAD applications.

![](../images/dialog-ve-options-openfilebehaviors.png)

## Configure Open File Behaviors

1. In the Vault Client, select Tools > Options.
2. Next to **Open file behavior settings** click Settings.
3. On the Open File Behaviors dialog, configure your open preferences for each CAD application.

   Note: Not all options are available for each CAD application. AutoCAD option applies to all AutoCAD tool sets for Architecture, MEP, Electrical, Mechanical, and so on.

   **Inventor:**

   * **Last Run Version** Opens the file with the last used version of Inventor.

     Note: This option is available only for Inventor files.
   * **Default** Uses the current settings in Vault for opening a specified CAD file. For example, if you have installed another application capable of opening Inventor files and configured Windows to use that application, Vault uses that same application to open Inventor files by default, too.

   **AutoCAD, ACM , ACE C3D**

   * **Latest Version** Opens the CAD file with the newest version of the CAD application.
   * **Saved by Version** Opens the CAD file with the version of the CAD application that was last used to save the file. If the specific application version in which the file was saved is not installed, the latest version of the application is used to open the file. If the respective CAD application is not available, then AutoCAD is used to open the .dwg file.

     Note: This option is not available in the Civil3D application.
   * **Default** Uses the current settings in Vault for opening a specified CAD file. For example, if you have installed another application capable of opening .dwg files and configured Windows to use that application, Vault uses that same application to open .dwg files by default, too.
4. Click **OK** when you are finished to save your changes.

**Parent page:** [Configure the Vault Environment](GUID-597293A4-CC5B-49A8-80C7-AB20E42EFB4D.htm)


### Organize Columns

# Organize Columns

The table columns can be organized by changing the order of the columns, the size of the columns, and the alignment of the data in the columns.

## Change Column Order

1. Click and drag a column heading to a new position within the table. A black frame indicates the new position of the column.
2. Drop the heading in its new location. The column moves to the new position and the other columns shift to accommodate.

## Change Column Width

Column width can be adjusted manually or set to automatically size to the best fit.

* Click and drag a column heading border to manually resize the column width.
* Double-click a column heading border to automatically size the column to best fit the data.

## Specify Text Alignment in a Column

* Right-click a column heading, select Alignment, and then select either Align Left, Align Right, or Center. The data in the column is aligned accordingly.

## Remove a Column

* Right-click a column heading, and then select Remove This Column. The selected column is removed from the table. Columns can be added to the table using Customize View.

## Customize View

* Right-click a column heading, and then select Customize View to customize view of the columns within the Vault Client's dialogs. You can add or remove fields from view, choose categories to appear in the current view, customize grid options, set auto preview for comments and automatic column sizing.

  By making efficient use of properties and customizing your view, data management becomes much more tailored to your project. For more information, see [Customize the View](GUID-D5AE6CDC-50FA-47A4-84D0-CA0A54C4E6D6.htm).

**Parent page:** [Configure the Vault Environment](GUID-597293A4-CC5B-49A8-80C7-AB20E42EFB4D.htm)


### Sort, Group, and Filter Columns

# Sort, Group, and Filter Columns

You can sort and filter the contents of the main pane the preview pane.

You can sort in ascending or descending order based on any column currently displayed, group by column headings, and filter based on properties.

## Sort in Ascending or Descending Order

* Right-click a column heading, and then select Sort Ascending or Sort Descending from the context menu.

  or

  Click the column heading to switch between sort ascending and sort descending.The corresponding column is sorted from highest value to lowest value or from lowest value to highest.

Note that the Grid View can sort data by multiple columns while Vault sorts the data by the name column by default. So, if you click on the column header, the sorting is applied to the selected column only. If you choose to sort a column using the context menu, it sorts on the initial column and then the next within the sorted results.

## Group by Column Heading

The contents of the main pane and the preview pane can be grouped according to any combination of column headings. When the contents are grouped, items with like values for the selected properties are combined in a collapsible list.

* Right-click a column heading, and then select Group By This Field. The entire list is grouped according to the selected column. Items with like values are collected in an expandable list.

You can group further by adding more columns to the Group By box.

* Drag a column heading up to the Group By box. The contents are arranged in sub-groups below the first group.
* Drag a column heading down from the Group By box to the file list to remove that grouping.

  or

  Right-click the Group By box, and then select Clear Grouping to remove all the column headings from the Group By box and display the files in a flat table.

## Filter Columns

Content not meeting specific criteria can be hidden from view using a column filter. There are several default filters from which to choose or, you can specify a custom filter.

* Click the filter icon in the upper right corner of the column header, and then select the filter from the list or create a custom filter.

Content not meeting the filter criteria are hidden from view until the filter is removed.

**Parent page:** [Configure the Vault Environment](GUID-597293A4-CC5B-49A8-80C7-AB20E42EFB4D.htm)


### Customize the View

# Customize the View

You can customize the view in the application window.

By making efficient use of properties and customizing your view, data management becomes much more tailored to your project.

**Distributed Views**

The Distributed View is the custom view created and controlled by the Administrator or Configuration Administrator tailored to your project. This is the initial view set when you access the system. You can customize the default configuration to optimize your view and improve efficiency.

An administrator can create a custom view and save it as a distributed view. The administrator can then deploy the custom view settings to the Vault Client, allowing users to use it for their regular activities.

As a user, you can use the distributed view created by the administrator, modify the distributed view as per your requirement, or use a different custom view. If there are any changes to the distributed view, you will receive an update notification. You can accept or reject the changes to the distributed views in the workspaces. If rejected, the changes will not impact any local edits you have made to the distributed views.

## Customize the View

1. Click the main pane, and then click View > Customize View.
2. In the Customize View dialog box, select one of the following:

   * **Fields:** to add or remove fields from view
   * **Custom Filters:** to selectively choose categories to appear in the current view. Custom Filters is only available in the main view.
   * **Other Settings:** to customize grid options, auto preview for comments, and column sizing.
   * **Reset > System default:** to restore the system default settings.
   * **Reset > Distributed view:** to reset the settings to the distributed view level.
3. Click Save as Distributed View to save the current view settings as the distributed view. This option is only available for Administrator and Configuration Administrator.
4. Click OK to apply and close the dialog.

## Customize Additional View Settings

1. Click the main pane or the preview pane, and then click **View > Customize View**.
2. In the **Customize View** dialog box, click **Other Settings**.
3. In the Settings dialog, select:

   * **Show grid lines** to display the column and row separator lines. Enabled by default.
   * **Show "Group By" box** to display the Group By box above the columns for quick sorting.
   * **Show AutoPreview** to display comments below each row.
   * **Automatic column sizing** to fit all columns within the grid area.

     Note: AutoPreview and Group By are only available for grid views (not available for tree views).

**Parent page:** [Configure the Vault Environment](GUID-597293A4-CC5B-49A8-80C7-AB20E42EFB4D.htm)


### Customize Fields

# Customize Fields

You can customize how fields are displayed in the application window.

By making efficient use of properties and customizing your view, data management becomes much more tailored to your project.

Note: The main pane, change order view, and preview views are customized independently of each other. Custom settings do not apply to all panes.

Customize Fields

1. Click the pane that you want to customize, and then click View > Customize View.
2. In the Customize View dialog box, click Fields.
3. In the Customize fields dialog box, select which fields are available to choose from.

   * Frequently-used fields
   * All File fields
   * All Item fields
   * All Change Order fields

   Note: All of the above field types are available if a saved search was set to any type of object.
4. Select a field from the Available fields list, and then click Add. The field is moved to the list of fields currently displayed in the view.
5. To remove a field from the current view, select the field from the Show these fields in this order list, and then click Remove. The field is returned to the Available fields list.
6. Change the order of the fields in the current view by selecting one from the Show these fields in this order list, and then clicking either Move Up or Move Down.
7. Click OK.

Note: After choosing a field, it becomes available in the Frequently-used field drop-down list.

You can customize the view in the application window. By making efficient use of properties and customizing your view, data management becomes much more tailored to your project.

Note: The main pane, change order view, and preview views are customized independently of each other. Custom settings do not apply to all panes.

**Parent page:** [Configure the Vault Environment](GUID-597293A4-CC5B-49A8-80C7-AB20E42EFB4D.htm)


### Customize Toolbars and Menu Commands

# Customize Toolbars and Menu Commands

You can customize which menu commands are available on toolbars and create custom toolbars with your most frequently used commands.

Toolbars can be turned off or on. You can also create and delete custom toolbars. You can also change settings for showing full menus, menus usage data, and icon size.

The following toolbars can be customized, but they cannot be renamed or deleted:

* Main Menu
* Standard
* Advanced

**Access Customize Features**

* From the View menu, select Toolbars > Customize.

## Customize Toolbars

1. Click the Toolbars tab. The Toolbars tab lists the available toolbars.
2. You can either customize an existing toolbar or create a new toolbar. To create a new, empty toolbar, click New. In the New Toolbar dialog box, enter a name for the new toolbar and then click OK.
3. Click the Command tab.
4. From the Categories list, select a category containing the commands you want to add to the toolbar.
5. The Commands list displays the commands available in the selected category. Commands can be added to custom toolbars or to existing toolbars. Commands can also be removed from toolbars.

   * To add a command to a toolbar, drag-and-drop a command from the Commands list to the toolbar.
   * To remove a command from the toolbar, drag-and-drop it from the toolbar back to the Commands list.
   * You can rearrange the commands on the toolbar by dragging and dropping the icons on the toolbar.
   * To turn off a toolbar that is currently displayed, turn off the check box in front of the toolbar name in the list.
   * To display a toolbar that is currently turned off, turn on the check box in front of the toolbar name in the list.
   * To return a toolbar to its original content and layout, select the toolbar from the list, and then click Reset. You are prompted to confirm your actions. Click OK.
   * To remove a custom toolbar, select the toolbar from the Toolbars list, and then click Delete.
   * To rename a custom toolbar, select the toolbar from the Toolbars list and then click Rename. In the Rename Toolbar dialog box, enter a new name for the toolbar, and then click OK.
6. Click Close.

## Personalize Menus and Toolbars

1. In the Customization dialog box, click the Options tab.

   * To display menus that contain only the most frequently used commands, turn off the Always show full menus check box.
   * Turn on the Show full menus after a short delay check box to view the entire menu by pausing the cursor in the menu if you are using shortened menus. This option is only available if Always show full menus is turned off.
   * To reset the list of most frequently used commands, click Reset my usage data. Menus will display the full list and your usage data will start over.
   * To display large icons in the toolbars, turn on the Large icons check box.
   * To display ScreenTips when the cursor pauses over a button in a toolbar, turn on the Show ScreenTips on toolbars check box. To include shortcut keys for the command in the ScreenTip, turn on the Show shortcut keys in ScreenTips check box.
   * By default, the menus follow the same animation settings selected for Windows. To change the animation used to reveal a menu, select an animation style from the Menu animations list.
2. Click Close.

**Parent page:** [Configure the Vault Environment](GUID-597293A4-CC5B-49A8-80C7-AB20E42EFB4D.htm)

### Manage Custom Views

# Manage Custom Views

Use the Manage Custom Views dialog to save, define, and manage all defined views.

**Custom Views**

When you use Customize View to choose different fields or apply a custom filter, you are actually modifying the current view. The current view is shown in the Advanced toolbar. Create new named views to store different view configurations. Click the down-arrow on the Advanced toolbar to select different views.

Views are accessed by clicking the down arrow on the Advanced toolbar. The environment you are in determines the default view. The following are the default views:

* **Vault:** All Files
* **Item Master:** All Items
* **Change Orders:** All Change Orders

You can change the default by making a different selection and closing out of the dialog.

## Manage Custom Views

You can create and manage custom views. First, create the view you want to save, and then use the Manage Custom Views dialog to save and manage it.

The Manage Custom Views dialog lists all the defined views set by you as well as the administrator. You can see which custom view is configured on the Vault Client.

Note: You must have an "Administrator" or "Configuration Administrator" role to manage and deploy the [distributed views](GUID-D5AE6CDC-50FA-47A4-84D0-CA0A54C4E6D6.htm).

1. On the Advanced toolbar, click the down arrow, and select Define Custom View.
2. In the Manage Custom Views dialog, select one of the following:

   * **New:** to store the view that is currently displayed. You are prompted to name the view. In the Create Custom View dialog, enter a name and then click OK.

     For Administrators: Select the check box "Save as Distributed View" to save the customized view as a distributed view.
   * **Modify:** to change the settings of the selected view. Changes made to a view are automatically saved to the view definition.

     To modify the distributed view, it is recommended to copy the distributed view and then modify it to add/remove fields.
   * **Copy:** to copy the settings of the selected view into a newly created view. You can only copy one view at a time.
   * **Rename:** to rename the selected view. You must be an administrator to rename the distributed view.
   * **Delete:** to delete the selected view. You must be an administrator to delete the distributed view.
   * **Reset all distributed views**: to reset all the distributed views in all the workspaces to the default distributed level set by the administrator. All other views that are not distributed by the administrator won’t be affected.

   Note: Due to unique file name enforcement, you can't use the same name for both local and distributed views.

   If you create a local custom view using the same naming convention as a distributed view, Vault will replace the local view with the distributed view.
3. Click Apply to save the changes.
4. Click Done to close the dialog.

## Tips for Customizing the Vault View

You can customize the view in the application window. By making efficient use of properties and customizing your view, data management becomes much more tailored to your project.

Note: The Advanced toolbar displays the current view and provides access to creating and managing views.

### Turn the Navigation Pane On or Off

The navigation pane is located on the left side of the window. The navigation pane is displayed by default.

* From the View menu, select Navigation Pane.
* If the navigation pane is currently displayed, then it is hidden.
* If the navigation pane is currently hidden, then it is displayed.

### Turn the Preview Pane On or Off

The preview pane is located at the bottom of the window. The preview pane is displayed by default.

* From the View menu, select Preview Pane.
* If the preview pane is currently displayed, then it is hidden.
* If the preview pane is currently hidden, then it is displayed.

### Turn the Saved Shortcuts Pane On or Off

The saved shortcuts pane is part of the navigation pane. It displays the shortcuts you've created. It is displayed by default.

* From the View menu, select Saved Shortcuts pane.
* If the saved shortcuts pane is currently displayed, then it is hidden.
* If the saved shortcuts pane is currently hidden, then it is displayed.

  Note: The saved shortcuts pane is not displayed if the navigation pane is turned off.

### Turn the Toolbars On or Off

The standard toolbar is displayed by default.

* From the View menu, select Standard or Advanced.
* If the toolbar is currently displayed, then it is hidden.
* If the toolbar is currently hidden, then it is displayed.

### Customize How the Toolbar is Organized

The standard and advanced toolbar and menus can be customized to fit your needs.

1. From the View menu, select Customize. The Customization dialog is displayed.
2. Use the tabs to customize the organization of the toolbar, the menus, and to change menu options such as screen tips and usage data.
3. Drag the toolbar buttons to reorder, add, and remove buttons.

### Change the Display of Status Bar

The status bar at the bottom of the window displays the number of files currently selected, the name of the server into which you are currently logged, the name of the active vault database, and the account name currently logged into the vault. The status bar is turned on by default.

* From the View menu, select Status Bar. If the status bar is currently displayed, then it is hidden. If the status bar is currently hidden, then it is displayed.

### Customize the View

The view can be customized per folder.

1. Click on the folder.
2. Right-click on a column in the main pane.
3. Select Apply Settings to > Current View to customize the view of the currently opened folder.
4. Select Apply Settings to > Default View to customize all the folders in the current hierarchy.

**Parent page:** [Configure the Vault Environment](GUID-597293A4-CC5B-49A8-80C7-AB20E42EFB4D.htm)


### Manage Shortcuts

# Manage Shortcuts

A shortcut is a pointer to an associated folder or object.

Shortcuts can be created that point to folders , items, or files. When you click a shortcut in the navigation pane, the associated object is displayed in the main view. Shortcuts can be organized by groups, renamed, and removed from the navigation pane. The shortcuts that are displayed depend on the environment.

Note:

* Only file and folder shortcuts are available when the Vault environment is selected.
* Only item shortcuts are available when the Item Master environment is selected.
* All the shortcuts are listed when the Folder List is selected.

Shortcuts are saved for each user account, so you can have your own collection of frequently used shortcuts. You can see all saved shortcuts under Saved Shortcuts > My Shortcuts

In addition to the saved shortcuts created-by-you (listed under My Shortcuts), there are distributed shortcuts that are saved by the administrator tailored to your project. These are the initial shortcuts set when you access the system.

As an administrator, you can create a shortcut and save it as a distributed shortcut for use. The administrator can then deploy the distributed shortcut to the Vault Client, allowing users to use it for their regular activities.

Note: You must have an "Administrator" or "Configuration Administrator" role to manage and deploy client configuration settings.

As a user, you can use the default shortcut created by the administrator, or copy to modify it as per your requirement.

## Saved Shortcut Pane

The Saved Shortcuts pane displays and organizes any shortcuts to folders, items, or files that you create. It is part of the navigation pane. If you hide the navigation pane, the Saved Shortcuts pane is also hidden. By default, the Saved Shortcuts pane is displayed.

## Create a Shortcut

Right-click a folder in the navigation pane or on a file in the main view, and then select **Create Shortcut** from the context menu.

* Select **My Shortcut** to create a new shortcut for use.
* Select **Distributed shortcut** to create a new shortcut to be made available for users. This command is only available-for-administration.

Choose to show or hide the shortcut you have created. If you are administrator, you can choose to save the shortcut as a distributed shortcut to be deployed on the Vault Client.

A shortcut is added to the saved shortcut pane under My Shortcuts (created-by-you) or Distributed Shortcuts (created by administrator). You can drag shortcuts within the group to change their order within the list or drag from Distributed Shortcuts to list under My Shortcuts.

Shortcuts can also be created from links to objects. Right-click on a link to any object and select Create Shortcut from the context menu. A shortcut to the target object is added to the saved shortcut pane.

Note: Shortcuts created from a project link will direct the user to the target of the link. For example, if the user right-clicks on a link to an Item and chooses the Create Shortcut command, a shortcut is added to the saved shortcut pane that points to the Item. It does NOT point to the link to the Item. Refer to [Project Links](GUID-6BB2511B-FAE7-4C33-919A-E8AD09D47634.htm) for more information.

## Follow a Shortcut

Click a shortcut to display the contents of the associated folder or file in the main pane.

Note: If the shortcut points to a folder or file that has been deleted, you are informed that the associated object was deleted and prompted to delete the empty shortcut.

## Rename a Shortcut Group

Right-click a group, and then select **Rename** from the Context menu. Enter a new name for the group in the text box.

## Remove a Shortcut Group

Right-click a shortcut group and then select **Delete** from the Context menu. The shortcut group is removed and any shortcuts contained in the group are removed.

Note: Shortcuts cannot be created for search folders.

## Group Shortcuts

1. Right-click the My Shortcuts node or Distributed Shortcuts node (available-for-administration) under the Saved Shortcuts, and click **New Group**.
2. Enter a new name for the group in the text box.
3. Select a shortcut, and then drag it to the new group. The shortcut is moved into the group.
4. Double-click the group to expand it.
5. Drag shortcuts within the group to change their order within the list.

## Rename a Shortcut

Right-click a shortcut, and then select **Rename** from the Context menu. Enter a new name for the shortcut in the text box.

## Remove a Shortcut

Right-click a shortcut, and then select **Delete**. Only the shortcut is removed, not the associated folder or file.

## Manage Shortcuts

The Manage Shortcuts dialog lists all the saved shortcuts created-by-you and the administrator. You can choose to show/hide the saved shortcuts you have created to show on the Vault Client.

* **Copy**: to copy the selected shortcut. You can only copy one shortcut at a time.
* **Rename**: to rename the selected shortcut.
* **Delete**: to delete the selected shortcut.

Note: You must be an "Administrator" or "Configuration Administrator" to rename or delete the distributed shortcut.

**Parent page:** [Configure the Vault Environment](GUID-597293A4-CC5B-49A8-80C7-AB20E42EFB4D.htm)


### Set the Focus Location for Move Operation in Vault Client

# Set the Focus Location for Move Operation in Vault Client

Specify the default focus location for move operation in Vault Client within **Tools** > **Options**.

By default, the Focus Location for Move Operation in Vault Client is on the Target Location. Select the default setting of **Focus Location for Move Operation**:

* **Target Location:** Select **Target Location** to set as the default focus location for move operation.
* **Source Location:** Select **Source Location** to set as the default focus location for move operation.

### View File Details

# View File Details

Examine file details through the context menu.

View General Details for a File

1. Right-click on a file in the vault and select Details.

   You can also access the Details dialog by selecting Details from the File menu.
2. In the Details dialog box, select the General tab.

   You can review the following information on the General tab:

   * **Type**

     The File type. For example, an assembly, drawing, or Word document.
   * **Status**

     Indicates whether the file is available for check out or if it is already checked out.
   * **Location**

     Indicates the folder path for the selected file in the Vault.
   * **Size**

     The size of the selected file.
   * **Checked In**

     The date and time the file was last checked in.
   * **Created By**

     The creator of the file.

**Parent page:** [Work with Files and Folders in Vault](GUID-6F58BD92-B230-4AA0-8439-B624DF65DD8C.htm)


### View Folder Details

# View Folder Details

## View General Details for a Folder

1. Right-click on a folder in the vault and select Details.

   You can also access the Details dialog by selecting Details from the File menu.
2. In the Details dialog box, select the General tab.

   You can review the following information on the General tab:

   * **Type**

     Indicates whether the selected folder is a general folder or a library folder.
   * **Location**

     Indicates the folder path for the selected folder in the Vault.
   * **Working Folder**

     Indicates the corresponding working folder for the selected folder. This folder may be on the local drive or on a network and can be changed to a location from the Details dialog. Refer to [Map a New Working Folder](GUID-EA0A0A90-2BB3-4AFF-91DD-74B1C0FB7CB9.htm) for more information.
   * **Map to Shared Server**

     If the selected folder is a library folder, it can be mapped to a shared server. You can specify the location on the shared server by entering the location in the Map to Shared Server field.

### Using Data Standard

# Using Data Standard

Data Standard is a data control feature for the Vault Client, Vault Office Client, Inventor, and AutoCAD that helps you enter data for new or existing files in a standardized format.

Vault has many ways in which you can enter or modify data surrounding a file, but some companies require a standardized format for their files. With Data Standard, administrators can design a save dialog that enforces the company's requirements for file data.

Note: See [Data Standard Administration](https://beehive.autodesk.com/community/service/rest/cloudhelp/resource/cloudhelpchannel/guidcrossbook/?p=VAULT&l=ENU&accessmode=live&v=2026&guid=GUID-5030830E-69F8-4A57-ABE4-D1D430C58F95) for more information on customizing the Data Standard dialog.

## How It Works

The basic features of Data Standard are the same across all supported applications. Start your application, create a new document, and start writing or designing your content. After you first save a file, the Data Standard dialog appears requesting certain data. Once you complete all of the fields, Data Standard generates the file name and location based on the data. The Save button becomes active only when all required fields are complete.

Once the document has been saved, the entered data is mapped to the file's properties. You do not have to worry about project folders, revising the file, or generating a file name. Data Standard does everything.

#### Data Standard Interface for Vault Client and Vault Office Client

# Data Standard Interface for Vault Client and Vault Office Client

Manage file data and create new files in the Vault client or Vault Office client with the Data Standard feature.

Note: The Data Standard feature must be installed to use data sheets.

## The Data Standard Interface

Two new tabs display in the Vault client and Vault Office client by default when Data Standard is installed (CAD-BOM and Datasheet).

These tabs may change, or more may be added, based on how your administrator has designed the experience.

### CAD-BOM Preview

The CAD-BOM preview pane displays the BOM details for the selected file, including any data gathered from outside applications.

![](../images/cad-bom-preview.png)

### Datasheet Preview

The Datasheet preview displays standard file properties determined by your administrator. For example, the default datasheet provides at-a-glance view of pertinent file information, such as lifecycle state and category.

![](../images/datasheet-preview.png)

**Parent page:** [Using Data Standard](GUID-D475D22B-3873-4B78-9936-DD773F109136.htm)


#### Set Up a Data Standard File Template

# Set Up a Data Standard File Template

New files cannot be created with Data Standard until a templates folder is created in Vault and at least one file template has been added to the folder. This file template is used to create new Vault files.

1. Create a folder at the root ($) level of your vault called Templates.

   Note: Administrators can specify a different folder for the templates by modifying the XAML file. See [Customize Template Folder Path for Data Standard](https://beehive.autodesk.com/community/service/rest/cloudhelp/resource/cloudhelpchannel/guidcrossbook/?p=VAULT&l=ENU&accessmode=live&v=2026&guid=GUID-DBDC927B-269D-4552-AECF-37CEDE0AE326) for more information.
2. Add one or more templates from which to create files to the templates folder.

   ![](../images/templates-folder.png)

   After the template has been added, you can use Data Standard to [add new files](Create-a-New-Vault-File-with.htm) to the vault based on the template.

**Parent page:** [Using Data Standard](GUID-D475D22B-3873-4B78-9936-DD773F109136.htm)


#### Create a New Vault File with Data Standard

# Create a New Vault File with Data Standard

Create a new standard file in the Vault client.

Important: New files cannot be created with Data Standard unless the Templates folder, or another folder specified by your administrator, is created and at least one file template has been added.

Note: Creating new standard files is a default Data Standard feature. Your Administrator may have removed or modified this option.

1. Right-click on any file in the Vault Client and select New Standard File.

   Note: Vault Office Client users can only create data standard sheets for non-CAD files.
2. Select a [template](GUID-8ECC9F70-83C9-41E5-A8DD-77ECCF07471D.htm) from the list and fill in the information for the data sheet.

   Note: Vault Office Client users will only see non-CAD templates, such as Word Document, Excel Sheet, and PowerPoint Presentation.
3. Click OK to save your changes and finish creating the new file based on the specified template.

**Parent page:** [Using Data Standard](GUID-D475D22B-3873-4B78-9936-DD773F109136.htm)


#### Edit a Data Sheet

# Edit a Data Sheet

Edit a standard file in the Vault client.

Note: The Data Standard feature must be installed to use data sheets.

Note: Editing standard files is a default Data Standard feature. However, your Administrator may have removed or modified this option.

#### Using Data Standard with the Vault Add-ins

# Using Data Standard with the Vault Add-ins

The Vault Data Standard dialog is available in Inventor and AutoCAD. Whenever you first save a file, the Data Standard dialog displays. Fill in the required fields and any additional fields set up by your [administrator](https://beehive.autodesk.com/community/service/rest/cloudhelp/resource/cloudhelpchannel/guidcrossbook/?p=VAULT&l=ENU&accessmode=live&v=2026&guid=GUID-5030830E-69F8-4A57-ABE4-D1D430C58F95) and click OK to save your data. The data is saved as a Data Sheet that can be modified in the future.

Note: The Data Standard feature must be installed to use data sheets.

Note: The Data Standard feature must be enabled before you can use it.

## Default Data Standard Dialogs

Data Standard for Vault installs default Data Standard dialogs that can be modified by an administrator.

The default dialog differs based on your release of Vault.

Users can enter a new title, description, and company information for the file. All other fields are automatically determined by the XAML.

By default, the following fields are provided.

![](../images/newfile-inventor-2025-2.png)

Users can select a numbering scheme and, if applicable, add prefixes or suffixes. They can also choose a folder for the file and provide a title, description, and comments. If the desired folder is not available, users can create a new one.

Note: If no numbering schemes are available for selection, the File Name field can be edited.

All other fields are automatically determined by the XAML.

The file name is generated when the user clicks OK.

## Enable Data Standard for Inventor

Follow these steps to load, unload the Vault Data Standard.

1. In Autodesk Inventor, on the ribbon, click Vault > Load to enable the Data Standard add-in, or click Vault > Unload to disable the Data Standard add-in.

   Alternatively, in Autodesk Inventor, on the ribbon, click Tools > Add-Ins.
2. In the Add-in Manager dialog, double-click Vault Data Standard in the list to switch between Loaded and Unloaded. The load behavior list updates to reflect the selected behavior.

   or

   Select the Load Behavior checkbox to load or unload Data Standard.

   ![](../images/ds-inventor-add-in-loadbehavior-2022.1.png)
3. Click OK.

## Enable Data Standard for AutoCAD

Follow these steps to enable the Data Standard dialog.

1. Launch Autodesk AutoCAD.
2. Create a new file or open an existing file.

   Once the file is opened, the Data Standard tab becomes visible on the icon ribbon.

   ![](../images/ribbon-acad-datastandard.png)
3. Click Enable to start using the Data Standard dialog.

   Click Disable at any time to stop using it.

## Saving Files

When the Data Standard feature is enabled, you are prompted to enter file details every time you first save a file. This occurs whether you click Save on the main toolbar or on the Data Standard ribbon. Enter the required details and click OK to save your data. If the administrator has enabled the Check-in dialog for Vault, you may be prompted to fill your check-in details as well.

## Copying Files

Use the Copy command to copy an assembly or part that needs to be modified.

**Inventor Only–**Use the Copy incl. Drawing command to copy an open part or assembly as well as the drawing that references it. The copied drawing will reference the copied part or assembly.

Note: Only an open Inventor assembly or part can be selected.

For each new copy, the Data Standard dialog appears when the file is saved for the first time.

## Save Copy As (inventor-only)

Use Save Copy As to copy parts, assemblies, drawings, or presentations in other formats, such as DWG, STP, PDF, or DXF.

1. With the part, assembly, drawing, or presentation open, click Save Copy As.

   ![](../images/menu-inventordatastandardribbon-savecopyas.png)
2. On the Save copy as dialog, select the category, the format to which you want to copy the open file, and a numbering scheme, if applicable. Enter comments, if desired.

   ![](../images/dialog-inventordatastandard-savecopyas-dialog-2025-2.png)
3. Click the Options Button to customize the print range, display settings, or vector resolution for the file. Click OK.

   ![](../images/dialog-inventordatastandard-savecopyas-optionsdialog.png)
4. Click OK on the Save copy as dialog to save the file as the new format.

   The file is automatically saved in the workspace and the vault. There is no need to perform a Vault check-in.

## Replace with Copy (Inventor Only)

Use the Replace with Copy command to copy a component of an assembly and replace it in the original file. This is useful when you want to reuse an Inventor assembly and replace the components that need to be modified with a copy.

Use the Replace with Copy incl. Drawing command to copy the component and the drawing that references it and replaces both in the original file. The copied drawing will reference the copied component.

Note: Only first level components of an Inventor assembly can be selected.

![](../images/ds-ribbon-rwc-expand.png)

For each new copy, the Data Standard dialog appears when the file is saved for the first time.

Note: Data Standard prompts for Copy and Replace with Copy can be configured. See [Manage Prompts in the Inventor Add-in](GUID-CE294AD5-D8E6-44BE-8CAC-96F735738B31.htm) for more information.

### Replace with Copy or Replace with Copy including Drawing

Note: These instructions for Replace with Copy including Drawing assume that the drawing only has one base view. If the drawing has two base views, see the procedure following this one.

1. In an open Inventor Assembly, click Replace with Copy or Replace with Copy incl. Drawing on the Data Standard ribbon.
2. Select the component that you want to copy from the Inventor Browser.

   If the component is not checked out to you or you do not have the latest version or the component is not in a vault, you are asked if you want to proceed. Click OK.

   Note: The base part of a derived part and 3rd party OLE references are not copied and replaced.
3. Enter the desired information on the Copy dialog and click OK.
4. If there are multiple instances of the selected component in the assembly, decide whether you want to replace one or all instances.
5. If the component is used as base view and you selected Replace with Copy incl. Drawing, the Copy Dialog displays for the Drawing as well.

   Enter the desired information and click OK.
6. Click OK.

   The selected component is copied and the reference is replaced with the copy.

### Replace with Copy Including Drawing When the Drawing Has Two Base Views

If the drawing you want to copy and replace inside an assembly has two base views, you must perform additional steps to replace with copy. For clarity, we will use example names in parentheses.

1. Open the assembly (assembly1.iam) and click Copy on the Data Standard ribbon to create a copy of the assembly (assembly2.iam).
2. In the copied assembly (assembly2.iam), select the component (Part1.ipt) and click Replace with Copy on the Data Standard Ribbon.
3. The Data Standard dialog for the component displays. Fill in the necessary information and click OK.

   A copy of the component (part2.ipt) is created and replaced in the assembly (assembly2.iam).
4. The Data Standard dialog for the related drawing displays. Enter the necessary information and click OK.

   A copy of the drawing (drawing2.dwg) is created and the view of the component (part2.ipt) is replaced in the drawing (drawing2.dwg). However, the reference to the base view to the original assembly (assembly1.iam) is still in the new drawing (drawing2.dwg).
5. Open the new drawing (drawing2.dwg) and select Replace Model Reference in Inventor. Replace the original assembly (assembly1.iam) with the copied assembly (assembly2.iam) manually.

The drawing (drawing2.dwg) now contains the views to the copied assembly (assembly2.iam) and to the copied component (part2.ipt).

## Modify an Existing Datasheet

You can change the data on a datasheet after it is created.

1. Open the file for which you want to modify the datasheet.
2. Click Datasheet on the Data Standard ribbon.
3. Make your changes and click OK to save your data.

   Note: The OK button remains disabled until all required fields are filled in.

**Parent page:** [Using Data Standard](GUID-D475D22B-3873-4B78-9936-DD773F109136.htm)

##### Data Standard New Files Interface for Inventor Components–Tube and Pipe

# Data Standard New Files Interface for Inventor Components–Tube and Pipe

The New Files-Tube and Pipe data sheet lists all new files generated by the Tube and Pipe Module.

The following document types are supported for Tube and Pipe:

* Run assemblies
* Route parts
* Run components

Note: No option exists in the list for standard parts since they are saved immediately when inserted.

Uncollapse each sublist to see the files for each document type. Every file listed requires user input before the new file can be saved for the first time.

![](../images/screenshot-datastandard-tubeandpipe-expanderlist.png)

Select a file from the list to start filling in the data for that file.

Tip: Select one or more files of the same document type to make changes to them all at the same time. Fields with unique values for each file will show Varies as a value.

## Run Assemblies

1. Select a numbering scheme and enter any required text in the Number fields.

   Note: If no numbering schemes are available, move onto the next step.
2. Enter a title for the assembly. This field is required by default.
3. If desired, fill in a description of the assembly.
4. The path where the assembly is saved is defined by Inventor. This path cannot be edited.
5. The assembly name is provided by Inventor but can be modified.

   Note: Users can only modify the File Name if no numbering scheme is defined.
6. Include any comments about the assembly, if needed.

## Route Parts

1. Select a numbering scheme and enter any required text in the Number fields.

   Note: If no numbering schemes are available, move onto the next step.
2. Enter a title for the route part. This field is required by default.
3. If desired, fill in a description of the route part.
4. The state of the route part is automatically defined by Inventor. This value cannot be edited.
5. The path where the route part is saved is defined by Inventor. This path cannot be edited.
6. The route part name is provided by Inventor but can be modified.

   Note: Users can only modify the File Name if no numbering scheme is defined.
7. Include any comments about the route part, if needed.

## Run Components

1. Select a numbering scheme and enter any required text in the Number fields.

   Note: If no numbering schemes are available, move onto the next step.
2. Enter a title for the run component. This field is required by default.
3. If desired, fill in a description of the run component.
4. The state of the run component is automatically defined by Inventor. This value cannot be edited.
5. The path where the run component is saved is defined by Inventor. This path cannot be edited.
6. The run component name is provided by Inventor but can be modified.

   Note: Users can only modify the File Name if no numbering scheme is defined.
7. Include any comments about the run component, if needed.

When you are finished, click OK.

Note: The OK button becomes active only when all required fields for all data sheets have been filled in.

**Parent page:** [Data Standard for Generated Inventor Components](GUID-68BFB742-6EE8-46F1-99BE-7068C0EE658E.htm)

2. Enter a title for the frame component. This field is required by default.
3. If desired, fill in a description of the frame component.
4. The state of the frame component is automatically defined by Inventor. This value cannot be edited.
5. The path where the frame component is saved is defined by Inventor. This path cannot be edited.
6. The frame component name is provided by Inventor but can be modified.

   Note: Users can only modify the File Name if no numbering scheme is defined.
7. Include any comments about the frame component, if needed.

When you are finished, click OK.

Note: The OK button becomes active only when all required fields for all data sheets have been filled in.

### Change the Working Folder

# Change the Working Folder

Specify a different working folder.

You can browse the working folder, specify a different working folder, or set up a shared working folder for multiple users.

## Understand Working Folders

The working folder contains read-only copies of files that have not been checked out from a vault. When a file is checked out, the checked out version from the vault replaces the file in the working folder and becomes read-write for editing. When the file is checked back into the vault, the local version in the working folder returns to read-only.

A working folder location is defined by default, allowing you to begin working with a vault right away. The default working folder is:

* My Documents\Vault

If you are using Civil 3D, the default working folder is:

* C:\Civil 3D Projects

Important: Do not move files from the local working folder after they have been checked out. Files checked out to the working folder must always be checked back into the vault from the same working folder.

## Map a Vault Folder to a Different Working Folder

You can change the working folder for a specific folder and its contents on the Details dialog.

1. Right-click on a folder in the vault and then select Details.
2. In the Details dialog box, select the General tab.
3. To select a new working folder, click Working Folder and browse to a new location on the local computer.
4. To reset the assigned working folder to the default path of My Documents\Vault, click Default.

   Note: While you can override the default working folder location, if the administrator is enforcing the location, it cannot be changed.
5. If the folder is a library folder, it can be mapped to a shared server. To map a shared server to a library folder, enter a path in the Map to Shared Server field.

   Note: The Map to Shared Server location will be replaced in case the working folder is enforced by the administrator.

After changing the working folder in Vault, you need to re-connect to Vault.

The Map to Shared Server function is used only in AutoCAD to relocate AutoCAD designs at the network folder into Vault.

**Parent page:** [Work with Files and Folders in Vault](GUID-6F58BD92-B230-4AA0-8439-B624DF65DD8C.htm)


### Move Files

# Move Files

Use the Move command to move files from one folder to another. This does not effect any of the file information such as version history, children, or parents. All internal dependencies will not be updated until getting outside of Vault.

When moving files, there is no effect on the vault-related information, however you may effect how and if the file can be opened by the authoring application. Many tools embed folder structures into the file such as a relative or absolute path. Moving files can cause these links to break.

Notes:

* Moving Autodesk Inventor files outside the scope of project file may cause unresolved link when opening in Inventor.
* It is not possible to move a Revit file with references to another Revit file in vault.
* The project specified in Autodesk Inventor Project Settings will be used for file resolving.

## Move files in a vault

1. Select a file or files.
2. From the Edit menu, select Move to Folder.
3. In the Select Vault Location dialog box, browse for the new location in the vault and then click OK.

**Parent page:** [Work with Files and Folders in Vault](GUID-6F58BD92-B230-4AA0-8439-B624DF65DD8C.htm)


### Move Folders

# Move Folders

Use the Move command to move folders from one location to another inside the vault. The file references in the folder will be updated when getting outside of Vault. Library folders in a vault cannot be moved.

## Move folders in the vault

1. Select a folder in the vault.
2. From the Edit menu, select Move to Folder.
3. In the Select Vault Location dialog box, browse for the new location in the vault and then click OK.

### Update File References

# Update File References

Update the file references for migrated files.

When adding a file to the vault from a CAD application, reference information which is used for updating files renamed or moved in Vault is automatically created. However, the files migrated from previous releases may be incomplete. You can see the parent or child in the Uses or Where Used tab, but a rename or move action will be blocked to protect the data. To resolve this issue, you can update file references before renaming or moving migrated files.

Note: The corresponding authoring application is required to run this command.

1. From the Actions menu, select Update File Reference.
2. Select a file, files or folder.

All file references are updated.

### Rename Files

# Rename Files

Rename a file in a vault.

When renaming files, the Rename Wizard may not update the related files which reference the files being renamed until getting the files outside of Vault (eg. Get/Check Out, Pack and Go and etc.). New file names can be specified in the Rename wizard or a naming scheme can be selected for renaming. A report listing the files that were renamed can be exported from the Rename Wizard. Only rename files in the vault using the Rename Wizard. Files being renamed must be checked into the vault before renaming.

Most files in the vault can be renamed using the Rename wizard, including Autodesk AutoCAD .dwg files as well as Autodesk Inventor .dwg files. Some file types can also be renamed using the Copy Design wizard. The version of a renamed file is incremented. The Comment field for each file effected by the rename process contains the comment "Rename" to annotate that point in the file history.

Note: iPart member files that use the key-based naming convention and custom iPart member files cannot be renamed. Automatically published visualization files are not supported. Automatically published visualization files are not directly supported.

Note: The project specified in Autodesk Inventor Project Settings will be used for file resolving.

You can rename files in a vault. When renaming files, the Rename Wizard may not update the related files which reference the files being renamed until getting the files outside of Vault (eg. Get/Check Out, Pack and Go and etc.). New file names can be specified in the Rename wizard or a naming scheme can be selected for renaming. A report listing the files that were renamed can be exported from the Rename Wizard. Only rename files in the vault using the Rename Wizard.

## Rename a File

You must be assigned the role of either Editor or Administrator to perform this action. Contact your vault administrator to verify your role.

Note: Files being renamed must be checked into the vault before renaming. iPart member files that use the key-based naming convention and custom iPart member files cannot be renamed. Automatically published visualization files are not supported.

**Notes:**

* Files being renamed must be checked into the vault before renaming. iPart member files that use the key-based naming convention and custom iPart member files cannot be renamed. Automatically published visualization files are not supported.
* It is not possible to rename a Revit file with references to another Revit file in vault. Vault cannot update the file reference in the parent file.

1. Select a file or files and then from the Edit menu, select Rename.

   The Rename wizard opens and lists the file or files that were selected from the main pane.
2. Click **[Add Files](https://beehive.autodesk.com/community/service/rest/cloudhelp/resource/cloudhelpchannel/guidcrossbook/?p=VAULT&l=ENU&accessmode=live&v=2026&guid=GUID-A55AD9BD-1801-4BD8-8A36-C096F85018C4)** to include other files to be renamed.
3. Click Next.

   Related parent files will be updated on the next file download. If there are difficulties detected with updating certain related files, those files are listed in the Related Files tab.
4. Click Next.

   The files to be renamed are listed.
5. Click in the New Name box for each file to enter a new file name.
6. Click Numbering Scheme to assign a numbering scheme to selected files, add prefixes and suffixes, or modify the file name directly. You can turn off the default prefix to retain the existing file name.

   You can also copy paste values between multiple editable columns such as New Name, Update Part Number and Numbering Schema. This can save you a lot of time when working with large datasets.
7. Select Update Part Number to update the part number to reflect the new filename on renamed files.
8. Click Next.

   The files you selected are checked out, provided you have the permissions to do so, renamed, and the results shown.
9. Optional: Save the changes as a report and add it to Vault.

### Rename Folders

# Rename Folders

Rename folders in a vault.

Renaming folder is considered as a path change operation to the files inside the folder. Therefore, the files referencing the files inside the folder are required to update when getting outside of Vault (such as Get/Check Out, Pack and Go and so on).

Before renaming a folder, make sure all files in the folder are checked into the vault. If a file in the folder is checked out, then the folder cannot be renamed.

After renaming a vault folder that is part of an Autodesk Inventor project, edit the Autodesk Inventor project file, .ipj, to map the project to the new folder name.

## Rename a Folder

1. Right-click on a vault folder and then select Rename.
2. Enter a new name for the vault folder.

If the vault folder is part of an Autodesk Inventor project, open Autodesk Inventor and edit the corresponding project file, .ipj, to reflect the name of the new folder.

### Replace Files

# Replace Files

The Replace command changes the references in a parent file to point to a different child file.

Note: You must have permission to check out all related files before replacing a file.

The file being replaced is not removed from the vault, versioned, or modified in any way. Only the immediate parent files are changed to reference the new file. As a result, a new version of the parent file is created. Previous versions of the parent file will reference the old file. New versions of the parent file will reference the new file.

The immediate parent files of a file being replaced must be checked in before replacing a file. Replacing a file requires that the necessary add-in for the parent file is installed so that the parent file can be repaired to use the new reference.

Note: AutoCAD xrefs contained in Autodesk Inventor .dwg files can be replaced using the Replace command. Autodesk Inventor .dwg and .idw files that do not have parents cannot be replaced.

## Replace Files

Note: You must have permission to check out all related files before replacing a file.

1. Select a file or files and then from the Edit menu, select Replace.

   Note: It is recommended that you select the leading version of the latest revision of a file when replacing it to ensure that the most recent data and file references are included.
2. The wizard lists the file or files that were selected from the main pane. Click Add Files to include other files from the vault.

   To exclude a file from being replaced, select it from the list and then click Remove.

   * If any of the selected files cannot be replaced due to restrictions in the vault, a list of restricted files is displayed. Select a file in the list to see the reason for that file being restricted.
   * If some of the files can be replaced, you are prompted whether to continue or not. Click Yes to continue replacing the files that are not restricted.
3. Click Next.
4. In the Identify Parent Files screen, the immediate parents affected by the change are listed.

   * By default, all of the parent files are selected. Turn off the check box next to a parent file to exclude it from being repaired with the new reference. Expand a parent file to see which of the files to be replaced will cause the parent to be repaired.
   * If the parent file is currently checked out or the necessary add-in for the parent is not installed, the parent is identified with an asterisk and red text. Click Back to remove the file to be replaced from the list or verify that the Autodesk Vault add-in for the parent file's application is installed. If one parent cannot be repaired, then none of the parent files will be repaired. You must resolve the issue before repairing any of the parent files.
5. Click Next.
6. The Specify Replacement Files screen lists the old files to be replaced. For each old file, click the browse button, ..., in the New File column and select the replacement file.

   Note: The state of the replacement file does not matter. A replacement file can be a file that is already checked out. When replacing files in an Inventor assembly, the replacement file must be within the project workspace of the parent file. Using the recommended setup of a single project file for the vault will avoid this restriction.
7. Click Finish.
8. You are prompted that replacing a component in an assembly may break constraints in Autodesk Inventor assembly files.

   * Click Yes to continue with the replacement.
   * Click No to return to the Replace Wizard.
9. The final screen of the Replace Wizard displays the results of the replace operation. The report lists the files that were replaced and the parent files that were repaired to include the new reference.
10. You can choose to generate a report as a text file and save it locally or in the vault by performing one of these options:

    * To save the report locally, click Save. On the Save As dialog, navigate to the folder structure where you want to store the file locally. Enter a name for the report and click Save.
    * To save the report in a vault, Click Send to Vault to display a list of vault folders. Select the vault in which you want the report saved, enter a name for the report, and click Save.

    The comment "Replace" is added to all files that have been replaced.
11. Click Close.

**Parent page:** [Work with Files and Folders in Vault](GUID-6F58BD92-B230-4AA0-8439-B624DF65DD8C.htm)


### Labels

# Labels

Throughout the design process, there are milestones that you want to capture. These milestones represent points in time such as customer proposals, design reviews, or concept variations. You can label these milestones so they can be easily identified.

Using labels, you can establish baselines and track marked progress for work-in-progress files. As the design progresses, you can also use these milestones to archive and retrieve past versions.

When you create a label, the most recent checked in version of every file in the project is assigned that label. If files within the project have child references outside of the current folder, those files are also assigned the label. There is no limit to the number of labels that can be assigned to a project. You cannot create more than one label with the same name.

Labels do not include folder information, only the project files are labeled. To help you identify the labeled project, include the name of the project in the label name and add a descriptive comment summarizing the extent of the label.

The Labels dialog box allows you to create new labels and view existing ones. You can also delete labels, rename labels, extract labeled files from the vault using Pack and Go, and restore labeled files. Labels can be viewed by anyone with permission to see labels.

## Manage Labels

All vault users can view labels; however, only user accounts assigned the role of Editor or Administrator can create and manage labels. The Labels dialog box is used to manage and view labels. Labels can be created, deleted, renamed, archived, and restored all from the Labels dialog box. The Labels dialog box also displays details about labels, such as who created it, when it was created, how many files are assigned to the label, and the comment associated with the label.

Assigning a label to a project creates a dependency between the project files and the corresponding label. Files associated with labels cannot be deleted from the vault unless the label is deleted first. When you delete a label, only the label is removed. The associated files remain in the vault.

No two label names can be the same. When naming labels, the following characters are restricted: \ / : \* ? " < > |

#### Extract Labels

# Extract Labels

Labeling a project allows you to archive or extract all of the project files that represent that milestone or baseline. By extracting the labeled project, you are capturing the project at a specific point in time. The captured project can then act as a roll-back target should it ever be necessary to return to the last labeled milestone.

## Extract a Label

Extract labels to cpature a project at a specific point in time. The captured project can then act as a roll-back target should it ever be necessary to return to the last labeled milestone.

1. From the Tools menu, select Labels.
2. In the Labels dialog box, select a label from the labels list.
3. Click Pack and Go.
4. Specify the location on the local computer or a network drive for the extracted label to be saved.
5. Select the type of package to be created, either a folder containing the files or a compressed Zip file. If you select Zip file, specify the name of the Zip file.
6. Select the label to pack. If only one label is available, no other labels are listed.
7. The extracted label can retain the folder structure from the vault or place all files in a single, flat directory. Select either Copy to Single Path or Keep Folder Hierarchy.
8. Click OK.

#### Restore a Label

# Restore a Label

Because a label is applied to the entire project, it is a convenient way of restoring a project in a single operation rather than restoring individual files. Restoring a label returns the packed versions of the files associated with a label to the vault as the newest versions of the files.

By restoring a label, you can rollback a project should it be necessary to return to a previous milestone. For example, you can rollback the project to the versions of the files labeled as "Initial Design" if the project has strayed too far off course or if the files have to be returned to the last known good state.

All of the files associated with the label must be checked in before restoring the label. Even files checked out to the person restoring the label must be checked in.

When a label is restored, all of the files associated with the label are restored to the vault. You cannot choose which files within the label are restored. The label represents the project in its entirety.

If you cancel the restoration process, the files that have been returned to the vault up to that point stay in the vault. The remaining files associated with the label are not restored.

## Restore a Label

Restore a label to return the packed versions of the files associated with a label to the vault as the newest versions of the files.

1. From the Tools menu, select Labels.
2. In the Labels dialog box, select a label from the labels list.
3. Click Restore.
4. You are prompted to confirm restoring the selected label and creating a new version of all the associated files. Click Yes.

The progress of the restoration is displayed. The files associated with the label are restored to the vault as the latest version.

## Copy Design

# Copy Design

Create new design objects by copying existing data within a vault with the Copy Design feature. Depending on which design application you are using, copying a design involves copying a drawing and its related files, copying an entire design structure along with the related 2D drawings for 3D models, or copying components of a design.

Copy Design is now a modeless dialog with a toolbar: It can now remain open while you use the Vault client for other commands as well as add files to be copied.

The Copy Design feature creates a copy of the design with the same structure as the source files. In the Copy Design dialog, you can choose which parts of an existing design to copy, reuse, reuse branch, replace, exclude, or detach.

Copy Design Dialog
