#### Add or Remove User-Defined Properties

# Add or Remove User-Defined Properties

Add or remove a [user-defined property](https://beehive.autodesk.com/community/service/rest/cloudhelp/resource/cloudhelpchannel/guidcrossbook/?p=VAULT&l=ENU&accessmode=live&v=2026&guid=GUID-1EC10936-9D84-4179-AEE3-59DD1B3E003C) (UDP) from a Vault object.

Note: Add or remove UDPs from Reference Designators or a Bills of Materials rows as well. Bills of Materials are available in Vault Professional.

You must have administrative access to perform these tasks.

## Add or Remove a Property

1. In the Vault client, select one or more vault objects in the same entity class (e.g., folders, files, items, change orders, etc.).

   Note: Items, change orders, and custom objects are available in Vault Professional.

   Note: The Add or Remove Property command is only available on one entity at a time. The menu item will not be available when selecting more than one entity type in a selection. For example, if you want to add a property to both files and folders, you must do the files first and then the folders.
2. Click Actions > Add or Remove Property.
3. In the Add or Remove Property dialog box, select the property from the Property list.
4. From the Action value of the property select Add or Remove from the drop-down list.

   * **Add.** The property is added to the selected object using the default value. If the property is already assigned to the selected object, no action is taken.
   * **Remove**. The property is removed from the selected object or objects. If the property is not assigned to the selected object(s), no action is taken.

   Note: If any restrictions occur with a selected object, the property is neither added nor removed and an error message is displayed.
5. Click OK.

Note: If a property is assigned by means of a category, it cannot be removed from a file. Removing the association to the category will allow you to remove the property.

**Parent page:** [Work with Properties in the Vault Client](GUID-F1EB65CD-2491-422D-92B8-4EEB62BC9626.htm)

To update the Revision table, set the value to 1 in the ‘Connectivity.VaultPro.dll.config’ file for the following keys:

### Update Properties–Vault Add-ins

# Update Properties–Vault Add-ins

File properties can be mapped to data in Autodesk Vault. If the mapped properties are edited, the data can be updated using the Update File Properties command. This action keeps the data and assigned properties synchronized.

For more information about mapping properties, refer to [Properties Administration](https://beehive.autodesk.com/community/service/rest/cloudhelp/resource/cloudhelpchannel/guidcrossbook/?p=VAULT&l=ENU&accessmode=live&v=2026&guid=GUID-26645DD0-AC27-4CFB-BC15-41719B5DE609) in the Administrator Tasks's section.

## AutoCAD Vault Add-in

Note: This feature available in Autodesk Vault Professional.

Use the Update Properties feature in AutoCAD or Autodesk Mechanical to keep the data and assigned properties synchronized.

The Update Properties feature is integrated with the vault revision table feature whereby it keeps revision block data synchronized with vault released information.

### Update Properties

Update properties by performing one of these procedures while working with a vaulted file:

* Click Update Properties on the Vault toolbar or Vault ribbon. In the Update Properties dialog box, all of the files that can have properties updated are listed. Turn off the check box in front of any files you do not want to update. Click OK.
* Type **vltgetlatestproperties** in the command line and press Enter. You will be prompted to enter the full Vault file name.

The Vault CAD properties that are mapped to Vault files are updated to reflect any changes made in Vault.

Note: If the mapped property with AutoCAD block attributes has noncompliant equivalence error, you need to modify the settings for the property and set the Create option to "No". Click Refresh in Vault Client to resolve the error. For more information, see [Map Properties](https://beehive.autodesk.com/community/service/rest/cloudhelp/resource/cloudhelpchannel/guidcrossbook/?p=VAULT&l=ENU&accessmode=live&v=2026&guid=GUID-915561C8-1143-4E68-BE41-37376FA39A58).

## Inventor Vault Add-in

Autodesk Vault file properties can be mapped to CAD data in Autodesk Vault. If the mapped properties are edited, the CAD data can be updated using the Update Properties feature in Autodesk Inventor to keep the data and assigned properties synchronized.

The Update Properties feature is integrated with the vault revision table feature so that revision block data is synchronized with vault released information.

Note: It is important that you understand properties and vault revision table before doing anything with your files' properties.

### Update Properties

The Update Properties command retrieves file properties from Autodesk Vault and updates the mapped properties in the corresponding Autodesk Inventor files. Files must be checked out before getting the latest properties.

The Update Properties dialog box lists the Autodesk Inventor files that are currently checked out and can be updated.

![](../images/icon-tree-view-vlt.gif) View the contents of the vault in a tree structure.

![](../images/icon-list-view.gif) View the contents of the vault in a flat list.

**Settings**

Displays the options for updating properties for parents and children.

### Update Properties Settings

#### Include children

Gets the latest properties of the files that are dependent on the selected file.

#### Include parents

Gets the latest properties of all files that depend on the selected file.

#### OK

Applies the settings to the Update Properties dialog box.

#### Cancel

Closes the Settings dialog box without applying changes to the Update Properties dialog box.

### Access Update Properties

Note: Files must be checked out before getting the latest properties from assigned files.

1. On the Vault ribbon tab in Autodesk Inventor, click Update Properties.
2. In the Update Properties dialog box, the files that are currently checked out and can be updated are listed. Turn off the check box in front of any files you do not want to update.
3. Click Settings to specify if parents and children of the selected files are also updated.
4. Click OK.

The vault CAD properties that are mapped to Autodesk Vault properties are updated to reflect any changes made in Autodesk Vault.

## Vault Revision Tables (add-ins-only)

# Vault Revision Tables (add-ins-only)

Learn about using revision tables with Vault.

The Revision table is a box of information on a drawing containing key information about the drawing and where it stands in its lifecycle. A revision table typically includes the revision letter, a description of changes, the date of the last change, zonal information, and approval information. The values contained in the revision table represent the properties associated with the drawing and not the associated part/assembly or its children.

The process of manually updating the revision tables on drawings can be time-consuming, especially for changes that require simple property updates throughout the drawing's lifecycle. The Vault Revision Table feature allows you to automatically update a drawing's revision table data. Since multiple revision tables may exist in the same drawing, the Vault Revision Table feature tracks and updates all tables that begin with a named identifier.

Administrators can configure the Vault Revision Table behavior by determining the mapped values and display settings within the [Vault Revision Table Settings](https://beehive.autodesk.com/community/service/rest/cloudhelp/resource/cloudhelpchannel/guidcrossbook/?p=VAULT&l=ENU&accessmode=live&v=2026&guid=GUID-FC3208AC-25AA-432C-A4A1-0F4A24FB5709) dialog. This dialog can also be accessed via the Behaviors tab on the Vault Settings dialog in the Autodesk Vault client.

## Supported Drawings

* AutoCAD drawings (.dwg)
* AutoCAD Mechanical drawings (.dwg)
* Autodesk Inventor drawings (.idw)
* Autodesk Inventor drawings (.dwg)

## Pre-requisites

Note: The system property 'Revision' is a key mapping and be must be mapped to at least one of the column headers.

* Autodesk Inventor is installed so that Inventor IDW and DWG drawings can be updated.
* Revision Table functionality is enabled.
* The [Job Server](GUID-ACFA69F2-EF56-4FC5-BFA3-C17CB50D08FB.htm) is enabled with the synchronize properties option selected for the required state transition(s).
* Suitable column headers are created and their property mappings established between the drawings' revision table columns and the Vault properties.

### Create a Revision Table in AutoCAD

# Create a Revision Table in AutoCAD

Use the **vltrevblock** command to create a Vault Revision Table and thereafter apply vault data to it.

The Vault Revision Table exists within AutoCAD in the form of a custom block with the name vaac\_RevBlock. Do not purge or rename the **vaac\_Revblock** block as it is referenced by both the Vault client and the AutoCAD Vault add-in for subsequent updates.

1. Type **vltrevblock** in the command line and press Enter.

   Note: The mapped fields for a Vault Revision Table on a non-vaulted drawing are displayed as empty to reflect the null state of information in the vault.
2. Click on a position in the drawing area to place the Vault Revision Table.

   Once a new Vault Revision Table is placed, all previous inserted instances will also be updated with Vault properties as defined by the administrator.

Note: Apply the Vault Revision Table to drawing templates to make deployment easy across your organization.

**Parent page:** [Vault Revision Tables (add-ins-only)](GUID-435562F5-6E8E-49C2-9914-19DAB3788289.htm)

Use the Vault Revision command to create an Inventor Revision Table in the drawing environment and apply vault data to it.

1. On the Ribbon, select the Annotate tab and click the Table panel > Vault Revision command.

   Note: The mapped fields for a Vault Revision Table in a non-vaulted drawing display empty values to reflect the null state of information in the vault.
2. Click on a position in the graphics window to place the Vault Revision Table.

   Note: The Vault Revision Table adopts the default style set in your Inventor environment.

   Note: Once the Vault Revision Table is placed, all drawing scoped Revision History objects are updated with Vault properties as defined by the administrator.

Tip: Apply the Vault Revision Table to the drawing templates to make deployment easier across your organization.

### Set the Location of the Revision Table Template in AutoCAD

# Set the Location of the Revision Table Template in AutoCAD

By default, the templates that determine the Vault Revision Table style, layout, and format are created in the user's application data folder. However you can refer these templates from another location within the local machine or from a shared network location.

This can be achieved by inserting a set of XML tags in the acad.exe.config file found within the AutoCAD installation directory.

## Change the location of the Vault Revision Table template for drawings in imperial units

1. Open the file acad.exe.config from the AutoCAD installation directory using an XML editor or Notepad.
2. Within the <AppSettings> tag, add the following XML tag:

   <add key="VltRevBlockImperialTemplate" value="C:\Imperial.dwg"/>

   In this instance, the Imperial.dwg file is located in the C:\ drive root directory. You may change this to a location of your choice.

## Change the location of the Vault Revision Table template for drawings in metric units

1. Open the file acad.exe.config from the AutoCAD installation directory using an XML editor or Notepad.
2. Within the <AppSettings> tag, add the following XML tag:

   <add key="VltRevBlockMetricTemplate" value="C:\Metric.dwg"/>

   In this instance, the Metric.dwg file is located in the C:\ drive root directory. You may change this to a location of your choice.

Note: The AutoCAD application must be restarted to apply any modified settings to the acad.exe.config.

**Parent page:** [Vault Revision Tables (add-ins-only)](GUID-435562F5-6E8E-49C2-9914-19DAB3788289.htm)


### Edit the Revision Table Template in AutoCAD

# Edit the Revision Table Template in AutoCAD

When the Vault add-in for AutoCAD is loaded for the first time, a set of default templates is created . You can modify the style, layout, and format of the Vault Revision Table by customizing these templates.

Edits made to the template are available only in new drawings that use the template. Existing drawings that use the template do not reflect these changes. To update a Vault Revision Table with settings from a new or modified template, you must delete all existing Vault Revision Tables and purge the vaac\_RevBlock block prior to creating a new revision table.

The default templates are based in both imperial and metric systems of measurement. You must edit both templates if you are working with both types of measurement systems.

## Edit the Vault Revision Table template for drawings in imperial units

1. Open vaac\_RevBlockImperial.dwg in AutoCAD.

   * C:\Users\{username}\AppData\Roaming\Autodesk\AutoCAD {version} Vault Add-in\
2. Type **Bedit** on the command line to open the Edit Block Definition dialog box.
3. Select the vaac\_RevBlock block instance.
4. Within Block Editor, perform your edits on the table style, layout, and format.
5. Go to the Block Editor tab on the ribbon and Click Close Block.
6. Save the file.

## Edit the Vault Revision Table template for drawings in metric units

1. Open vaac\_RevBlockMetric.dwg in AutoCAD.

   * C:\Users\{username}\AppData\Roaming\Autodesk\AutoCAD {version} Vault Add-in\
2. Type **Bedit** on the command line to open the Edit Block Definition dialog box.
3. Select the vaac\_RevBlock block instance.
4. Within Block Editor, perform your edits on the table style, layout, and format.
5. Go to the Block Editor tab on the ribbon and Click Close Block Editor.
6. Save the file.

Edits made to the template are available only in new drawings that use the template. Existing drawings that use the template do not reflect these changes. To update a Vault Revision Table with settings from a new or modified template, you must delete all existing Vault Revision Tables and purge the vaac\_RevBlock block prior to creating a new revision table.

**Parent page:** [Vault Revision Tables (add-ins-only)](GUID-435562F5-6E8E-49C2-9914-19DAB3788289.htm)

## Items

# Items

Learn about using items in Vault.

Autodesk Vault Professional tracks the lifecycle of items used to manufacture products. The vault manages the files necessary to produce those items, such as CAD designs and the supporting documentation. Because information from the vault needs to be consumed by departments outside of engineering, the files in the vault are linked to items. When a file is assigned an item, a unique item number based on your company's standard is assigned to the item and a Bill of Materials is generated that tracks the relationships between associated items using the file relationship information from the vault.

## What is an item?

Items refer to what a company manages, assembles, sells, and manufactures. An item is identified by its item number or part number. Items typically represent:

* Parts
* Assemblies
* Consumable goods such as fluids, lubricants, and artwork
* Bills of Material

Items can be created in two ways:

* Assign an item to a file using the Assign Item command.
* Drag and Drop files into the Item Master tab
* Drag and Drop files into the Item Master node in the browser
* Use the New item command within the Item Master to create an item from scratch.

Note: New items tend to be user-defined items that are not included in the CAD design such as grease, adhesives, or mechanical components that are not modeled.

## What is the item master?

The Item Master is the complete list of all items within the vault. You can switch to the Item Master view by clicking the Item Master group button.

### Item Tasks

Each item in the vault has an item record. Use the Item Record dialog box to perform the following item tasks:

* View general item details
* View and edit item properties
* Change item numbers
* Change item lifecycle state or revision
* View item revision history
* View and edit BOM data
* View where used information
* View Change Orders applied to the item
* Add items to a new or existing Change Order
* Attach files and edit attachments

## Item rules

* The following files can be assigned items:

  + Inventor .ipt and .iam files checked in using the Inventor add-in.
  + AutoCAD and AutoCAD Mechanical .dwg files checked in using the add-in for AutoCAD products.
  + AutoCAD Electrical project file (wdp).

    **Note:** If you assign an item to a .dwg file that belongs to an AutoCAD Electrical project, the project file is assigned to an item, and each .dwg that belongs to that project is assigned to an item.
  + Any non-CAD files such as Microsoft Office documents.
* The files must be checked into the vault before assigning an item.
* The files must be checked in with a native application to have the BOM information for assign and update item.
* The permission assigned to a user determines the item tasks the user can perform.
* The security of an item determines which operations may be applied to an item.

## Who can work with items?

Vault Professional uses a secure database. A user must have an account to access data and must be assigned appropriate user permissions. User permissions are set using the following roles:

| Role | Description |
| --- | --- |
| *Administrator* | Full privileges within Vault Professional and administrative privileges on the server. ERP tasks are included. |
| *Item Editor Level 1* | Basic file and item privileges within Autodesk Vault Professional, but cannot delete files, folders, or items. No administrative privileges on the server. |
| *Item Editor Level 2* | Full privileges within Vault Professional, but no administrative privileges on the server. |
| *Item Reviewer* | Read-only access to items and files. |
| *Document Editor Level 1* | Basic file adding and editing privileges within the vault, but cannot delete files and folders. No administrative privileges on the server. |
| *Document Editor Level 2* | Full privileges within the vault, but no administrative privileges on the server. |
| *Document Consumer* | Read-only access to vault data only. |
| *ERP Manager* | Performs ERP tasks:   * Configure and manage the MSMQ DWF settings. * Import ERP: Import an item from an ERP system into Vault Professional. * Export ERP: Exports items for use with an ERP system. |

### View Item Record Details

# View Item Record Details

You can examine the details of an item through the Preview Pane or by examining the item record.

## View an Item Summary

1. In the Item Master, select an item.

   The item record information is displayed in the preview pane.
2. Select a tab to review different details about the item and associated files.

## View General Item Information

1. In the Item Master, select an item.
2. Select the General tab in the Preview Pane. The General tab summarizes information about the selected item, including:

   * Revision
   * Item number
   * Title
   * Description
   * Units
   * Item category
   * Lifecycle state
   * Revision
   * The last user to update the item
   * The date the item was last updated
   * Files associated with the item
   * Item properties
3. To see other revisions of the item, select a revision from the drop-down list.
4. Right-click on an associated file and select Go to Folder to go to the vault folder where the associated file is stored.

   You can also open the associated file in its native application or view it in the preview window.

## View the Revision History of an Item

1. In the Item Master, select an item.
2. Select the History tab in the Preview Pane.

   The revisions of the item are listed. Each revision listed includes statistics such as the item name, the revision number, the lifecycle state, the item title, the item class, and units.
3. Select Show all versions to see every iteration of the selected item.

## View a Bill of Materials for an Item

1. In the Item Master, select an item.
2. Select the Bill of Materials tab in the Preview Pane.

   The Bill of Material for the selected item is listed.

   Note: To edit a Bill of Materials, you must open the item and edit the BOM in the Item dialog box.
3. You can choose to view the BOM either by date or revision:

   * **View BOM by Revision** - Select a revision from the revision drop-down. The date the revision was last used prior to being superceded by a newer revision is displayed in the date drop-down.

     Note: Depending on the current item state, not all items may be displayed. Items in the Obsolete state only display the latest revision.

     **Revision Settings**

     + **latest** - The current BOM. There may be items in any state in the BOM.
     + **Prior Revisions** - Past released BOMs.
   * **View By Date** Select a Date from the Date-Picker drop-down. You can select a date all the way back to the item's creation date.

     Note: Changes to the Date-Picker do not affect the displayed BOM if the *latest* is selected.
   * **View by Row Type** - Select whether you want to view BOM rows that are turned on, off, or both from the Row Type drop-down.

   Note: You cannot edit information for previous revisions.

   Items in the Obsolete state display the previous revisions and the latest.
4. Select a method for displaying the BOM from the Structure list:

   * Multi-Level - a hierarchical list
   * First Level - the top level items
   * Parts Only - items for parts only
5. Right-click on an item to take additional actions:

   * **Turn row on** - Turns the item on for the BOM.
   * **Turn row off** - Turns the item off for the BOM.
   * **Add Row** - Adds a new item row to the BOM. Select whether you want to add an existing item or a new item to the BOM. See [Add Row to BOM](GUID-92EE6E10-3429-4472-837C-1FD01E18D18B.htm) for more information.
   * **Remove Row** - Removes an item from the BOM, including any item links or children items. Removing a row for an assembly in the BOM removes the assembly row and all corresponding child rows. See [Remove Row from BOM](GUID-7346FE1A-69C9-460B-896C-C79DAE341DA9.htm) for more information.
   * **Assign To** - Assign the item to a file.
   * **Turn Branch On** - Turns on the item and all children items for the BOM.
   * **BOM Report** - Create a BOM report based on the row level view structure used in the BOM tab.
   * **Open** - Opens the item record for viewing.
   * **Update** - Gets the latest version of the associated file(s) and updates the BOM to reflect any changes. For example, if a component has been added, the BOM is automatically updated to show the new component item.
   * **Change Number** - Opens the Change Item Number dialog so you can edit the item number.
   * **Change State** - Select a new lifecycle state for the item.
   * **Go to** - Go to the change order associated with the item, go to the folder where the associated file is located in Vault, or go directly to the item in Vault.
   * **Create Shortcut** - Add the item to the My Shortcuts pane.
   * **Expand All** - Expands all levels of the item hierarchy.
   * **Collapse All** - Collapses all levels of the item hierarchy.
   * **Details** - Access and configure item security.

   Note: Turn row on, Turn row off, Add row, Remove row, Assign to, and Turn Branch On commands are only available when the item record is in edit mode.

## View Where an Item Is Used

In the Item Master, select an item.

1. Select the Where Used tab in the Preview Pane.

   The parent items in the item master that reference the selected item are listed, as well as the number of parents related to the item.
2. Select one of these values from the View by Revision drop-down menu to further refine your results:

   Note: The revision drop down will display the following revisions. Depending on the current item state, not all items may be displayed:

   * The current (latest) item in any state.
3. Right-click on an item to take additional actions:

   * **Open** - Opens the item record for editing.
   * **Update** - Gets the latest version of the associated file(s) and updates the BOM to reflect any changes. For example, if a component has been added, the BOM is automatically updated to show the new component item.
   * **Change Number** - Opens the Change Item Number dialog so you can edit the item number.
   * **Change State** - Select a new lifecycle state for the item.
   * **Change Revision** - Select a new revision value for the item.
   * **Add to Change Order** - Add the item to a new or existing change order.
   * **Attachments** - View attached files or attach/detach files.
   * **Go to** - Go to the change order associated with the item, go to the folder where the item is located in Vault, or go directly to the item in Vault.
   * **Create Shortcut** - Add the item to the My Shortcuts pane.
   * **Delete** - Permanently deletes the selected item and all of its revisions from the vault.

## View the Change Orders Applied to an Item

1. In the Item Master, select an item.
2. Select the Change Order tab in the Preview Pane.

   The change orders applied to the current item are listed. The change order summary for the item includes the ECO number, the current state of the change order, the title of the change order, and the due date for the change order.
3. Right-click on a change order and select Go To Change Order to go directly to the change order in the vault.
4. Right-click on a change order and select View to open the change order.

## View the Files Attached to an Item

1. In the Item Master, select an item.
2. Select the View tab in the Preview Pane.
3. From the Show list, select which file types to display:

   * **All** - all attached files are listed
   * **Drawings** - Autodesk Inventor .idw and .dwg files are listed
   * **Documents** - only Microsoft Word files are listed
   * **CAD Files** - only files from CAD applications are listed
   * **Other-**all other file types.
4. From the Attached Files list, select a file to view.

   * If the selected file is a .dwf file or is a file with a .dwf attachment, the .dwf is displayed inside the View tab using Autodesk DWF Viewer. Click View in Window to view the file in a separate window.
   * If the selected file does not have an associated .dwf file, the view is empty. Click Open with Viewer to view the file in an external application.
5. When viewing a .dwf file, use the Autodesk DWF Viewer controls to zoom, pan, and print the .dwf image.

### Create an Item

# Create an Item

Create non-model file-based items using the New Item command.

Creating new items allows you to track items that are not modeled yet but that are required to fully describe the finished product. Items may be purchased parts, consumables (e.g., grease or fluids), documentation, or packaging. You can enter item attributes and attach files managed by the vault to the new item. Items can be added to the BOM of another item using the BOM editing functionality.

User-defined items can be designated as one of the following:

* **Assembly:** the item represents a group of designs. For example, to create a group of parts, such as a repair kit that is shipped with a product.
* **Document:** the item represents information that needs to be tracked, such as a design specification or set of instructions.
* **Electrical:** item represents a component of an AutoCAD Electrical project.
* **Electrical Project:** item represents an AutoCAD Electrical project.
* **General:** an item type that does not meet another classification.
* **Part:** item represents a part without an associated CAD file. Select when creating non-modeled parts.
* **Process:** item represents a process, such as heat treatment where an attached file has the specification.
* **Product:** item represents an entire product.
* **Purchased:** item represents a part to be purchased

Note: Custom item categories that are created using the Item Categories dialog are also available in the list.

An item number based on the default item number format is generated. The item number can be edited after the item has been created in the item master.

## Create a New Item

1. Select the Item Master view.
2. Click New on the tool bar.

   If the administrator has granted you permission to assign item categories, select a category and click OK to continue to the new item record.

   The default item category is Document. To change the item category, click the drop-down arrow and select a new category.
3. In the Item Title text box, enter an item title.
4. In the Item Description text box, enter a brief description of the item.
5. From the Units drop-down list, select the default units for the item.
6. To attach files in the vault to the item, select the Actions menu > Attachments. The files attached to the item are displayed in the Associated Files list. Click attach and browse to the file that you want to associate with the item.

   Item properties and BOM data is extracted from the file and the item record is updated with the new data.

   If Assign Items to Children is turned on, items are automatically created for children files.

   Note: No items are created for file components. These components are added to the BOM as excluded and unassigned rows.
7. To link a file to the item, perform one of the following actions:

   * Right-click in the Associated Files box and select Add Link. Browse to the files that you want to link to the item and click Open.
   * Drag-and-drop files into the Associated Files field.
   * Copy a file from the vault and paste it into the Associated Files field.

   The first file added in the Associated Files field will be the primary link to the item. Additional files are secondary links. If multiple files are added at the same time, a random file is selected as a primary link. If a primary link already exists, all additional files become secondary links.

   Note: **AutoCAD Mechanical Users** – If the AutoCAD Mechanical file has no top-level assembly or has more than one component, the file is attached to the item instead of linked to the item. If the file has a top-level assembly, the assembly becomes the primary link to the item. If the file has no assembly but has only one component, the component becomes the primary link.
8. Right-click in the Properties list and elect Modify Attached Properties to attach properties to the new item.

   Note: If you recently saved the item record, you must click Edit to continue making modifications to the record.
9. Click Save to save your changes.

   If desired, proceed to the other item record tabs to add comments, turn on items in the bill of materials, or add the item to a change order.
10. When finished, click Save and Close.
11. If you want to keep the record open but want to be able to edit other items, click Exit Edit Mode.

**Parent page:** [Items](GUID-F3E9FC7B-277F-4961-8E70-5ADA7BD189C6.htm)


### Edit an Item

# Edit an Item

You can change item attributes.

**Rules for editing an item**

* The item must be in the Work in Progress state.
* No other user can be editing the item.
* Only one item at a time can be edited.
* If the item is on a change order, the change administrator must have enabled Allow Edits. In this circumstance, the lifecycle state of the item cannot be edited.
* Only an Item Editor Level 1, Item Editor Level 2, or an Administrator can edit an item.

**Edit opens an item record so you can:**

* Modify the title and description fields.
* Add, remove, and modify user-defined properties.
* Attach and modify attachments.

  Note: Links to the design representation files (.pdf, .dxf, .step) are automatically removed when their source files are removed from the item. During the next Assign/Update Item operation, any remaining design representation files in Vault will be automatically re-associated with the item.
* Turn on and Turn off BOM rows.

## Edit an Item

Note: An item cannot be opened for editing if it is being edited by another user. You must have Item Editor Level 2 permissions to edit an item.

1. Right-click an item in the item master and select Open.

   The Item Record dialog displays all attributes and properties of the selected item.

   Note: A file and its dependents must be checked into the vault to edit the corresponding items.
2. Click Edit on the Item Record toolbar.
3. The following item attributes can be edited within the Item Record dialog:

   * Item Title text
   * Item Description text
   * Item Category

     Click the drop-down arrow, and select a new category from the list.
   * File attachments

     Select Actions > Attachments to attach a file to the item or remove current attachments.
   * Item properties.

     Right-click in the Properties list and then select Modify Attached Properties. In the Modify Attached Properties dialog, specify which properties to add or remove. The property values can be edited if the item is not associated with a file.
   * BOM details

     Click the BOM tab to make changes to the BOM.
4. Click Save to save your changes.

   If you wish to cancel your changes without closing the item, select File > Exit Edit Mode.

**Parent page:** [Items](GUID-F3E9FC7B-277F-4961-8E70-5ADA7BD189C6.htm)

The new item is automatically added to the Item Master and opened in read-only mode.

### Attach Properties to an Item

# Attach Properties to an Item

Attach properties to new or existing items.

1. Perform one of the following tasks:

   * **To attach a property to an existing item** - Right-click the item in the Item Master and select Open.

     In the Item Record, click Edit on the tool bar.
   * **To attach a property to a new item** - Select the Item Master view and click New on the toolbar.
2. Select the General tab.
3. In the Properties section, right-click and select Modify Attached Properties.
4. The Modify Attached Properties dialog box displays the list of properties that can either be attached to the item or removed from the item. Properties attached to the item are indicated with a check mark. Administrators can create new user-defined properties that can be attached to the item.

### Edit Properties on an Item

# Edit Properties on an Item

Item properties can be edited without opening the item in an edit window. Additionally, properties can be edited on multiple items with one command.

1. Select the item or items that need a property edit.
2. Open the Edit Properties dialog using any of the following 3 methods:

   * Edit > Edit Properties
   * Ctrl + E
   * Select the Edit Properties button from the properties grid.

   The Property Edit dialog opens.
3. To add any items that were left out of the selection, click Add and search for the items to be added. If there are items listed that do not need to have properties edited, select the item row and click Remove.
4. With the items listed in the dialog, click Select Properties to add or remove properties from the dialog grid.
5. Edit the properties of the items and select OK.
6. View the results of the item property edit.
7. Click OK to apply the changes.

All successful changes are displayed with a check mark in the Success column.

For more on property editing, see [Understanding Properties](GUID-5F0C9F22-0288-471E-8D64-D5F57FBE300A.htm).

### Write Back Item Properties to a File

# Write Back Item Properties to a File

You can manually synchronize properties on files associated with items.

By default, item properties are written back to the associated file from Vault add-ins, Vault Explorer, and the Job Processor.

Item properties take precedence over file properties and file mappings. If the file's properties are edited and properties are synchronized, the item properties will overwrite the file properties.

Note: Editing and saving a property may also result in an item property being written back to a File.

Important: The **Write Item properties back to the file** check box on the [Items tab](https://beehive.autodesk.com/community/service/rest/cloudhelp/resource/cloudhelpchannel/guidcrossbook/?p=VAULT&l=ENU&accessmode=live&v=2026&guid=GUID-A88D9FBD-AF27-481A-AFEC-E5EACD6BB04E) must be selected for item properties to be written back to a file.

## Synchronize Associated File Properties

1. In the Item Master, select the item for which you want to synchronize file properties.
2. Select the General tab in the preview if it is not already selected.
3. Right-click on the Associated Files section and select Synchronize Properties.

Item properties are written back to the associated file.

**Parent page:** [Items](GUID-F3E9FC7B-277F-4961-8E70-5ADA7BD189C6.htm)


### Assign Item Numbers

# Assign Item Numbers

When an item is created, an item number is automatically applied based on the [default numbering scheme](https://beehive.autodesk.com/community/service/rest/cloudhelp/resource/cloudhelpchannel/guidcrossbook/?p=VAULT&l=ENU&accessmode=live&v=2026&guid=GUID-F5356B61-194B-45BF-8B92-31C299A37206). However, if the numbering scheme requires user input, the Item Number dialog opens so you can enter the required values.

1. If you do not want to use the default numbering scheme, select a new numbering scheme from the scheme drop-down list. Otherwise, continue onto the next step.
2. If user input is required for the item numbering assignment, select a field and enter the required value.

   You can also click Replace to search for the property that you want to use in the field.
3. Click PreCheck to verify that all values are accepted. Make any changes, if necessary.
4. If you want to remove an item from the list, select the item and click Remove.
5. When all values are added and the Precheck succeeds, click OK to assign the new item numbers.

### Change Item Numbers

# Change Item Numbers

Learn about changing item numbers.

The term item refers to what a company manages, assembles, sells and manufactures. An item is identified by its item number and is often referred to as the part number.

The following commands generate an item number:

* New Item
* Assign Item

The Assign Item and New Item commands create item numbers based on the default scheme specified in the Administrator dialog box.

Note: Default numbering schemes that require user input are not applied automatically. Instead an auto-generated number is assigned. You must edit an item number requiring user input and select the default item numbering scheme. All fields must be filled in.

Fields that require user input display a question mark (?) in the Edit Item Number dialog box.

An item number cannot be opened for editing if the item is being edited by another user. You must have administrator rights to edit an item number.

## Change Item Numbers

Note: New item numbering schemes can be defined in the Administration dialog box. Available schemes are listed in the Change Item Number dialog box.

1. Right-click on one or more items in the Item Master or BOM view and select Change Item Number.
2. Select a numbering scheme from the drop-down list.

   * **Use Property Mapping** - Uses mapped properties to generate the item number. By default, property mapping is always chosen first. Even if a different scheme is set as default, property mappings take priority over other schemes.
   * **Sequential** - Numbers are generated sequentially. This scheme is used if no property mappings are available.
   * **Mapped** - Numbers are generated based on user input.

   Fields that require user input display the default values. Auto-generated fields are represented as a pound sign (#).
3. Enter text as needed in the event a field requires user input.
4. Click Precheck to verify the new item number. Make any changes if necessary.
5. If more than one item is in the list and you want to remove one, select the item and click Remove.
6. Click OK to accept the new item number.

### Assign Items

# Assign Items

CAD data becomes available to the non-CAD user by assigning an item to a file. Assigning an item requires Item Create permission.

Assigning an item to a file within a vault creates an item record in the Item Master and allows the CAD data to be tracked throughout its lifecycle.

## Files that can be assigned items

* Autodesk Inventor IPT, IAM, IPN, DWG, and IDW files that have been checked into the vault using the Inventor add-in

  **Note:** You cannot assign an item to an iAssembly or iPart factory.
* AutoCAD and AutoCAD Mechanical DWG files
* AutoCAD Electrical projects
* Non-CAD files such as Microsoft Office documents

When an item is assigned to an Autodesk Inventor .ipt or .iam file, the related 2D .idw files are automatically associated to the item.

Note: Only design representation files (.pdf, .dxf, .step) created through standard Vault workflows such as Job Processor tasks or the Vault Client '[Create File from CAD Files](https://beehive.autodesk.com/community/service/rest/cloudhelp/resource/cloudhelpchannel/guidcrossbook/?p=VAULT&l=ENU&accessmode=live&v=2026&guid=GUID-EE6877E0-BBEB-4FB2-8B08-F9052F6FCB32)' operation are automatically associated with items. Files that are manually attached, even if recategorized as Design Representation, are not automatically associated during Assign/Update Item operations.

The associated .idw files are listed in the item's Associated Files list and are available for mark up within the item. When an .iam file is assigned an item, the presentation file, .ipn, is also associated with the item and displayed in the Associated Files list.

When you assign an item to a file, an item number is automatically generated based on property mapping. You can apply a different item numbering scheme other than the default item number by editing the item record.

## Assign an Item

1. Right-click one or more files in the main view and select Assign/Update Item.

   A new item is created for each of the files selected and for the related files.
2. If you assign an item to a single file, the item record automatically opens for editing. Begin making changes, if needed.
3. If you select multiple files and assign an item, an item icon displays in the Item Column. However, you must right-click on a file and select Open Item to view the item record. Select Edit on the item record toolbar to begin editing.

   Note: Item Numbering is automatically applied based on the [default numbering scheme](https://beehive.autodesk.com/community/service/rest/cloudhelp/resource/cloudhelpchannel/guidcrossbook/?p=VAULT&l=ENU&accessmode=live&v=2026&guid=GUID-F5356B61-194B-45BF-8B92-31C299A37206). However, if the numbering scheme requires user input, the Item Number dialog opens. Enter the required values and click OK to continue.

   See [Edit an Item](GUID-CB764599-B7C9-4DE2-A445-A7B02CE8EB57.htm) for information on modifying an item record, including changing the item number, adding and removing rows to the BOM, adding items to a change order, and attaching files.
4. Click Save and Close when you are finished.

   The item master is updated with the new items. If items were assigned to Autodesk Inventor assembly files, any associated drawing (.idw) and presentation (.ipn) files are linked to the items. If items were assigned to Inventor part files, the associated drawing (.idw) files are linked to the items.

Note: Links to design representation files (.pdf, .dxf, .step) are automatically removed when their source files are removed from the item. During the next Assign/Update Item operation, any remaining design representation files in Vault will be automatically re-associated with the item.

**Parent page:** [Items](GUID-F3E9FC7B-277F-4961-8E70-5ADA7BD189C6.htm)


### Update an Item

# Update an Item

Update synchronizes items with the properties of the associated file versions in the vault. An item can be updated even if the associated file has not been changed so as to update any properties that have been globally added since the last update.

Updating an item linked to an assembly file creates a new item for each new file associated with it. If any drawing files that were originally associated with the CAD files are removed, their association with the item is also removed when the item is updated.

**Rules for Updating an Item**

* If the item has child items (for example, an Autodesk Inventor assembly), the child items are also updated to reflect the most recent versions of the child files.
* Attached files that are pinned are not updated.
* Before updating items, make sure drawings are up to date with the model so that they are linked to the item.

## Update an Item

* Right-click on an item in the item master and select Update.

  The Update Item dialog displays progress for the update process.

  If the item is up to date, a message displays showing that no changes were made.

  If the item was updated with new information from associated files, then the item record opens with the updated data.

Note: The following icons indicate the state of a primary or secondary item:

* ![](../images/icon-item-file-link.png) - item is up to date
* ![](../images/icon-file-item-link-outofsate.png) - item needs to be updated

**Parent page:** [Items](GUID-F3E9FC7B-277F-4961-8E70-5ADA7BD189C6.htm)

# Assign a File to an Item

By assigning a file to an item, the item can represent the file in a BOM. You can assign files to new or existing items.

1. Right-click on the file that you want to assign to an item and select Assign To.

   Tip: You can also drag and drop a file onto an existing item in the Item Master or onto the Item node to create a new item for it.

   The Item dialog opens in edit mode. If the item was created for the file, the file becomes the primary associated file.

1. Right-click on an item or items in the Item Master that are not already assigned to a change order and select Add to Change Order.

   Note: You can also select Actions > Add to Change Order in the item record.

View files attached to an item.

### Attach a File to an Item

# Attach a File to an Item

Use Attachments to attach any file type from the vault to an item. For example, you can attach assembly instructions to an assembly or a drawing to a purchased part.

Note: Auxiliary files attached to a primary file in the vault do not get automatically attached to the item .

Pinning an attached file prevents the file from being updated. An attached file that is not pinned updates to the most recent version each time the item is updated.

When the Number of Attachments column is displayed in the Item Master the paper clip icon displays for every item with one or more attachment. Control-click the paper clip to view attached files.

## Manage File Attachments

1. Right-click on an item and select Attachments.

   The current Attachments for the item are displayed.
2. To attach files, click Attach and browse to the location of the file or click Search to find files in the vault. See [Select File from Vault](https://beehive.autodesk.com/community/service/rest/cloudhelp/resource/cloudhelpchannel/guidcrossbook/?p=VAULT&l=ENU&accessmode=live&v=2026&guid=GUID-A55AD9BD-1801-4BD8-8A36-C096F85018C4) for more information.

   Select one or more files and click Open.

   The most recent version of the attached file is displayed in the Attachments dialog box.
3. Modify the way an Item Update operates on the attached files.

   By default, attached files update to the most recent version each time the item is updated. You can pin a particular version of the file to the item so that it references that version instead of the newest version during item updates.

   1. Select the Version Number field and select the version of the file you want to pin from the drop-down list.
   2. Select the Pin check box to pin the file to the specified version.

   During an update, the file version specified at the time of attachment remains attached to the item and the item is updated with the most current information from that file version.
4. To detach a file, select the file, and click Detach.
5. Click OK to save your changes and close the dialog.

### Item File Links

# Item File Links

When files are assigned to Items, they are given specific Item File Link types. The Item File Link type defines how the Item relates to the linked file.

Note: Item File Links are not the same as attaching a file to an item. For more information regarding attaching files to items please see [Attach a File to an Item](GUID-869F7592-D61A-41FF-B2B1-D377FFAF61AE.htm).

After a link has been created you can modify the link type or remove the link. Removing the link will disassociate the file from the Item.

## Component and Subcomponent Links

For linking purposes, parts are considered a component or subcomponent, depending on how they are defined.

* Components are parts that are defined by a unique file.
* Subcomponents are parts which are defined internally as part of a file. For example, subcomponents can be virtual components in Inventor, or part references and structured components in AutoCAD Mechanical. Subcomponents are often defined multiple times in many different files and assemblies.

  A subcomponent link is established when a part (component) is defined within a file, but it is not the component defined by the file.

  Note: Administrators can configure Vault to create standard component links instead of primary and secondary subcomponent links during an Item Assign or Item Update event. See [Configure Item Assignment](https://beehive.autodesk.com/community/service/rest/cloudhelp/resource/cloudhelpchannel/guidcrossbook/?p=VAULT&l=ENU&accessmode=live&v=2026&guid=GUID-FF26CEE9-A2B7-47BB-9FFF-1655D0A5C91B) for more information.

### Primary and Secondary Subcomponent Link Rules

Primary and secondary subcomponent links adhere to these rules when set as [the preferred link types](https://beehive.autodesk.com/community/service/rest/cloudhelp/resource/cloudhelpchannel/guidcrossbook/?p=VAULT&l=ENU&accessmode=live&v=2026&guid=GUID-FF26CEE9-A2B7-47BB-9FFF-1655D0A5C91B#GUID-FF26CEE9-A2B7-47BB-9FFF-1655D0A5C91B__LI_00EFC620783344E09414BE824C8540B9) for an Item Assign or Item Update event.

* If a file is assigned to an item, and a subcomponent is found for which there is no existing Item, then a Primary Subcomponent link is assigned to the file. If a pre-existing item is found, then a Secondary Subcomponent link is assigned.
* If a Primary Subcomponent is later defined in its own file, then a Primary link is assigned to the new file and the Primary Subcomponent link automatically changes to a Secondary Subcomponent link.

### Subcomponent Link Examples

* **AutoCAD Mechanical** - If a whole assembly is drawn and defined in one file, the assembly receives a primary link to an item because the file is the definition of the assembly. All subassemblies and parts in the assembly receive subcomponent links from the assembly file to items.
* **Inventor** - Use subcomponents as virtual parts. For example, a user may add a virtual part for grease to their assembly. There is no physical part file modeled for grease, so it is solely defined within the assembly. That virtual grease component receives a subcomponent from the assembly file to an item.

## Item File Link Types

|  |  |  |
| --- | --- | --- |
| *Primary* |  | A component with a primary link is the primary definition for the Item. Properties are read from this component on Item assign and update. Properties can be written back to the component as well. When the Item is released the primary link file will be locked.  By default, a state change cannot be executed if the link needs updating. This setting can be configured in the state transition. |
| *Secondary* |  | A component with a secondary link is a secondary or duplicate definition for the Item. Properties are not read from this component on Item updates, though properties can be written back to the component. When the Item is released the secondary link component is locked.  By default, a state change cannot be executed if the link needs updating. This setting can be configured in the state transition. |
| *Primary Subcomponent* |  | A component containing the primary definition for a subcomponent. Properties are read from and can be written back this component. When the Item is released, the component is locked.  By default, a state change cannot be executed if the link needs updating. This setting can be configured in the state transition. |
| *Secondary Subcomponent* |  | A component containing a secondary or duplicate definition for a subcomponent. Properties are not read from this component, though properties can be written back to the component. When the Item is released, the component is locked.  By default, a state change cannot be executed if the link needs updating. This setting can be configured in the state transition. |
| *Standard Component* |  | A component with a Standard Component link contains standard content. Properties are read for the Standard Component only at Item assign, and properties are written back to the file. When the Item is released, the file is locked.  Subcomponents also receive Standard Component links. |
| *Tertiary* |  | A file with a tertiary link is a design document file such as an .idw, .ipn, or .dwg file. These links are automatically assigned when the corresponding model file is assigned to Item. Files with Tertiary links are locked when the Item is released. |

Note: This command releases locks for items and change orders that are reserved to the user performing the command. Changes to the items or change orders are not saved.

2. Verify that you want to clear the locks.

### Roll Back the Lifecycle State of an Item

# Roll Back the Lifecycle State of an Item

Return an item to a previous lifecycle state with the Roll Back Lifecycle State Change command.

Note: This feature is available in Vault Professional.

When an item is rolled back, it:

* returns to the item version associated with the rolled-back state.
* returns to the security, lifecycle definition, and revisions scheme associated with the rolled-back state.
* retains any property definitions associated with the current version being rolled back.

The current version of the item is deleted when the item is rolled back to a previous state.

## Rules for Rolling Back an Item Lifecycle State

You can roll back an item from any state to another state as long as:

* The rolled back state has not been deleted.
* The current lifecycle state is not  and the rolled back state is not .
* The rolled back state is not controlled by [purge](GUID-986334F8-B790-4BA2-A445-E4AE3D02B17C.htm) settings.
* There are no ECO restrictions on state change.
* The rolled back state did not exist before the ECO was created.
* The ECO is not closed.

  Note: If the ECO was canceled, you can still roll back to the last state in the ECO.
* There are no component link restrictions.

  For example, if rolling back to the previous state would link the item to a component that is only allowed one link and the component is already linked to another item, then the roll back is not permitted.

Only users with Item Editor Level 2, ERP Manager, or Administrator roles can change the state on an item.

## Roll Back the Lifecycle State of an Item

1. Select an item in the Item Master, and then select Actions > Roll Back Lifecycle State Change.
2. Click Continue to complete the lifecycle state rollback.

**Parent page:** [Items](GUID-F3E9FC7B-277F-4961-8E70-5ADA7BD189C6.htm)


### Purge Items from the Vault Client

# Purge Items from the Vault Client

Purge item versions in a vault based on the item's lifecycle state control settings.

Note: Items are available in Vault Professional.

When a lifecycle state is created, the administrator must identify which item and file versions in that state are retained during a purge.

For example, a lifecycle state can be defined so that all items in the Review State are purged except for the latest version when the Purge command is invoked.

Note: Item versions are purged based on their [lifecycle control settings](https://beehive.autodesk.com/community/service/rest/cloudhelp/resource/cloudhelpchannel/guidcrossbook/?p=VAULT&l=ENU&accessmode=live&v=2026&guid=GUID-02294D64-9ACA-4546-956E-095D9D7814B1). You can purge items from the ADMS Console or the Autodesk Vault Client.

## Purge Items from the Autodesk Vault Client

2. Select Actions > Purge Items.
3. Click OK to confirm the purge.

Item versions are purged based on their lifecycle control settings.

The Purge Item Result dialog displays to show details of the purge. Click Close when finished reviewing the purge results.

### Sync Items to Fusion Manage

# Sync Items to Fusion Manage

The Vault Connector allows users to synchronize Vault Items and their associated data directly to a Fusion Manage workspace. This can be done on-demand from the Vault client or automatically as part of a lifecycle state change.

## Prerequisites for Syncing

Before you can use the `Sync to Fusion Manage` or `Open in Fusion Manage` commands, the following conditions must be met:

* The Vault Connector must be enabled in the ADMS Console.
* Property mappings must be configured between Vault and the target Fusion Manage workspace.

## The Synchronization Process

When an Item is synced from Vault to Fusion Manage, the connector performs the following actions in sequence:

1. Creates a corresponding item in the target Fusion Manage workspace.
2. Populates the item's Bill of Materials (BOM) based on the Vault Item's BOM.
3. Uploads and attaches relevant files to the Fusion Manage item.

## Synced Attachments

The synchronization process includes the following types of attachments from the Vault Item:

* Direct attachments (excluding design files).
* DWF attachments from primary and tertiary linked files.
* Design representation attachments (such as PDF or STEP files) from primary and tertiary linked files.

## Important Considerations

* **Item Revisions:** The Vault Connector synchronizes Item data but does not sync the Item's revision history. Each sync updates the existing record in Fusion Manage to match the current version in Vault.
* **Open in Fusion Manage:** The `Open in Fusion Manage` command is only available for Items that have been successfully synchronized at least once.

**Parent page:** [Items](GUID-F3E9FC7B-277F-4961-8E70-5ADA7BD189C6.htm)


## Bills of Materials (BOMs)

# Bills of Materials (BOMs)

A Bill of Materials (BOM) is a summary of items needed to manufacture a part or product.

Note: The BOM feature is available only in Vault Professional.

A BOM includes item numbers, quantities, part descriptions, lifecycle state, and other properties.

Every time a file with a BOM is assigned an item, a BOM is generated in Vault for that item. BOM details differ depending on what the item represents.

* An item representing a single part typically contains BOM information related only to that part.
* An item representing an assembly typically contains BOM information for all parts in the assembly.
* An item representing an assembly comprised of subassemblies and parts typically contains BOM information for all of the subassemblies.

## What Can I Do with BOMs?

BOMs are a powerful tool for tracking a product because you can:

* Update them when items are added and removed from the design.
* Add custom items that are outside the design process, such as grease or adhesives.
* Compare one BOM revision with another to see what has changed between revisions. For example, you can pinpoint exactly which parts changed between revisions of an assembly.
* Manually create a BOM by creating an item from scratch, and then adding items to the new item's BOM.
* Save BOM View as a Microsoft Excel spreadsheet or a comma-separated values file (.csv) so it can be analyzed or formatted in other applications for custom reports and printouts.

### BOM Rules

* Items that have never been released are displayed in their current state.
* If an item has been released, then the released revision is listed, even if it has been changed back to work-in-progress (WIP).
* When a part that is used in multiple assemblies is released, the new released revision of the part immediately appears in the BOM of every assembly in which it is used.

## Important BOM Terminology

Knowing these terms and phrases will make understanding the help and BOM workflows easier.

| Terms | Definitions |
| --- | --- |
| BOM row is turned off | Row is excluded from the BOM and BOM processes, such as lifecycle state change restrictions.  Note: A row that is turned off may or may not have an item. When a row that doesn't have an item is turned on, an item is automatically created. |
| BOM row is on | Row is included in the BOM and BOM processes, such as lifecycle state change restrictions. |
| BOM Components | Rows that do not have an item assigned and that are turned off. |

### Bill of Materials (BOM) Status Icons

# Bill of Materials (BOM) Status Icons

It's important to understand the icons and status settings for the Bill of Materials tab to best manage your BOMs.

Note: The Bill of Materials (BOM) feature is available only in Vault Professional.

**BOM View of an Item**

![](../images/dialog-itemrecordbomview-updated.png)

## Status Icons and Details

| Icon | Details |
| --- | --- |
|  | Item exists in the vault. |
|  | Item exists but the row is turned off in the BOM. |
|  | No item is assigned. The file is the child of a parent with an assigned item, however no item has been assigned to the child file. |
|  | Item row consists of multiple rows that have been grouped together, shown in light theme. |
|  | Item row consists of multiple rows that have been grouped together, shown in dark theme. |
|  | Item row consists of multiple rows that have been grouped together, shown in classic theme. |
|  | Item row is turned on. The item is included in all BOM processes. |
|  | Item row is turned off. The item is listed for tracking purposes but is not included in BOM processes. |
|  | Item can be edited. |
|  | Item is locked and cannot be edited. |
|  | Item is created but has not been saved to vault yet. |
|  | The item is obsolete. However, a newer revision may exist. |
|  | The item is not available for editing because another user is currently editing the parent file. |

## Status Fonts and Details

| Font | Details |
| --- | --- |
| Blue, bold, italic font. | Property has been overridden by the user but is not saved to the vault yet. |

### Access the Bill of Materials (BOM) for an Item

# Access the Bill of Materials (BOM) for an Item

Manage your Bill of Materials (BOM) from the Bill of Materials tab on the item record.

Note: Items and BOMs are available only in Autodesk Vault Professional.

1. In the Item Master, double-click on an item to open the item record.
2. Select the Bill of Materials tab.

The Bill of Material for the selected item is listed.

Note: To edit a Bill of Materials, you must click Edit on the Item Record toolbar.

**Parent page:** [Bills of Materials (BOMs)](GUID-86373139-0500-4B28-A5C3-DE80A53D1AF6.htm)


### View BOM Details

# View BOM Details

Control how rows are displayed in the BOM view of an Item Record to better suit your work environment.

Note: The BOM can only be edited when it is in the multi-level view.

## View BOM Details

1. In the Item Master, double-click on an item to open the item record.
2. Select the Bill of Materials tab.

   The Bill of Material for the selected item is listed.

   Note: To edit a Bill of Materials, you must click Edit on the Item Record toolbar.
3. You can choose to view the BOM either by date or revision:

   * **View BOM by Revision** – Select a revision from the revision drop-down. The date the revision was last used prior to being superceded by a newer revision is displayed in the date drop-down.

     Note: Depending on the current item state, not all items may be displayed. Items in the Obsolete state only display the latest revision.

     **Revision Settings**

     + **Latest–** The current BOM. There may be items in any state in the BOM.
     + **Prior Revisions–** Past released BOMs.

       Note: Views of past released BOMs are read-only, even if the item record is in edit mode.
   * **View By Date**–Select a Date from the Date-Picker drop-down. You can select a date all the way back to the item's creation date.

     Note: Changes to the Date-Picker do not affect the displayed BOM if the *Latest* is selected.

   Note: You cannot edit information for previous revisions.

   Items in the Obsolete state display the previous revisions and the latest.
4. Select a method for displaying the BOM from the Structure drop-down list:

   * Multi-Level - a hierarchical list

     Note: BOM rows can only be modified when the BOM is in Multi-Level view.
   * First Level - the top level items
   * Parts Only - items for parts only
5. Filter whether all BOM rows are displayed, or only rows that are turned on or turned off using the BOM Rows drop-down list.

   * **All Rows–**All BOM rows are displayed regardless of whether they are turned on for the BOM.
   * **On Rows Only–**Only rows that have been turned on for the BOM are displayed.

     Note: When Parts Only view is selected, the row filter is automatically set to On Rows Only and cannot be changed.
   * **Off Rows Only–**Only rows that are turned off are displayed.
6. Configure how rows and row data are displayed.

   * **Sort by Column Value**–Click a column heading to sort rows by that value. For example, click the BOM Rows On/Off ![](../images/icon-rowturnedoff.png) icon to sort by whether a row is turned on or off.

     Tip: Right click on a column heading and select Sort Ascending or Sort Descending to immediately sort by that order.
   * **Align Column Data–**Right-click on a column heading and select Alignment from the context menu. Select whether you want column data displayed as left-aligned, centered, or right-aligned.
   * **Auto-size the Column Width–**Right-click on a column heading and select Best Fit to automatically resize the column to fit the data displayed.
   * **Remove Columns–**Right-click on a column heading and select Remove This Column to automatically remove that column from the display.
   * **Customize the View–**Right-click on a column heading and select Customize the View to open the Customize View dialog. Click Fields to control which columns and fields are displayed in the BOM view. Additionally, you can choose whether to show grid lines or include automatic column sizing by clicking the Other Settings button on the Customize View dialog. Click Reset to restore the BOM view to product default settings.
7. Right-click on a BOM row to take additional actions:

   * **Turn row on–**Turns the item on for the BOM.
   * **Turn row off–**Turns the item off for the BOM.
   * **Add Row–**Adds a new item row to the BOM. Select whether you want to add an existing item or a new item to the BOM. See [Add Row to BOM](GUID-92EE6E10-3429-4472-837C-1FD01E18D18B.htm) for more information.
   * **Remove Row–**Removes an item from the BOM, including any item links or children items. Removing a row for an assembly in the BOM removes the assembly row and all corresponding child rows. See [Remove Row from BOM](GUID-7346FE1A-69C9-460B-896C-C79DAE341DA9.htm) for more information.
   * **Assign To–**Assign the item to a file.
   * **Turn Branch On–**Turns on the item and all children items for the BOM.
   * **BOM Report–**Create a BOM report based on the row level view structure used in the BOM tab.
   * **Open–**Opens the item record for viewing.
   * **Update–**Gets the latest version of the associated file(s) and updates the BOM to reflect any changes. For example, if a component has been added, the BOM is automatically updated to show the new component item.
   * **Change Number–**Opens the Change Item Number dialog so you can edit the item number.
   * **Change State–**Select a new lifecycle state for the item.
   * **Go to–**Go to the change order associated with the item, go to the folder where the associated file is located in Vault, or go directly to the item in Vault.
   * **Create Shortcut–**Add the item to the My Shortcuts pane.
   * **Expand All–**Expands all levels of the item hierarchy.
   * **Collapse All–**Collapses all levels of the item hierarchy.
   * **Details–**Access and configure item security.

   Note: Turn row on, Turn row off, Add row, Remove row, Assign to, and Turn Branch On commands are only available when the item record is in edit mode.

**Parent page:** [Bills of Materials (BOMs)](GUID-86373139-0500-4B28-A5C3-DE80A53D1AF6.htm)


### Add a Row to a BOM

# Add a Row to a BOM

By adding rows to an existing BOM, you can add non-CAD items such as grease or adhesives. You can also account for items that are not part of the design but are required for manufacturing and shipment, such as packaging.

You can create a BOM from scratch by [creating a new item](GUID-925F1AFF-B211-435E-A9CB-4F2FD951C482.htm) and building its BOM row by row without ever creating a single CAD file.

Note: When manually adding items to a BOM, remember to enter a quantity for the new item since there may be no CAD data to determine the quantity automatically.

When you add a new row to a BOM, you can choose to link it to an existing item or a new item. New items are not assigned unless you manually assign them.

## Add a Row to a BOM

1. In the item master, double-click an item to open the item record.
2. Select the Bill of Materials tab.

   Note: Rows can only be added to the BOM when it is in multi-level view.
3. Click Edit on the item record toolbar to put the item record in edit mode.
4. Right-click a row in the BOM and select Add New Row from the context menu.
5. Choose whether you want to add an existing item or a new item.

   If you choose a new item, the item is added immediately to the BOM. Be sure to fill out the details when you're finished adding rows to the BOM. See [Create an Item](GUID-925F1AFF-B211-435E-A9CB-4F2FD951C482.htm) for more information.

   If you choose existing item, use the Find dialog to locate the item or items to add to the bill of materials. From the search results list, select the items to add and then click OK. The items are added to the BOM and automatically turned on.
6. Click Save on the item record to save your changes.

**Parent page:** [Bills of Materials (BOMs)](GUID-86373139-0500-4B28-A5C3-DE80A53D1AF6.htm)


### Remove a Row from a BOM

# Remove a Row from a BOM

Remove rows from the BOM that are no longer needed.

For example, you might need to remove individual parts because you track and buy the assembly as a single item.

Note: If you wish to track an item or virtual component but don't want it represented as part of the BOM, you can simply [turn the row off](GUID-7FEA3BEB-09DE-4225-9C59-798D4A7FD5C6.htm) instead of removing the row altogether. For example, an assembly might exist in the CAD file for reference only, but should not be represented as part of the BOM. In these instances you can keep the item listed but turn off the row.

Items listed in the BOM can be removed by deleting the rows containing the items. When a row is removed from the BOM, the link to the item and links to all children of the item are removed. Removing a row for an assembly in the BOM removes the assembly row and all corresponding child rows.

## Remove a Row from a BOM

1. In the item master, double-click an item.
2. In the item record, select the Bill of Materials tab.

   Note: The BOM can only be edited when it is in the multi-level view.
3. Click Edit on the toolbar to put the item record in edit mode.
4. Right-click on a row in the BOM and select Remove Row.

   The link to the item and links to all children of the item are removed.

**Parent page:** [Bills of Materials (BOMs)](GUID-86373139-0500-4B28-A5C3-DE80A53D1AF6.htm)


### Turn BOM Rows on and Off

# Turn BOM Rows on and Off

Turn off BOM rows that you do not want included in the BOM process but still want listed on the BOM.

By adding rows to an existing BOM, you can add non-CAD items such as grease or adhesives. You can also account for items that are not part of the design but are required for manufacturing and shipment, such as packaging.

In addition, you can also add virtual components now and not assign an item until the component is ready. This flexibility allows you to build the BOM piece by piece, even if parts of the design have not been created yet, making it easier to track the entire project before everything is ready. Virtual components that do not have an item assignment or items that you do not want included in the BOM can be turned off.

## Turn a BOM Row On

Turn on rows to include them in the BOM.

Note: If a row is turned off and does not have an item assigned to it, an item is automatically created when the row is turned on.

1. Double-click on an item in the Item Master to open the item record.
2. Select the Bill of Materials tab.
3. Click Edit on the item record toolbar to put the item record in edit mode.
4. Right-click on the row that you want to turn on and select Turn row on.

   Note: You can also click the On/Off ![](../images/icon-rowturnedoff.png) icon to turn a row on.

   The item is now included in the BOM.

## Turn a BOM Branch On

Turn on multiple rows in a branch at the same time with the Turn Branch On command.

1. Double-click on an item in the Item Master to open the item record.
2. Select the Bill of Materials tab.
3. Click Edit on the item record toolbar to put the item record in edit mode.
4. Right-click on the row for which you want to turn on as well as all of its children and select Turn Branch On.

The selected row and all of its children are included in the BOM.

## Turn a BOM Row Off

Turn rows off to exclude them from the BOM. These rows are also excluded from the Item Export process.

1. Double-click on an item in the Item Master to open the item record.
2. Select the Bill of Materials tab.
3. Click Edit on the item record toolbar to put the item record in edit mode.
4. Right-click on the row that you want to turn off and select Turn row off.

The item is now excluded from the BOM.

**Parent page:** [Bills of Materials (BOMs)](GUID-86373139-0500-4B28-A5C3-DE80A53D1AF6.htm)
