### Grouped BOM Rows

# Grouped BOM Rows

Learn about grouped BOM rows.

A grouped BOM row is a row that contains multiple occurrences of an item that share a single parent, but have one or more BOM row properties with different values. The different values for the BOM row properties can include, but are not limited to, Length, Quantity, and Description.

A grouped BOM row is indicated in the BOM by the Grouped ![](../images/icon-bom-merged.png) [icon](Bill-of-Materials-BOM-Status.htm).

![](../images/screenshot-ve-bom-groupedrows.jpg)

## Why Are Some BOM Rows Grouped?

Frequently, objects in a design come from the same stock pieces, but have different properties. For example, stock material that is cut to length or has different finishes.

These components will often have the same part number, with other properties indicating how the component differs from the original.

Because these components have the same part number, they are often combined in the CAD BOM. When that CAD BOM is imported into a vault, these grouped rows are kept in tact unless the administrator has elected not to [group BOM rows as per the design BOM](https://beehive.autodesk.com/community/service/rest/cloudhelp/resource/cloudhelpchannel/guidcrossbook/?p=VAULT&l=ENU&accessmode=live&v=2026&guid=GUID-FF26CEE9-A2B7-47BB-9FFF-1655D0A5C91B#GUID-FF26CEE9-A2B7-47BB-9FFF-1655D0A5C91B__LI_73F596D76A6E4A76A7BF667E1FE0B4C6).

Note: Group BOM rows as per the design BOM must be enabled on the [Configure Assign Item dialog](https://beehive.autodesk.com/community/service/rest/cloudhelp/resource/cloudhelpchannel/guidcrossbook/?p=VAULT&l=ENU&accessmode=live&v=2026&guid=GUID-FF26CEE9-A2B7-47BB-9FFF-1655D0A5C91B) for Vault retain grouped rows based on CAD BOM data. If this option is not enabled, the rows are displayed individually.

## Rules for Grouping BOM Rows

The following rules must be met for BOM rows to be grouped in Vault.

* Auto-select first duplicate must be enabled on the Configure Assign Item dialog to enable the Group BOM Rows feature.
* BOM rows must be imported from a the CAD BOM to be grouped. BOM rows created manually are not grouped automatically even though there may be items with the same number.
* The **Group BOM rows as per the design BOM** option on the Configure Assign Item dialog must be enabled if you want to retain CAD BOM groups after import.
* Item numbers must match.
* Item occurrences must share a single parent.
* Items in a grouped row must be of a unit of measure that's in the same family so they can be merged.

  For example, rows using both inches and millimeters as units of measure can be merged, but rows using mass and length cannot be merged.
* A group's on/off setting persists when the group is unmerged. For example, if a group BOM row is set to OFF and the group is unmerged so that all BOM rows are listed individually, all of the unmerged rows retain the OFF setting.

## How Does Vault Display Grouped BOM Row Values?

When BOM rows are grouped together, only one row is displayed in the BOM. Unless otherwise specified, the values that are displayed represent the primary BOM row's properties.

**Details**

* The Primary BOM row is the row with the Detail ID. If none of the rows in the group has a Detail ID, then another row is chosen as the primary row.
* **Position–**This is the position of the group itself. If the rows are ungrouped, this value applies to all of the rows.
* **Row Order–**This is the row order of the group itself. If the rows are ungrouped, this value applies to all of the rows.
* **Unit Qty–**If the items in a BOM row group all share the same Unit of Measure type but the actual units are different, the value of the primary row is displayed in the Unit QTY field.

  Note: The Units QTY field is not displayed by default. You can add it to your BOMs by [Customizing the BOM View](GUID-E926FCEE-9774-4329-BDCD-87BB537BFE17.htm).
* **Item QTY–**The Item QTY value is the number of items in the group.

  Note: The Item QTY field is not displayed by default. You can add it to your BOMs by [Customizing the BOM View](GUID-E926FCEE-9774-4329-BDCD-87BB537BFE17.htm).
* **Quantity–**The Quantity value is the sum of all quantities in the group.

**Parent page:** [Bills of Materials (BOMs)](GUID-86373139-0500-4B28-A5C3-DE80A53D1AF6.htm)


### Reordering Rows in a BOM

# Reordering Rows in a BOM

The order of items in the Bill of Materials is inherited from the CAD application that generated the BOM. This order can be modified.

When viewing the BOM in Vault Professional, the Row Order column indicates the order of the items. Each subassembly listed in the BOM displays its own numbering scheme, starting at 1. The parent rows increment by one and the children rows increment by tenths. For example, if a parent row is 4, then the first child starts with 4.1.

New items added to the BOM within Vault Professional are appended to the end of the order. New items added to the BOM from a CAD add-in are appended to the end of the order when an update is performed.

When an item is removed from the BOM, a gap occurs in the numbering sequence. To update the order, drag-and-drop rows to reset the numbers. Only the top-level children in an item's BOM can be renumbered.

Items listed in the BOM can be reordered by dragging and dropping items within the BOM. The items can be returned to the last saved order by clicking Restore to Saved Order ![](../images/icon-restoresavedorder.png) on the toolbar.

## Reorder a BOM

1. In the item master, double-click an item.
2. In the item record, click Edit and select the Bill of Materials tab.
3. Click on the Row Order column to sort by the current order.

   Note: The BOM must be sorted by the Row Order column to reorder rows.
4. Select a row and drag and drop it to the new location.

   Note: Rows can be dragged and dropped within the current parent. They cannot be dragged outside of the parent.
5. To revert back to the last saved order, click Restore Saved Order ![](../images/icon-restoresavedorder.png) on the toolbar.
6. To manually modify a row value, click within the Row Order cell and change the value.

   Note: When editing the row values, only the child's value is shown and not the parent's. So if you edit a child file that is 4.2 in the row order, only the 2 shows.
7. Click Save to save the changed order or click File > Exit to close the item record without saving the new BOM order.

**Parent page:** [Bills of Materials (BOMs)](GUID-86373139-0500-4B28-A5C3-DE80A53D1AF6.htm)


### Change the Position of an Item in a BOM

# Change the Position of an Item in a BOM

Each item has a position number in the Bill of Materials. This position number is a property that can be modified by the user.

## Rules for Position Numbers

* The BOM can only be edited when it is in multi-level view.
* Position numbers are alphanumeric.
* If the BOM row was manually or automatically created, the position can be manually modified.
* The position value is sticky for manually created rows.
* If the BOM row was imported from CAD, the position may be overwritten if the values change on the CAD side.

  Important: It is not transparent if the row was manually created or imported from CAD. Modify positions with caution.
* Duplicate position numbers are highlighted in yellow, similar to Inventor.

## Modify an item position number in a BOM

1. In the item master, double-click an item.
2. In the item record, click Edit and select the Bill of Materials tab.
3. Select a row in the BOM.
4. Click the position for the row.
5. Enter an alphanumeric string for the new position.
6. Press Enter.
7. Save the BOM to record your changes.

**Parent page:** [Bills of Materials (BOMs)](GUID-86373139-0500-4B28-A5C3-DE80A53D1AF6.htm)


### Change the Quantity of an Item in a BOM

# Change the Quantity of an Item in a BOM

The quantity of any item can be changed in the BOM.

For example, you can change the quantity of items that were added to the BOM from scratch or of parts that are modeled once but are reused throughout the design, such as bolts. When adding non-CAD items to a BOM, you must include a quantity because there is no CAD data to determine the quantity automatically. Item quantity can only be edited on the Bill of Materials tab in an item record.

The BOM can only be edited when it is in multi-level view. Quantities can only be edited for the direct children of the host item. To edit a quantity within a subassembly listed in the BOM, open the subassembly from the item master.

The item quantity can be either static or calculated. A calculated quantity is derived from the source CAD file and updates accordingly. A static quantity overrides the quantity specified in the linked CAD file and the original quantity contained in the CAD design is no longer reflected in the BOM.

A different font is used to identify whether a quantity is static or calculated.

| Type | Font |
| --- | --- |
| Static | *Italic* |
| Calculated | Standard |

## Change the Quantity of an Item

1. In the item master, double-click an item.
2. In the item record, click Edit and select the Bill of Materials tab.
3. Select a row in the BOM.
4. Click the quantity for the row.
5. Enter a number for the quantity.
6. Press Enter.

Note: When you change the quantity of an item, you override the quantity derived from the linked CAD file by default. The original quantity contained in the CAD design is no longer reflected in the BOM.

## Override the Current Quantity

* Right-click the quantity and then select Static Quantity.

The quantity no longer reflects the value in the linked CAD file and does not update when the quantity is changed in the source file.

## Revert the Quantity to the CAD Value

* Right-click the quantity and select Calculated Quantity.

The quantity will reflect the value in the linked CAD file after the item is updated.

**Parent page:** [Bills of Materials (BOMs)](GUID-86373139-0500-4B28-A5C3-DE80A53D1AF6.htm)


### Edit a BOM Property Value

# Edit a BOM Property Value

Some Item and BOM property values can be edited by clicking directly on the field in the BOM.

Note: If the selected field is mapped to a CAD property, the CAD property value will overwrite the new value the next time the item is updated.

1. In the item master, double-click an item.
2. In the item record, click Edit and select the Bill of Materials tab.

   Fields that can be edited are in white. Fields that cannot be edited are shaded.
3. Click in the item field that you want to edit and make your changes and press Enter.

   The new values are in bold blue until you click Save on the toolbar. This means that the changes are committed but have not been saved to the Vault yet.

   A pencil ![](../images/icon-itemiseditable.png) icon displays next to items that are impacted by the change, indicating that the item has been edited and is reserved until Save is clicked.

   Note: If an item or row is shown in the BOM more than once, the value automatically updates with the committed changes.
4. Click Save on the toolbar to save your changes to the vault.

   To cancel your changes, click the ESC key and click No when asked if you want to save your changes.

**Parent page:** [Bills of Materials (BOMs)](GUID-86373139-0500-4B28-A5C3-DE80A53D1AF6.htm)


### Assign to Item from the BOM View

# Assign to Item from the BOM View

Assign items and virtual components to other items from the [BOM view](GUID-F821AE1D-54F3-4CB6-8A29-5F4B89FC42AD.htm).

## Assign To Rules

These rules apply when assigning items in the BOM view.

* You can assign an item to the top BOM row item only if the top row is selected.
* You can select more than one BOM row item for assignment, provided that the selection meets this criteria:

  + Selection set is only components.
  + Selection set consists of uncommitted rows.

1. Assign to Item from BOM View
2. In the BOM view, select one or more items that are not already assigned, right-click, and select Assign To.

   The Find dialog opens.
3. Browse to or search for the item(s) to which you want to assign the selected item.
4. Select the item(s) and click OK.

The item in the BOM is now assigned to the specified item(s).

### Compare BOMs

# Compare BOMs

You can compare the BOM from one revision with the BOM of another revision to see what has changed between revisions. You can also compare the BOM of two different items as well as two different versions of the same item.

Note: This feature is available only in Vault Professional.

Only the properties displayed in the BOM are compared. The differences between the two BOMs are highlighted in the current BOM view.

Note: BOM components are not displayed in BOM compare.

|  |  |
| --- | --- |
| Blue | The row was added or turned on in the displayed BOM, but not in the comparison BOM.  Or  The row has an item now but was a BOM component in the comparison BOM. |
| Blue and bold | Values of individual properties are different. |
| Red strikethrough | The row does not exist or is turned off in the displayed BOM. |

## Compare the BOM of Two Different Items

1. In the item master, double-click an Item and select the Bill of Materials tab.
2. To compare the Bill of Materials of a different Item with the Item that is currently open, enter a different item number in the Compare field. Item numbers previously entered are available by selecting the drop-down arrow.

   If needed, click the Find button, to search for an Item.
3. Click the Compare drop-down arrow and select a Revision from the list.
4. Click Compare.
5. If you select an Item that is different than the open Item, the available revisions display in the revision drop-down on the toolbar. This includes the revisions for the latest revision and all revisions that have been previously been effective.

   The currently displayed BOM is compared against the Item and revision selected in the BOM toolbar. The differences are highlighted and color coded in the BOM grid. Hover over a row in the BOM to display a tooltip showing the differences found.

## Compare a Revision of a BOM with the Displayed Revision

1. In the item master, double-click an item.
2. In the item record, select the Bill of Materials tab.
3. Select a BOM revision from the Revision drop-down list. The corresponding revision of the BOM is displayed.
4. On the BOM Edit toolbar, select a revision of the BOM to compare against the displayed version.
5. Click Compare.

The currently displayed BOM is compared against the revision selected in the BOM toolbar. The differences are highlighted and color coded in the BOM grid. Hover over a row in the BOM to display a tooltip showing the differences found.

Use the navigation controls at the bottom of the BOM to step through the differences one at a time. A description of the current difference is displayed next to the controls.

|  |  |
| --- | --- |
|  | Go to the first difference. |
|  | Go to the previous difference. |
|  | Go to the next difference. |
|  | Go to the last difference. |

## Compare the BOM of Two Different Versions of the Same Item

Note: Show All Item Versions must be turned on to an item's version history.

1. In the item master, double-click an item.
2. In the item record, select the Bill of Materials tab.
3. Select a BOM version from the version drop-down list. The corresponding version of the BOM is displayed.
4. On the BOM Edit toolbar, select a version of the BOM to compare against the displayed version.
5. Click Compare.

The currently displayed BOM is compared against the version selected in the BOM toolbar. The differences are highlighted and color coded in the BOM grid. Hover over a row in the BOM to display a tooltip showing the differences found.

Use the navigation controls at the bottom of the BOM to step through the differences one at a time. A description of the current difference is displayed next to the controls.

|  |  |
| --- | --- |
|  | Go to the first difference. |
|  | Go to the previous difference. |
|  | Go to the next difference. |
|  | Go to the last difference. |

### Save BOM View

# Save BOM View

BOM data can be saved to a file to be analyzed or formatted in other applications. You can create specialized reports in Microsoft Excel or in other applications that read the comma-separated vales (.csv) file format for custom reports and printouts.

The BOM can be saved in either:

* The tree view layout with each instance of an item being a unique row.
* The flat layout with re-used items rolled up into a single instance with a total quantity.

The default file type is Excel (.xls).

## Save a BOM View

1. In the item master, double-click an item.
2. In the item record, select the Bill of Materials tab.
3. Select either the tree view layout or the flat view layout for the BOM list.
4. On the BOM File toolbar, click Save BOM View. The Save As dialog box is displayed.
5. Select the directory in which to save the file.
6. Select either the Microsoft Excel file format or comma-separated values (.csv).
7. Enter a name for the file.
8. Click Save.

Note: All rows in the tree view layout are saved, whether or not the rows are collapsed.

### Bill of Materials - Autodesk Inventor and Manufacturing

# Bill of Materials - Autodesk Inventor and Manufacturing

You can use Autodesk Inventor to manage the BOM in Vault Professional.

In an Autodesk Inventor assembly file, you can assign a BOM status for each component within the file. The status you assign determines whether the component displays in an Item in Vault Professional. In Autodesk Inventor, in the BOM dialog box, a component can be assigned one of the following:

* **Normal:** treats an item as component in the BOM and can be assigned quantities.
* **Phantom:** indicates the component is used to simplify the design process and only exists temporarily. They exist in the design, but are not distinct line items in a bill of materials. These do not appear in Vault Professional when an assembly is assigned an item.
* **Reference:** indicates the component is used as construction geometry or to add context to a design, such as a skeleton part or assembly for skeleton modeling. These do not appear in Vault Professional when an assembly is assigned an item.
* **Purchased:** indicates the component is not fabricated, such as Cylinders, pistons, or shock absorbers. Purchased components are considered a single BOM line item, regardless if it is a part or an assembly. For example, an assembly marked as purchased is listed as a part in parts-only parts list. If the purchased component is an assembly, its children are not generally included in the BOM. Children are also excluded from quantity calculations in the BOM. Normal child components of a purchased assembly are included in structured parts lists, and numbered, but are hidden in parts-only parts lists.
* **Inseparable:** indicates a fabricated assembly whose child components are maintained as a single item.

For detailed information on these different categories, see the Help in Autodesk Inventor.

**Parent page:** [Bills of Materials (BOMs)](GUID-86373139-0500-4B28-A5C3-DE80A53D1AF6.htm)


### Create BOM Report

# Create BOM Report

Create BOM reports that show Parts-level, First-level, and Multi-level views.

Note: Structure is not shown in BOM reports. For this reason, the BOM row order is significant for Multi-level BOM reports. The row order can be leveraged to show the level of the BOM.

Vault comes with three out-of-the-box BOM templates that can be used to create BOM Reports:

* BOM - First-Level.rdlc
* BOM - Multi-Level.rdlc
* BOM - Parts-Only.rdlc

Note: The BOM Report templates are located at C:\Program Files\Autodesk\Vault [*Edition*] [*year*]\Explorer\Report Templates. See [Create Report Templates](https://beehive.autodesk.com/community/service/rest/cloudhelp/resource/cloudhelpchannel/guidcrossbook/?p=VAULT&l=ENU&accessmode=live&v=2026&guid=GUID-6D1DF94C-7498-4836-9CA8-FFFB25C002EA) for more information about designing your own template.

## Create a BOM Report

1. Open the item for which you want to generate the BOM report and select the BOM tab.
2. Identify the structure that you want to show in the BOM report by selecting Multi-Level, First-Level, or Parts Only from the View drop-down.
3. If you are planning to create a multi-level BOM report, modify the row order of the BOM so that the row order can be leveraged to show the level of the BOM.
4. Right click on any item in the BOM grid and select BOM Report.
5. On the Select Report Template dialog, identify the path to the BOM report template that you want to use or click Browse Files to browse to that directory.

   Important: The BOM Report template must match the structure view you selected. For example, if you selected Parts Only, you must choose a template that supports the Parts Only view.

   Note: The Browse button defaults to Report Templates directory provided by Vault.

   You can also click the drop-down arrow beside the Browse Files button to specify whether you want to browse for templates on the local machine or in a vault.
6. Select the BOM template that matches the view that you selected and click Open.
7. Verify that you have identified the correct template and click OK.

**Parent page:** [Bills of Materials (BOMs)](GUID-86373139-0500-4B28-A5C3-DE80A53D1AF6.htm)


### Intrinsic BOM Row Properties

# Intrinsic BOM Row Properties

Learn about the intrinsic BOM row properties available in Vault.

There are five intrinsic BOM row properties:

* **Detail ID**

  An identifier for the BOM row. This value is not necessarily related to the order in which the rows are presented.

  Since it is often necessary to re-order rows but to maintain a unique ID for each individual row for documentation purposes, the Detail ID allows you to track your BOM rows, regardless of their order in the BOM.
* **Row Type**

  Displays whether the BOM row was added manually or imported from a CAD file.
* **Unit QTY**

  This is the unit size.
* **Item QTY**

  This is the number of items in the row.

Important: Both Unit QTY and Item QTY properties can be edited for both CAD imported and Manual rows. However, if you edit a CAD imported row, the modified values are overwritten with the values from the CAD file the next time the item is updated.

Tip: Add custom or intrinsic BOM row properties so that they are visible in the BOMs by [Customizing the BOM view](GUID-E926FCEE-9774-4329-BDCD-87BB537BFE17.htm).

See [Create a BOM Row Property Definition](https://beehive.autodesk.com/community/service/rest/cloudhelp/resource/cloudhelpchannel/guidcrossbook/?p=VAULT&l=ENU&accessmode=live&v=2026&guid=GUID-E8EFF24A-E893-48E3-B6A3-88231D4ACA42) for information on creating custom BOM row properties.

**Parent page:** [Bills of Materials (BOMs)](GUID-86373139-0500-4B28-A5C3-DE80A53D1AF6.htm)


### Customize the Bill of Materials (BOM) View

# Customize the Bill of Materials (BOM) View

Customize how your BOMs are displayed in the preview pane and the item record.

You can customize your display by:

* adding or removing column fields
* selecting whether grid lines display between rows
* selecting whether columns are automatically sized
* Showing or hiding the Find Panel.

There is also an option to reset the view to the default settings.

## Customize Fields, Grid Lines, and Column Sizing in the BOM View

1. Select the Item Master.
2. Select the Bill of Materials tab in the Preview Pane.
3. Right-click in the white space beneath the BOM rows and select Customize View.

   Note: You can also customize the view from the BOM tab on an Item Record.
4. On Customize View dialog, click Fields to add or remove column fields.

   On the Customize Fields dialog, do any of the following:

   * Select a property from the Available fields list and Click Add to add it to the list of shown fields.

     Tip: Use the drop-down filter to control which types of properties are displayed in the Available Fields list.

     Note: Not all added fields are visible when the BOM is displayed in Parts-Only view.
   * Select a field that is shown and click Remove to remove it from the BOM view.
   * Select any of the fields that are being shown and click Move up or Move Down to adjust the order in which the fields are displayed on the BOM.

   Note: See [Intrinsic BOM Properties](Intrinsic-BOM-Row-Properties.htm) and [Create a BOM Row Property Definition](https://beehive.autodesk.com/community/service/rest/cloudhelp/resource/cloudhelpchannel/guidcrossbook/?p=VAULT&l=ENU&accessmode=live&v=2026&guid=GUID-E8EFF24A-E893-48E3-B6A3-88231D4ACA42) for more information.

   Click OK to save your changes to the Fields.
5. Click Other Settings to select your BOM view experience settings.

   On the Settings dialog, select:

   * Whether you want grid lines shown between the rows.
   * Whether you want columns to automatically resize based on the column data.

   Click OK to save your changes to the BOM settings.
6. Click Reset on the Customize View dialog at any time to reset all settings to the default settings.
7. Click Close to exit the Customize View dialog.

## Show or Hide the Find Panel

Use the Find panel to search BOM rows within the current context of the grid. The current row filter selection is respected.

1. Select the Item Master.
2. Select the Bill of Materials tab in the Preview Pane.
3. Right-click in the white space beneath the BOM rows and select Show Find Panel to show it at the top of the grid.

   Deselect Show Find Panel to hide it from the BOM View.

### Search BOM View

# Search BOM View

Use the Find Panel to search listed BOMs in the BOM view, including the multi-level view.

## Rules for BOM Searches

* Rows that match search criteria are displayed along with their parents, all the way up to the top-level node.
* All related parents of nodes that meet search criteria are displayed, even if the parents themselves do not meet the search criteria.
* The search honors the current Row Type selection.

The Find Panel must be turned on to search BOMs.

2. Select the Bill of Materials tab in the Preview Pane.
3. Right-click in the white space beneath the BOM rows and select Show Find Panel.

The Find Panel displays in the upper right of the BOM view.

## Change Orders

# Change Orders

Change orders are a component of the change management process that describe why, how, and when changes are made to a design.

Note: Change Orders are available only in Vault Professional.

Change order states help track the progression of the change order through the change management process. The state of the change order can determine which users can affect the change order, based on the user's role. Change orders use a routing list to control which users are notified when a Change Order enters a certain state. See [Working with Change Order States](GUID-0887FD74-C548-4118-9D20-E3126C0B7E4F.htm), for more information.

## Change Order Pre-requisites

* You must be an Administrator or Change Order Editor to create or participate in a change order.

  See Roles and Permissions for more information.
* A routing list and numbering scheme must be already be defined.

  Note: The routing list may be modified after creating the change order.

See [Change Order Administration](https://beehive.autodesk.com/community/service/rest/cloudhelp/resource/cloudhelpchannel/guidcrossbook/?p=VAULT&l=ENU&accessmode=live&v=2026&guid=GUID-1425F5FA-80E5-4D32-BAD5-01A44A6CD529) for more information.

### Change Order Dialog

# Change Order Dialog

View and edit change order details, add comments or associated items, and specify routing lists on the Change Order dialog.

## Access the Change Order Dialog

There are two ways to access the Change Order dialog:

* In the Change Order List view, right-click on an existing change order (ECO) and select Edit.
* In the Change Order List view, select File > New to create a new change order.

The Change Order dialog has six tabs:

* **General**: Contains the change order attributes.
* **Records**: Displays the list of files and items associated with the change order. The record details for each file or item include a title, description, revision, and the state.
* **Comments**: Summarizes the decisions for the change order in the form of comments, attachments, and markups. You can also customize email notifications.
* **Files**: Lists all files and associated items for the change order. Attachments and markups are also listed.
* **Routing**: Lists the participants involved with the current change order.
* **Status**: Contains a graphical representation of the current status of the change order.

Use the toolbar to interact with the change order:

* **Save**: Saves the change order with any changes that have been made.
* **Update**: Updates the record selected in the Records tab.
* **Refresh**: Refreshes the view.

The Change Order toolbar indicates what activities can be performed depending on:

* The current state of the change order
* The role of the participant.

#### View Change Orders

# View Change Orders

View the change order summary and status, attached items, comments, and the routing list on the Change Order dialog.

## View a Change Order Summary

## View Comments Attached to a Change Order

## View Files Attached to a Change Order

#### Add Files or Items to Change Orders

# Add Files or Items to Change Orders

Add files, related files, or items to a change order as part of your change management process.

Refer to the [rules](GUID-F3DECAE8-D0BA-405F-821D-8F749FEF1D71.htm) for working with Change Orders, Files, and Items for more information.

## Add a File or Item to a Change Order

### Add an Item or a File to a Change Order from the Change Order View

1. Right-click a change order and then select Edit.
2. In the ECO dialog, select the Records tab.
3. Click Add.
4. The Find dialog is displayed. Locate the files or items to add. Multiple files or items can be added at the same time.

* To remove a file or item from the change order, highlight the file or item you want to remove, and click Remove.

### Add an Item to a Change Order from the Item View

1. Right-click on an item or items not already assigned to a change order and select Add to Change Order.
2. On the Find dialog, search for the change order to which you want to assign the item(s).
3. Select the change order from the results list and click OK to complete the assignment.

## Add Related Files Or Items to a Change Order

### Add Related Files to a Change Order

1. Right-click a change order and then select Edit.
2. In the ECO dialog, select the Records tab.
3. Right-click a file listed on the Records tab and then select Add Related.
4. In the Add Related dialog, turn on the check box next to a child or parent file to add that file to the change order. If the check box for a file is disabled, the file is already on the change order or is on another change order and cannot be selected.
5. Click OK to add the related files to the change order.

### Add Related Items to a Change Order

1. Right-click a change order and then select Edit.
2. In the ECO dialog, select the Records tab.
3. Right-click an item listed on the Records tab and then select Add Related.
4. In the Add Related Items dialog:

   * click the Bill of Materials tab to add related child items. Turn on the check box next to a child item to add that item to the change order or click Auto Add to add all previously unreleased child items to the change order. If the check box for an item is disabled, that item is already on the relevant change order or is on another change order and cannot be selected.
   * click the Where Used tab to add related parent items. Turn on the check box next to a parent item to add that item to the change order. If the check box for an item is disabled, that item is already on the relevant change order or is on another change order and cannot be selected.

# Add Comments to a Change Order

## Rules for Adding Comments to a Change Order

* You must be a routing participant on the change order.

  + By the Change Administrator or Responsible Engineer upon changing the state of the change order.
  + By all participants in the Work state.

Any routing participant or the author of the change order can add comments in the Work state. This allows anyone with the appropriate role to add their comments and participate in the change order. The routing can be modified by any routing participant to add reviewers who want to add comments to the change order.

#### Change Order Routing Roles

# Change Order Routing Roles

When a change order is created, you must specify a routing. A routing is a list of participants with pre-defined roles. Each of the six different routing roles has specific permissions and responsibilities.

The Change Administrator, Responsible Engineer, and Approver roles control the progression of the change order. The Reviewer role can add markups, view, add, and reply to comments.

The person creating the change order automatically becomes a Reviewer on the change order routing. Any participant can add additional Reviewers to the routing as needed.

The task a routing participant can perform depends on the routing participant role.

Note: Only users with Administrator or Change Order Editor privileges can be assigned routing roles. Refer to [Manage Users and Roles](https://beehive.autodesk.com/community/service/rest/cloudhelp/resource/cloudhelpchannel/guidcrossbook/?p=VAULT&l=ENU&accessmode=live&v=2026&guid=GUID-428B79D5-7F4B-4182-932A-D52D61BD962D) for more information.

## Routing Roles Details

| Routing Role | Definition |
| --- | --- |
| Approver | Can review, approve, and reject a change order. |
| Change Administrator | Can add or remove Approvers, Change Administrators, and Responsible Engineers. This participant can edit the title of the change order, add or remove files or items, and modify user-defined properties.  An item becomes effective when it is released.  The Change Administrator can also cancel the change order or reopen a rejected change order. |
| Change Requestor | This participant initiated the change order and automatically becomes a reviewer. |
| Checker | If Check State is enabled, a Checker is added to the list of routing participants when a work order is rejected. The checker can review, approve, or reject the change order.  Note: The standard workflow does not included the Check State or Checker role. |
| Notification User | Receives notification when the change order is closed. |
| Responsible Engineer | Can edit the change order, make necessary revisions, and submit the change order for review. |
| Reviewer | Can only view, add, and reply to comments. |

Note: Any participant can add additional Reviewers to the routing as needed.

**Parent page:** [Change Order Dialog](GUID-01920ABD-30B0-41AC-B0BC-4C8ED59ABBF8.htm)


#### Manage Change Order Routings

# Manage Change Order Routings

Each of the different roles has specific permissions and responsibilities. Change order activities can only be performed by routing participants.

Routing Rules

* Routing lists can only be created by a user with Administrative permissions.
* Only users with Administrator or Change Order Editor privileges can be assigned routing roles. Refer to [Manage Users and Roles](https://beehive.autodesk.com/community/service/rest/cloudhelp/resource/cloudhelpchannel/guidcrossbook/?p=VAULT&l=ENU&accessmode=live&v=2026&guid=GUID-428B79D5-7F4B-4182-932A-D52D61BD962D) for more information.
* Depending on the state of the change order, anyone on the routing can add another reviewer, except for the Notification User.
* The Administrator, Change Administrator, and Responsible Engineer can add and remove Approvers and Change Administrators.
* Only the Administrator, Change Administrator, and Responsible Engineer can remove a reviewer.

#### Work with Change Order States

# Work with Change Order States

The state of a change order determines which change order fields can be modified and by which users.

## View the Workflow Chart for a Change Order

* The Status tab in the Change Order dialog box displays a workflow chart of all possible combinations of state progressions.
* You can also view the current status of the change order by selecting the Status tab in the Change Order dialog box. Double-click a state to view information about that state.

By default, a single participant assigned the approval role can approve a change order that is in the Review state. The routing definition can optionally require all participants with approval permission to approve a change order for it to enter the approved state.

The Change Administrator can optionally require that all participants with approval permission must approve a change order for it to enter the approved state.

Note: The Change Administrator can force the approval of an open change order.

Once a change order is fully approved, the change order enters the closed state. When the change order closes, the Change State dialog can be displayed for the associated items which allows the user to select any lifecycle state that is set for items. The conditions for displaying the Change State dialog are as follows:

* If the Change Order is closed exclusively for attached items, the Change State dialog is displayed.
* If the Change Order is closed exclusively for attached files, the Change State dialog isn't displayed.
* If the Change Order is closed for both items and files, the Change State dialog is displayed only for items.

|  |  |
| --- | --- |
| *Change Order State* | *Description* |
| Create | When a new change order is saved, it enters the Create state. The person requesting the change order is automatically assigned to the Change Requestor role. When the Change Requestor submits the change order, the change order enters the Open state and notification is sent to the users that have a role in the next state of the workflow.  In the Create state: the Change Requestor can perform the following actions:   * Edit * Submit * Delete   Note: The Change Requestor cannot change item lifecycle, roll back lifecyle, or update the item associated with the change order.  The change Administrator can delete the change order or submit it. Once submitted, the change order enters the Open state. Notification is sent to the Change Administrator, indicating there is a change order requiring attention. |
| Open | Open Change Orders show current data or the tip versions of the objects in the change order. In the Open state, the Change Administrator can perform the following actions:   * Edit * Submit and Force Approval * Cancel * Submit   Upon clicking Submit, the change order enters the Work state. Notification is sent to the Responsible Engineer, Change Administrator, and Change Requestor on the routing list, alerting the participants that there is a change order requiring attention. |
| Work | In the Work State,   * A Reviewer can add comments, reply to comments, and view. * The Change Requestor can add comments, reply to comments, and view. * The Change Administrator can withdraw the change order from the process or fast track the change order through the approval process. * The Responsible Engineer makes the requested design changes, and submits the change order for review. * Anyone except the Notification User can edit the routing list per rules specified in the routing section.   Once the Responsible Engineer submits the change order, it enters the Check state or the Review state based on the workflow definition specified in the Administration dialog box. |
| Check (optional) | If the change order workflow definition is set to Check State in the Administration dialog box, the change order enters the Check state when submitted by the Responsible Engineer. Notification is sent to the Checker, Change Requestor, and Reviewer alerting that the change order requires attention.  In the Check State:   * The Checker can reject or approve the change order. * The Change Requestor or the Reviewer can add comments and reply to comments.   If the Checker rejects the change order, it returns to the Work state. Once the Checker approves the change order, it enters the Review state. |
| Review | Upon a change order being submitted for review, the change order enters the Review state. Notification is sent alerting the Reviewers and the Approvers that there is a Change Order requiring their attention.  In the Review state:   * The approver can approve or reject the change order. * The change Requestor or the Reviewer can add comments and reply to comments.   For a change order to enter the Approved state:   * One Approver approves the change order if the routing definition does not specify unanimous approval. * All Approvers must approve the change order if unanimous approval is specified.   Note: If the Approver rejects the change order, the change order enters the Rejected state. In the Rejected state, the Change Administrator can re-open or cancel the change order. |
| Approved | In the Approved state, the change order can only be closed.  When a change order enters the Closed State, effectivity is immediate and notification is sent to anyone listed as a Notification User on the routing list. |
| Cancelled | In the Cancelled state, no action can be taken by anyone. |
| Closed | In the Closed state, no action can be taken by anyone.  Closed Change Orders show historical data, old versions, or revisions of objects. |

**Parent page:** [Change Order Dialog](GUID-01920ABD-30B0-41AC-B0BC-4C8ED59ABBF8.htm)

### Rules and Best Practices for Using Change Orders with Files

# Rules and Best Practices for Using Change Orders with Files

Certain rules apply to closing a change order or releasing files with relationships. Follow these rules and best practices for using change orders with files.

## General Rules

* Only users with Administrator or Change Order Editor security permissions can affect change orders.
* A file can only be associated with one active change order at a time. Once a change order has been closed or cancelled, the file can be associated with a new or a currently active change order.
* Change orders do not drive file state changes. However, a change order will prevent certain lifecycle state changes for the file depending on the change order's state and if *linked to change order* is added as a criteria in the file's lifecycle transition.

## Rule for Closing a Change Order

* The change order must be in the Approved state.

## Best Practices

* As a best practice, you should add all children to a change order with an assembly. Reviewers and Approvers are notified of all affected files.
* In general, it is useful to add all files affected by a design change to the change order. For example, in Autodesk Inventor, changing a part also changes the parent assembly.

**Parent page:** [Change Orders](GUID-967A669D-028F-4E7B-AD66-86780FDAC4E9.htm)


### Rules and Best Practices for Using Change Orders with Items

# Rules and Best Practices for Using Change Orders with Items

Certain rules apply to using change orders with items and lifecycle states, closing a change order, or releasing items with relationships. Follow these rules and best practices for using change orders with items.

## General Rules

* Only users with Administrator or Change Order Editor security permissions can affect change orders.
* An item can only be associated with one active change order at a time. Once a change order has been closed or cancelled, the item can be associated with a new or a currently active change order.
* The Change Order Administrator can make the item editable in all states except Canceled and Closed. The Responsible Engineer can make an item editable in the Work State, changing the lifecycle state. See the next section for more detail.
* An Item Editor Level 2 can edit an item associated with a change order when it is in the Work in Progress state except for the following:

  + Change State
  + New Change Order

## Rules for Using Change Orders with Items and Lifecycle States

* If a released item is added to a change order and the Change Order Administrator changes the state of the item to Work in Progress, the item changes to Work in Progress and a new revision is created according to the Bump revision action specified in the Lifecycles rules dialog box. If the Bump revision action is set to None, a new revision is not created.
* The state of an item does not change when it is attached to a change order.

  After a new revision is created, the Change Order Administrator can change the lifecycle state of the item making the item editable or non-editable by using the Change State command available from the context menu in the Change Order dialog box in the Item tab. The context menu displays the available lifecycle states.

## Rules for Closing a Change Order

* The change order must be in the Approved state.

When you close a change order, a Change State dialog displays asking if you want to change the state for assocaited items. You can modify the item states before closing the change order, or simply close the change order without making any changes.

## Best Practices

* As a best practice, you should add all children to a change order with an assembly. Reviewers and Approvers are notified of all affected items.
* In general, it is useful to add all items affected by a design change to the change order. For example, in Autodesk Inventor, changing a part also changes the parent assembly.

**Parent page:** [Change Orders](GUID-967A669D-028F-4E7B-AD66-86780FDAC4E9.htm)


### Create a Change Order

# Create a Change Order

Track and officiate changes to your design files by creating change orders.

1. In the Vault Explorer, select the Change Order List, then right-click Change Order List, and select New.

   OR

   Right-click a file or item and select Add to Change Order > To New to create a change order for the selected file or item.
2. In the Change Order (ECO) dialog, select the ellipses icon ![](../images/icon_ellipses.png) next to the change order number to specify a numbering scheme.
3. In the Change Order Numbering Scheme dialog, select the drop-down arrow and make a selection.

   Note: The numbering scheme cannot be changed after the change order has been created and enters the Open state.
4. Enter a title in the Change Order Title field.
5. Enter a description in the Detailed Description field.
6. Click the down arrow in the Due Date field, and select a date the change order is to be completed by.
7. To attach files or items to the change order, click the Records tab, and then click Add in the Associated Records section. The Find dialog box is displayed.
8. You must attach a file or item to create a change order. Use the Find dialog to locate the file(s) or item(s) to add to the change order. From the search results list, select the file(s) or item(s) to add and then click OK. The files or items are added to the change order.

   Note: If items are added, any files to which the items are assigned are added automatically.
9. To remove a file or item from the change order, highlight the file or item you want to remove, and click Remove in the Associated Items section.
10. All properties are automatically added when the change order is created. The property values can be edited. Right click in the Value field on the General tab and enter a value. The Name field cannot be edited.
11. Click the Routing tab, and then click the down arrow to specify the routing to be used.
12. All the files to which items are assigned are automatically added to the change order when the items are added. To add more files, click the, and then click attach.

    Note: You can only attach files that are in the vault.

    To remove a file, highlight the file, and then click Remove.

    To markup a file, select the file and use the Autodesk Composer markup tools. Click Save to save the markup and add a comment. Click Help on the Composer toolbar for help with using the Autodesk Composer tools. The selected file must either be a .dwf or have a .dwf file type associated with it (see details on publishing DWF files when adding them to the vault).
13. To see which items are assigned to the attached files, select a file from the list and select the Associated Items tab.
14. Click Save and Close to create the change order and exit the dialog box.

The user creating the Change Order is automatically assigned to the Change Requestor role.

### Manage Change Order Notifications

# Manage Change Order Notifications

A user on the routing list is notified when the change order enters a state that requires attention.

For example, the Responsible Engineer is notified when the change order enters the Work state, but the approver does not get notified until it enters the Review state.

* The change order number is added to each participant's worklist.
* An e-mail message is sent to each person on the routing list. The administrator must configure Autodesk data management server for e-mail notification and Vault Professional users must have valid e-mail addresses in their user profiles. For more information on configuring the data management server for e-mail notification, see the server console help.
* If Vault Professional is running but inactive, an alert is sent to each person on the routing list.

## Turn ECO Notification Off or On

The pop-up message indicating an ECO has been added to your worklist can be turned off or on. By default, the pop-up notification is on.

* From the View menu, select Notification Display.

### Change Administrator and Responsible Engineer Tasks

# Change Administrator and Responsible Engineer Tasks

Change Administrators and Responsible Engineers have the greatest range of permissions and control over the change order process.

When you create a change order, you select a routing definition requiring one or more participants to approve the change order.

**Before you create a change order**: Make sure that a routing has been created by the administrator. The routing should contain everyone that needs to review, be responsible for, and approve the change order.

Note: The routing list may be edited as needed by the Change Administrator after the change order has been created. Anyone already on the routing can add a reviewer. The administrator can add or remove Approvers, Change Administrators, and Responsible Engineers.

## Permission Requirements

You must have one of the following permissions to be a Change Administrator:

* Administrator
* Change Order Editor

The data associated with an open change order can be modified by the Change Administrator.

In the Open and Review State

* Change the state of the item. Changing the state to Work In Progress allows the item to be edited. Changing it to In Review locks the item, preventing the item from being edited.

  Note: When you change the state of a released item to Work In Progress, a new revision is created. If the Bump revision action is set to None in the Lifecylce Rules dialog box a new revision is not created.

  When Change State is disabled, the lifecycle state of the item changes to In Review.
* Attach or remove files.
* Create a markup from an attached .dwf file and add a comment to the markup.
* Customize the email notification
* Add or remove items.
* Add, remove, or edit user-defined properties

#### Open State

The Change Administrator can edit the title, edit the value of a user-defined property, and change the attachment of an open change order.

The Change Administrator can perform the same editing tasks in the open state as in the state when the change order is first being created with one exception: The specified numbering scheme cannot be changed.

Change the lifecycle state of the item by using the change state command in the context menu of a selected item.

#### Work State

When a change order enters the Work state, the Responsible Engineer is notified that there is a change order requiring attention:

* The change order number is added to the work list of each participant.
* An e-mail message is sent to each person on the routing list if they have subscribed to e-mail notification for change order events.

Anyone can view the status.

A reviewer can view, add, and reply to change order comments.

The Responsible Engineer can edit the change order, as well as make the necessary revisions and then submit the change order for review.

#### Review State

* When a change order enters the Review state, routing participants are notified that there is a change order requiring attention:

  The change order number is added to each participant's work list.
* An e-mail message is sent to each person on the routing list if they have subscribed to e-mail notification for change order events.

A reviewer can view, add, and reply to change order comments.

Anyone can view the status.

#### Approved State

A participant with approver status can approve a change order.

The Change Administrator can change the life cycle state of the item by selecting an item and selecting Change State from the context menu. Only the allowable state changes are displayed.

Items are effective immediately when released.

#### Rejected State

A participant with Approver status can reject a change order.

As a Change Administrator, you can do the following to a rejected change order:

* Cancel the Change Order
* Reopen the change order

#### Perform Change Administrator Tasks on a Change Order in the Open State

# Perform Change Administrator Tasks on a Change Order in the Open State

When a change order is in the open state, the Change Administrators can edit the change order or the routing. In addition, the change administrator can submit the change order to the Work State, submit the change order and force approval, or cancel the change order.

Note: Only the Change Administrator can perform change order tasks in the Open state.

## Edit the Change Order

1. In the main pane, right-click the change order and select Edit.
2. In the Change Order dialog box, make appropriate changes.

   Note: The Change Administrator can perform the same tasks in the Change Order dialog box as can be done when a change order is created (see-above) except:

   * The numbering scheme cannot be changed.
   * To access the edit routing dialog box, right-click a change order in the open state and click Edit Routing.
   * You can create markups of attached 2D .dwf files.

     Note: You can only view 3d files (.dwf files of an .ipt or .iam file)

     To markup a 2d .dwf file, select the file and use the Autodesk Composer markup tools. Select the Save button to save the markup and add a comment. Click the help button on the Composer toolbar for help with using the Autodesk Composer tools.
3. Click Save and Close.

## Edit the Routing

1. In the main pane, right-click the change order and select Edit Routing, or select the routing tab and click Edit.
2. In the edit routing dialog box, highlight a user in the list of change order participants and click add.

   Note: Only users with Administrator or Change Order Editor permissions are listed.

   To remove a user, highlight a user in the list of routing participants, and click remove.

   Note: A reviewer cannot be removed. Approvers, Responsible Engineers, and Change Administrators can only be edited by the administrator.
3. Click OK to save changes.

## Submit the Change Order to the Work State

In the Work State the Responsible Engineer makes the requested design changes.

1. Right-click the change order in the main pane, and select Respond > Submit.
2. In the Add Comments dialog box, select the Comment tab and edit the description and comments in the text boxes if appropriate.
3. Select the Email tab and modify the email notification if needed.
4. Click Add comment to email to include the comments to the change order in the email notification.
5. Click OK to save the comment and send notification to all routing participants.

## Submit the Change Order and Force Approval

1. Right-click the change order in the main pane, and select Respond > Submit and Force Approval.
2. In the Add Comments dialog box, select the Comment tab and edit the description and comments in the text boxes if appropriate.
3. Select the Email tab and modify the notification if appropriate.
4. Click OK to save the comment and send notification to all routing participants.

## Cancel

1. In the main pane, right-click the change order and select Respond > Cancel.
2. In the Cancel - Add Comments dialog box, select the Comment tab and edit the description and comments in the text boxes if appropriate.
3. Select the Email tab and edit the notification if appropriate.
4. Click OK to save the comment and send notification to all routing participants.

**Parent page:** [Change Administrator and Responsible Engineer Tasks](GUID-A2965595-061E-4865-8A93-7222A7EB2290.htm)


#### Perform Responsible Engineer Tasks on a Change Order in the Work State

# Perform Responsible Engineer Tasks on a Change Order in the Work State

When a change order is in the Work State, the Responsible Engineer can edit the routing, as well as view, add, and reply to comments. The Responsible Engineer can also withdraw a change order from the Work State and return it to the Open State.

Note: Only the Responsible Engineer can make changes to the Change Order when it is in the Work State.

## View, add, and reply to comments to the change order

1. In the main pane, right-click the change order and select View and Respond.
2. In the Change Order dialog box, select the General, Files, and Routing tabs to view basic information and attached files.
3. Select the Comments tab to view comments from other participants or to add your own.

   Add comments:

   1. Click Add Comment.
   2. Select the Comment tab and enter any comments.
   3. Select the Email tab and modify the notification if appropriate.
   4. Click OK to save the comment and send notification to all routing participants.

   Reply to comments:

   1. Right-click a comment, and select Reply Comment.
   2. In the Comments tab, click Add Comment.
   3. Select the Comment tab and enter any comments.
   4. To add an attachment, click Attachments and browse for a file in the vault or a file attached to the change order.

      To markup a 2D .dwf file, use the Autodesk Composer markup tools shown in the graphics display. Click the help button on the Composer toolbar for help with using the Autodesk Composer tools.
   5. Select the Email tab and modify the notification if appropriate.
   6. Click OK to save the comment and send notification to all routing participants.
4. Status: To view the current status of the change order and review actions taken by the change order participants.

   * To review when the change order entered a particular state (including multiple times) and on what date, double-click a Status box.

     Note: No information is displayed if the change order has not been in the selected state.
5. Click Save and Close to save your comments.

## Add Comments

1. In the main pane, right-click the change order and select Respond > Add Comments.
2. Select the Comment tab and enter any comments.
3. To add an attachment, click Attachments and browse for a file in the vault or a file attached to the change order.
4. Select the Email tab and modify the notification if appropriate.
5. Click OK to save the comment and send notification to all routing participants.

## Edit the Routing

1. In the main pane, right-click the change order and select Edit Routing.
2. In the edit routing dialog box, highlight a user on the left and click add.

   To remove a user, highlight a user on the right, and click remove.

   Note: A reviewer cannot be removed. Approvers, Responsible Engineers and Change Administrators can only be edited by the administrator.
3. Click OK to save changes.

## Withdraw

1. In the main pane, right-click the change order and select Respond > Withdraw.
2. In the Withdraw - Add Comments dialog box, select the Comment tab and edit the description and comments in the text boxes if appropriate.
3. To add an attachment, click Attachments and browse for a file in the vault or a file attached to the change order.
4. Select the Email tab and modify the notification if appropriate.
5. Click OK to save the comment and send notification to all routing participants.

The change order returns to the Open state.

Upon a change order being submitted for Review, the change order enters the Review state.

**Parent page:** [Change Administrator and Responsible Engineer Tasks](GUID-A2965595-061E-4865-8A93-7222A7EB2290.htm)


#### Perform Change Administrator Tasks on a Change Order in the Review State

# Perform Change Administrator Tasks on a Change Order in the Review State

In the Review State the Change Administrator can perform the same editing tasks as when the Change Order is in the Open State. Approvers can approve or reject the Change Order.

Note: Only a reviewer can add and reply to comments.

Approver Tasks

* Reject and Reopen the Change Order.
* Reject and Cancel the Change Order.
* Approve the Change Order.

Rules for Submitting a Change Order for Approval

The change order must be approved by a participant with the Approver role for the change order to enter the approved state.

When a change order is submitted for Approval, the change order enters the Approved state if the following conditions apply:

* An Approver approves the change order and the routing definition does not specify unanimous approval.
* The routing definition specifies unanimous approval and all Approvers on the routing have approved the change order.

**Parent page:** [Change Administrator and Responsible Engineer Tasks](GUID-A2965595-061E-4865-8A93-7222A7EB2290.htm)


#### Perform Change Administrator Tasks on a Change Order in the Approved State

# Perform Change Administrator Tasks on a Change Order in the Approved State

Change Administrators can close change orders that are in the Approved state.

1. Right-click the change order in the main pane and select Close Change Order.
2. In Close Change Order- Add Comments dialog box, select the Comment tab and edit the description and comments in the text boxes if appropriate.
3. To add an attachment, click Attachments and browse for a file in the vault or a file attached to the change order.
4. Select the Email tab and modify the notification if appropriate.
5. Click OK to save the comment and send notification to all routing participants.

On Close Change Order, the system attempts to release all files and items on the change order. Effectivity is immediate.

If the state of any file or items is Released prior to this action, no action occurs.

**Parent page:** [Change Administrator and Responsible Engineer Tasks](GUID-A2965595-061E-4865-8A93-7222A7EB2290.htm)


#### Perform Change Administrator Tasks on a Change Order in the Rejected State

# Perform Change Administrator Tasks on a Change Order in the Rejected State

Change Administrators can Reopen or Cancel a Change Order in the Rejected State.

When a participant with Approver status rejects a change order, the change order enters into the Rejected State. Only a user with a Change Administrator role can respond to a change order in the rejected state.

## Reopen

1. Right-click the change order in the main pane and select Respond > Reopen.
2. In the Reopen- Add Comments dialog box, select the Comment tab and edit the description and comments in the text boxes if appropriate.
3. To add an attachment, click Attachments and browse for a file in the vault or a file attached to the change order.
4. Select the Email tab and modify the notification if appropriate.
5. Click OK to save the comment and send notification to all routing participants.

The change order returns to the Open state.

## Cancel

1. Right-click the change order in the main pane and select Respond > Cancel.
2. In the Cancel- Add Comments dialog box, select the Comment tab and edit the description and comments in the text boxes if appropriate.
3. To add an attachment, click Attachments and browse for a file in the vault or a file attached to the change order.
4. Select the Email tab and modify the notification if appropriate.
5. Click OK to save the comment and send notification to all routing participants.

The change order enters the Cancel state.

When a change order enters the Closed State, Notification is sent to anyone listed as a Notification User on the routing list.

**Parent page:** [Change Administrator and Responsible Engineer Tasks](GUID-A2965595-061E-4865-8A93-7222A7EB2290.htm)


### Change Order Reviewer Tasks

# Change Order Reviewer Tasks

Change Order Reviewers can view the change order, add and reply to comments, and add attachments and markups. Reviewers can also add additional reviewers to the routing.

You must be a routing participant assigned the Reviewer role to review a change order.

Note: When you create a change order, you are automatically assigned the role Reviewer.

## Notifications

When you are added as a reviewer to a change order, you are notified in the following ways:

* The change order number is automatically added to your work list.
* A notification window appears if Vault Professional is not the active application.

**Parent page:** [Change Orders](GUID-967A669D-028F-4E7B-AD66-86780FDAC4E9.htm)


### Change Order Approver Tasks

# Change Order Approver Tasks

The Approver role only allows you to approve or reject a change order. You must explicitly be given the reviewer role to add or reply to comments.

You must be a routing participant with approver permissions to approve a change order. Only a Change Administrator can modify how a change order is approved.

## Notifications

As an Approver on a change order, you are notified in the following ways:

* The change order number is automatically added to your work list.
* An e-mail message is sent to you.
* A notification window appears if Vault Professional is not the active application.

**Change Order status icons**

|  |  |
| --- | --- |
|  | Work in Progress: When one or more items on a change order is in the Work in Progress lifecycle state, an icon displays on the change order to indicate design changes are in progress and the change order should not be approved yet. |
|  | Ready For Final Review: When all items on the change order are either in review or are released, an icon indicates to the routing participants who are responsible for approving or rejecting the change order that the change order is ready to be approved or rejected. |
|  | Closed or Cancelled: Indicates the change order is closed or cancelled. |

**Parent page:** [Change Orders](GUID-967A669D-028F-4E7B-AD66-86780FDAC4E9.htm)


### Perform Reviewer Tasks on Change Orders

# Perform Reviewer Tasks on Change Orders

Reviewers can view, add, and reply to change order comments, and add additional Reviewers to the routing.

## View, Add, and Reply to Comments

1. Right-click the change order and then select View and respond.
2. Click a tab to perform the following:

   * **General:** View the basic information regarding the change order.
   * **Records:** View the files and items associated with the change order.
   * **Comments:** View comments made by any of the routing participants, add your own and reply to existing comments. You can also customize the email notification.

     To add comments, click Add comments, and enter a title and your remarks in the text fields.

     To add attachments, click Attachments.

     To reply to comments, right-click a comment, and select Reply to comment. Select Include Original comment to include original comment.

     To customize an email notification, select the the Email tab and modify the message.
   * **Files:** View any files that are attached.
   * **Routing:** View the routing participants.
   * **Status:** View the state of the change order.
3. Click File > Exit to close the dialog box.

## Add Comments without Viewing

1. Right-click the change order in the main pane, and select Respond > Add Comments.
2. In the Add Comments dialog box, enter your remarks.
3. To add attachments, click Attachments.
4. To customize the email notification, click the Email tab and make changes as appropriate.
5. Click OK to create the operation.

## Add Additional Reviewers to the Routing

1. Right-click the change order in the main pane, and select Edit Routing.
2. In the Edit Routing dialog box, select a user from the left column, and then click Add.
3. Click OK.

Note: You cannot remove any routing participants, including the ones you add.

**Parent page:** [Change Orders](GUID-967A669D-028F-4E7B-AD66-86780FDAC4E9.htm)


### Perform Approver Tasks on a Change Order

# Perform Approver Tasks on a Change Order

Approvers can Approve or Reject a Change Order.

You must be a routing participant with Approver permissions. Only a Change Administrator can modify how a change order is approved.

Note: The Approver role only allows you to approve a change order. You must explicitly be given the reviewer role if you need to add or reply to comments.

An Approver should only proceed to approve or reject a change order when the change order is in the Ready For Final Review state. This status is reported if all of the items or files on the Change Order are in either an In Review or Released Lifecycle State.

## Approve

1. Right-click the change order in the main pane, and select Respond > Approve.
2. In the Add comments dialog box, select the Comment tab and edit the description and comments in the text boxes, if appropriate.
3. Select the Email tab and edit the email notification, if appropriate.
4. Click OK to approve the change order.

   Note: When the change order is initially created, the Routing can optionally specify approval must be unanimous by all approvers, when more than one approver has been added to the routing. In such cases, when all the approver participants have approved the change order, the change order status changes from Approval to Approved.

   The status changes from Review to Approved when:

   * You are the only approver on the routing.
   * You are the first of more than one approver on the routing to approve the change order and unanimous approval was not specified.
   * You are the last of more than one approver on the routing to approve the change order and unanimous approval was specified.

## Reject

1. Right-click the change order in the main pane, and select Respond > Reject.
2. In the Add comments dialog box, select the Comment tab and edit the description and comments in the text boxes if appropriate.
3. Select the Email tab and edit the email notification, if appropriate.
4. Click OK to reject the change order.

The change order status changes from Review to Rejected.

**Parent page:** [Change Orders](GUID-967A669D-028F-4E7B-AD66-86780FDAC4E9.htm)


## Custom Objects

# Custom Objects

Learn about Custom Objects.

Custom Objects allow Vault administrators to use an extensible system to create new Vault entities to meet the needs of their team, organization, or company. Right out-of-the-box, the administrator can create a Custom Object definition and assign it categories, lifecycles, and properties. Once the Custom Object definition is created, users can create instances of that custom object directly through the user interface. As with files and folders, users can perform many common Vault tasks with custom objects.

## Custom Object Definitions vs. Custom Object Instances

There are two concepts to the Custom Objects entity class. They are Custom Object definitions and a Custom Object instances.

## Custom Object Definition

* The Custom Object definition is the type of entity that is being created. For example, an administrator can create a custom object definition called Contacts or Tasks.

  Custom Object Definitions are created, edited, and deleted on the Configure Custom Objects Dialog. You can access the Configure Custom Objects Dialog through the Custom Objects Tab on the Vault Settings dialog. You must be an administrator to create and modify custom object definitions.

## Custom Object Instance

* When the user creates a new custom object based on a definition, this is considered an instance. For example, an administrator creates a custom object definition called Contact. A user could then create an instance of that custom object called Bob Smith.
* Users can attach files, folders, and other Vault entities to a custom object with a link.

  For example, if a custom object definition has been created called Tasks and a user has created a task called Review John's Design, the task (Review John's Design) can be linked to John's design in the vault.
* Custom Object instances can be checked in, checked out, undergo a change state, and managed with many common Vault commands. Similarly, linked objects are also affected, depending on the user's settings for the Vault function.

  For example, if a user wants to check out a custom object and the custom object has links to files, folders, items, or change orders; the files associated with that linked data are gathered and checked out as well.
