### Add a New Custom Object Instance

# Add a New Custom Object Instance

A custom object definition must be configured before you can add a new instance of that custom object.

The Administrator can create new custom object definitions on the [Configure Custom Object Definition](https://beehive.autodesk.com/community/service/rest/cloudhelp/resource/cloudhelpchannel/guidcrossbook/?p=VAULT&l=ENU&accessmode=live&v=2026&guid=GUID-E1BA9E4A-443F-43EA-B8BF-3CAA382C25A3) dialog.

Note: Newly created or edited Custom Object definitions will not populate in the Vault Client until the following login.

Add a new custom object instance by performing one of these steps:

1. Select the Custom Object Definition's view button in the lower left of the navigation pane.

   In the following example, there are two types of custom objects that have been defined: Contacts and Tasks. The image shows the user selecting Tasks.

   ![](../images/customobjects-tasksbutton.png)
2. Click New on the toolbar and select New *<custom object>*, where *<custom object>* is the name of the custom object definition from which you want to create an instance.

   In the following example, the user is creating a new Task.

   ![](../images/customobjects-new.png)

   Note: You can also right-click on the custom object node in the tree and select New Task.
3. On the New *<custom object>* dialog, enter a name for the custom object instance.

   For example, this user may want to create an instance of Tasks called Review John's Design.

   ![](../images/customobjects-newtaskdialog.png)
4. Click OK.

   The new custom object instance is added.

**Parent page:** [Custom Objects](GUID-582E4F75-420D-4B77-8433-D41EBC041317.htm)


### Edit a Custom Object Instance

# Edit a Custom Object Instance

There are several ways to modify an existing custom object instance. These modifications are made on the instance and not the entire definition.

For example, edits made to a specific Task, such as Review John's Design, are not being made to the entire Tasks definition. The commands available for custom objects are listed below with a short description of each function.

Note: Refer to the Vault topic for the specified command for more information.

## Check In

Selecting [Check In](https://beehive.autodesk.com/community/service/rest/cloudhelp/resource/cloudhelpchannel/guidcrossbook/?p=VAULT&l=ENU&accessmode=live&v=2026&guid=GUID-94955FE3-C965-428E-B116-48ACA128D59B) on a custom object instance will gather all files that are associated with all linked data. So if the custom object has links to files, folders, items, or change orders; the files associated with that linked data will be gathered and checked in.

## Get/Check Out

Selecting [Get/Check Out](https://beehive.autodesk.com/community/service/rest/cloudhelp/resource/cloudhelpchannel/guidcrossbook/?p=VAULT&l=ENU&accessmode=live&v=2026&guid=GUID-F64CF492-8F37-4A35-AE00-25835D82AD50) on a custom object will download and optionally check out the files associated with the links in the custom object. So if the custom object has links to files, folders, items, or change orders; the files associated with that linked data will be gathered and downloaded/checked out.

## Undo Check Out

Like check in and check out, the undo check out command will undo any check outs needed for files associated with data linked to the custom object.

## Change Category

The Change Category command assigns a new category to a custom object. Links to custom objects of the same definition can be included on the change category dialog.

## Change State

The state can be changed on a custom object as well as any links to the same definition type. So. for example, if a Tasks custom object has been defined, and a task instance has links to other tasks, then all linked tasks can be included in the change state operation.

## Delete

Custom Object instances can be deleted as long as the roles and permissions assigned to the definition and instance allow it. Any links to that instance prompt a dialog to confirm the delete.

## Rename

Custom objects can be renamed with the Rename command. The dialog used for custom objects is similar to the rename folder command.

## Go To

The Go To command takes the user to the source of a link. If this command is chosen on a link to a custom object, the user is taken to the source of the link.

## Details

Selecting this command populates the general properties and security dialog for the custom object. It is here that a [security override](https://beehive.autodesk.com/community/service/rest/cloudhelp/resource/cloudhelpchannel/guidcrossbook/?p=VAULT&l=ENU&accessmode=live&v=2026&guid=GUID-67F7EED5-76C4-4C6F-806C-74D1518A8FF2) can be applied to an instance.

**Parent page:** [Custom Objects](GUID-582E4F75-420D-4B77-8433-D41EBC041317.htm)


### Custom Objects and Categories

# Custom Objects and Categories

Categories can be assigned to custom objects in two ways: when the custom object is created and when the user performs a change category event on the custom object.

By assigning custom object instances to a category, properties and lifecycle definitions associated with the category are automatically applied to the instance.

See [Work with User-Defined Properties](GUID-5F0C9F22-0288-471E-8D64-D5F57FBE300A.htm) for more information.

**Parent page:** [Custom Objects](GUID-582E4F75-420D-4B77-8433-D41EBC041317.htm)


### Custom Objects and Lifecycles

# Custom Objects and Lifecycles

Just like files and folders, when a custom object is assigned a category, it automatically inherits the associated lifecycle definition. Lifecycles can be configured to automate certain behaviors based on the custom object's status in the lifecycle. Lifecycle settings are configured by the administrator.

See [Lifecycles Administration](https://beehive.autodesk.com/community/service/rest/cloudhelp/resource/cloudhelpchannel/guidcrossbook/?p=VAULT&l=ENU&accessmode=live&v=2026&guid=GUID-088F0236-B5B7-4E35-B218-BD2D253B87F6) for more information.

**Parent page:** [Custom Objects](GUID-582E4F75-420D-4B77-8433-D41EBC041317.htm)


### Custom Objects and Properties

# Custom Objects and Properties

Categories can also be used to assign user-defined properties to Custom Objects.

There are also out-of-the-box properties specific to custom objects, such as Custom Object Name and Custom Object System Name.

See [Work with User-Defined Properties](GUID-5F0C9F22-0288-471E-8D64-D5F57FBE300A.htm) for more information.

**Parent page:** [Custom Objects](GUID-582E4F75-420D-4B77-8433-D41EBC041317.htm)


### View Custom Object Properties

# View Custom Object Properties

For custom objects, the properties available are the icon, the name of the instance, custom object type, and lifecycle state.

Follow these steps to view the properties of a custom object instance.

1. Right-click on a custom object instance in the vault.
2. Select Properties.
3. In the Properties dialog box, select the General tab to view the General properties for the instance.
4. Select the Security tab to see the roles and permissions assigned to the instance.

Note: See [Editing and Overriding Custom Object Security](https://beehive.autodesk.com/community/service/rest/cloudhelp/resource/cloudhelpchannel/guidcrossbook/?p=VAULT&l=ENU&accessmode=live&v=2026&guid=GUID-67F7EED5-76C4-4C6F-806C-74D1518A8FF2) for more information about modifying the security on a custom object definition or custom object instance.

**Parent page:** [Custom Objects](GUID-582E4F75-420D-4B77-8433-D41EBC041317.htm)


## Vault Office Client

# Vault Office Client

The Vault Office client is similar to the Vault client, but provides only non-CAD file and folder data management options.

The Vault Office client cannot be [installed](tpicid=GUID-508F607E-BEFA-4E79-82B5-6A1BBFBD3DBC) on the same machine as a full Vault Professional client.

## Who Should Use the Vault Office client?

The Vault Office client is ideal for users who do not need all of the CAD functionality of a full Vault client, but who still need to manage documents in a vault. For example, non-design engineers and project managers, employees on the shop floor, and sales personnel could all use the Vault Office client to fulfill these responsibilities:

* Review and validate design data
* Participate in the change process
* Manage project data
* Communicate with external team members
* Create reports
* Consume released design data
* Manage additional non-CAD data and custom objects.

You can preview files using the View tab if dwf exist for these files and "Inventor Read-Only Mode" is selected in Vault Options. If the files don't have dwf, you can only view files in Inventor in the Inventor Read-only mode using the "Open" button in the View tab or "View in Window..." command in the context menu. If files have dwf, but "Always use Inventor Read-Only Mode" is selected in Options, you can only view files in Inventor Read-only mode.

You can also configure the default behavior for double-clicking a file with the Invoke with double-click setting changed to View in Window in the Options.

## Tasks Users Can Perform with the Vault Office client

### File and Folder Tasks

* Create folders
* Move, Rename, and Delete non-CAD files
* Move, Rename, and Delete folders which do not contain CAD files
* Check in, check out, perform quick checkouts, and undo checkouts on non-CAD files
* Check in, check out, perform quick checkouts, and undo checkouts on folders

  Note: CAD files in the folder are not affected.
* Open non-CAD files
* Get/download non-CAD files
* Edit non-CAD file properties
* Edit folder properties
* Attach non-CAD files to CAD files
* Attach files to non-CAD files
* Detach files from non-CAD files
* Classify, categorize, change lifecycle definition, change state, and change revision on non-CAD files
* Classify, categorize, change lifecycle definition, and change state on folders
* Change state on CAD files
* Preview files before getting the files from the Vault. Use View in Window using Inventor Read-Only or use the Preview Tab.

### Custom Object Tasks

* Create Custom Object instances
* Classify, categorize, change lifecycle definition, change state, and change revision on custom objects
* Edit custom object properties

### Job Processor Tasks

* Update view using Queue Update
* Send jobs to the Job Processor

### Shortcuts and Links Tasks

* Create, edit, and delete links to folders and non-CAD files
* Create, modify, and delete links of non-CAD files and folders to custom objects

### Item Tasks

* Read item details (Bill of Materials, etc.)
* Change state on items

### Report Tasks

* Run reports on files, folders, items, and change orders
* Rerun reports on Bills of Materials (BOMs)
* Run reports on Custom Objects

### Change Order Tasks

* Created, edit, and participate in Change Orders

### General Tasks

* Go to working folder
* Access and create saved searches
* Enable custom utility for non-CAD files, folders, and custom objects


## Vault Thin Client

# Vault Thin Client

The Vault Thin Client provides read-only features for viewing and sharing Vault data in a web browser.

You can work with your vaulted data using the following features:

* View data associated with individual vault objects.
* Preview Autodesk Inventor files and other supported file types in the Viewer.
* View records and attachments in change orders.
* Switch between vaults in the Thin Client.
* Share links you can open in the Vault Client on desktop or in the Thin Client.
* Download copies of files directly to your computer.
* And more!

### Thin Client - Get Started

# Thin Client - Get Started

Learn the basics of the Vault Thin Client.

The Thin Client is a browser extension of the Vault Client designed for quickly viewing your vaulted data. To use the Thin Client, sign into your Vault database, installed on an [Autodesk Data Management Server Console](https://beehive.autodesk.com/community/service/rest/cloudhelp/resource/cloudhelpchannel/guidcrossbook/?p=VAULT&l=ENU&accessmode=live&v=2026&guid=GUID-5B413A05-3F67-4ADD-B207-7402635A83E9).

Note: You must have a data management server account to sign in. Contact your vault administrator for your account and server information.

## Vault Compatibility

The Thin Client is compatible with Vault Professional *only*. There is no subscription or license requirement for Thin Client.

## Browser Compatibility

Make sure your browser meets the Thin Client's requirements before signing in. Consult the [System Requirements](https://knowledge.autodesk.com/support/vault-products/troubleshooting/caas/sfdcarticles/sfdcarticles/system-requirements-for-autodesk-vault-products.html) to learn more about Thin Client browser compatibility.

## Sign in to the Thin Client

Sign in with your username and password. If an account has not been set up for you, contact your administrator.

Note: Your administrator can also import a Windows Active Directory account. With an Active Directory account, you can sign in using your Windows account credentials.

1. In the browser's address field, enter the URL for the Thin Client. The format for the Thin Client URL is http://*<servername>*/AutodeskTC/*<vaultname>*.

   1. *<servername>* represents either the IP address or the name of the computer hosting Autodesk Data Management Server. If you do not know the name of the server, consult your system administrator.
   2. *<vaultname>* represents the vault instance that you are accessing.

      You can switch to a different vault by selecting the vault in the sign in screen (step 2). The vault name in the URL changes upon selecting a vault.

      You can also change vaults in the [Thin Client interface](GUID-755B8891-AA7F-489B-8770-168D39C4941D.htm) after signing in to the Thin Client. If you do not know the name of the vault, consult your system administrator. .
2. You can choose a vault to connect from the list of all available vaults.
3. Enter your user credentials, depending on the authentication method:

   * **Autodesk Vault Account:** Enter the username and password for the Autodesk Data Management Server account assigned to you by your system administrator and click **Sign in to Vault**.

     Note: If the administrator has enforced a password policy and your current password does not meet the requirements, you will receive a prompt to change your Vault account password. Login via Thick Client or contact your administrator to change the Vault account password.
   * **Windows Authentication:** Click **Windows Account**, enter your Active Directory username and password in the window that appears, and then click **OK**.

   Note: Ensure you are logging into the Autodesk Data Management Server (ADMS). Logging into the Autodesk Vault File Store (AVFS) Server is currently not supported for Vault Thin Client.

## Sign out of the Thin Client

To sign out of the Thin Client:

1. Click the Profile icon ![](../images/icon-newthinclient-profile-small.png) in the upper right corner of the page.
2. Click **Sign Out**.

**Parent page:** [Vault Thin Client](GUID-A394FD9E-88EB-4592-B6F9-B41D31C14F7D.htm)


### Thin Client - The Interface

# Thin Client - The Interface

Learn how to use the Thin Client interface.

## Navigation Bar

The navigation bar contains several icons at the top of the window. It also contains a search bar. For information on searching, see [Search Bar](#search-bar) below.

* **Vault Selector**: ![](../images/icon-newthinclient-vault-selector.png)

  Displays a list of available vaults.

  To switch to a different vault:

  1. Click the Vault Selector, indicated by the current server/vault name.
  2. Select one of the vaults displayed.
  3. Click **Confirm** to change vaults. You must sign in again before you can access the selected vault.
* **Help Icon**: ![](../images/icon-newthinclient-help.png)

  Displays a menu containing the following options:

  + Help and Support: Opens the Autodesk Knowledge Network help for Vault.
  + About: Displays current version information for the Thin Client.
  + Contact Us: Opens the Vault Products Feedback Forum, where you can communicate directly with Autodesk about Vault software.
* **Notification Icon**: ![](../images/icon-newthinclient-notifications.png)

  Displays unread notifications. When you have a new notification, a badge appears on the icon.

  Click the notification icon to view download progress.
* **Profile Icon**: ![](../images/icon-newthinclient-profile-small.png)

  Displays logged in user's initials.

  The profile icon displays the user initials based on the following behavior:

  + If the first name and last name fields are available in Vault, the profile icon displays the first letter from first name and last name.
  + If only the first name field is available in Vault, the profile icon displays the first letter from first name only. If only the last name field is available in Vault, the profile icon displays the first letter from last name only.
  + If both the first name and last name are not available in Vault, the profile icon displays the first letter from display name.

  It includes the following options:

  + Settings: Displays [settings](GUID-3C037673-084A-4C1F-B1DA-E1283EF1281D.htm) for viewing data in the Thin Client.
  + Sign out: Ends your session in the Thin Client and signs out the current account.

## Workspace Navigation

![](../images/icon-newthinclient-workspace-pane.png)

The Workspace Navigation pane, to the left of the Thin Client interface, contains three icons. Each icon represents one of the Vault object types that you can work with in the Thin Client: files, items, and change orders.

Click a Workspace icon to display that workspace. If a workspace contains folders, you can navigate the folder tree by clicking folder names in the Workspace Navigation pane.

## Search Bar

The search bar searches in the current workspace.

To learn more about searching in the Thin Client, view [Thin Client - Search the Vault](GUID-D44E6840-2CF2-4A78-A576-E7F6245279AD.htm).

## Data Tables

Click an object or a folder in the data table of a workspace to display its contents and to view more details.

![](../images/icon-newthinclient-actions.png)

A checkbox displays to the left of the items in a data table. Select a checkbox to display icons at the top of the table. Each icon represents an action available for that type of object. To learn more, see [Thin Client - Work with Vault Data.](GUID-B363C783-FEA4-479E-9F97-1D0A8DD0C1E0.htm)

## Properties Panel

The properties panel shows the properties associated with an object in the vault.

Click the Properties Panel icon ![](../images/icon-newthinclient-properties-panel.png) to open the panel. Select an object to display its properties.

Tip: Hover over the edge of the thin client property panel to resize it and save the setting.

## Full View vs. Paged View

Click the view icon ![](../images/icon-thin-client-fullview.png) to toggle between full and paged views to load and display data.

Tip: Hover your mouse over the icon to see the current settings.

## Show/Hide Folders

Click the Show/Hide Folders icon ![](../images/icon-showhidefolders.png) to expand or collapse the folder view in the Files workspace.

With this option, you can hide the folders in the main data table that aren't relevant or make them show when required. You don't need to scroll through all the folders in the main data table to view specific files or folders. You can still navigate through the folder tree navigation in the left panel.

## Details View

Every object in the vault has specific data and relationships associated with it.

Click the object's name (the value in the Name column) to open its details view. See the following topics for information on each type of object's details view:

* [Thin Client - Files](GUID-0213EC9E-C7A6-4662-9197-51D8EB9234B2.htm)
* [Thin Client - Items](GUID-FF8CA8D4-D13B-42B2-9436-8AF3B028A76A.htm)
* [Thin Client - Change Orders](GUID-E4E18888-CD2A-422C-9A1A-A8A0668A54CC.htm)

**Expand/Collapse Rows**

Expand or collapse rows in a tree view. This functionality is available in the File (Uses and Where Used tabs) and Items (Where Used and BOM) details page.

To expand/collapse all rows:

* Click the Collapse all icon in the tree view action bar to collapse all the rows.

  Note: If the child rows weren't previously collapsed, they will appear in their previously-expanded state. Using "Collapse all" ensures that all rows appear in a collapsed state.
* Click the Expand all icon in the tree view action bar to expand the collapsed rows (parent-rows-with-children) so that all rows are displayed in a tree view.

![](../images/thinclient-expandcollapseall-icons.png)

**Expand all Children/Collapse all Children**

To expand the collapsed rows in a tree view:

* Hover over the parent row and click the ellipses icon (…).
* Select "Expand all Children" to display all the rows.

Similarly, to collapse the expanded rows, hover over the parent row and select the ellipses icon (…) to select "Collapse all Children".

![](../images/thinclient-expandcollapseallchildren.png)

## The Viewer

The Thin Client displays files with viewable geometry in an integrated viewer.

To learn more about using the Viewer, see [Thin Client - Work with Vault Data.](GUID-B363C783-FEA4-479E-9F97-1D0A8DD0C1E0.htm)

**Parent page:** [Vault Thin Client](GUID-A394FD9E-88EB-4592-B6F9-B41D31C14F7D.htm)


### Thin Client - Files

# Thin Client - Files

Learn how to find files and view file details in the Thin Client.

## The Files Workspace

The Files workspace displays files and documents in your vault.

Folders in the Files workspace organize data in nested levels. A breadcrumb trail, displayed above the data table, represents the location of the current folder. Click a folder name in the breadcrumb trail to view its contents.

Files are listed in a data table. Click the Configure Columns icon ![](../images/icon-newthinclient-configure-columns-small.png) to modify the column headers in the Files workspace. You can re-order or add user- and system-defined headers to the data table in the Configure Columns drop-down menu. The default order contains headers for the following data:

* Name (required)
* State
* Revision
* Category Name
* Checked Out By
* Vault Status

## File Details

The file details view contains several tabs that display file information and viewing functions. The following tabs are available in the details view of a file:

* Properties Tab
* History Tab
* Uses Tab
* Where Used Tab
* Item Tab
* Change Order Tab
* View Tab

To view the details of a file:

1. Select the Files workspace in the navigation panel.
2. Navigate the folder tree to find your file. You can click folders in the workspace navigation pane or in the data table. Alternatively, you can [search the vault](GUID-D44E6840-2CF2-4A78-A576-E7F6245279AD.htm) to find the file with the search bar.
3. Click the file name in the data table.

**Parent page:** [Vault Thin Client](GUID-A394FD9E-88EB-4592-B6F9-B41D31C14F7D.htm)


### Thin Client - Items

# Thin Client - Items

Learn how to find items and view item details in the Thin Client.

## The Items Workspace

The Items workspace displays items in your vault.

Items are listed in a data table. Click the Configure Columns icon ![](../images/icon-newthinclient-configure-columns-small.png) to modify the column headers in the Items workspace. You can re-order or add user- and system-defined headers to the data table in the Configure Columns drop-down menu. The default order contains headers for the following data:

* Name (required)
* State
* Revision
* Vault Status
* Category Name
* Title (Item, CO)

## Item Details

The item details view contains several tabs that display item information. The following tabs are available in the details view of an item:

* Properties Tab
* History Tab
* Bill of Materials Tab

  + The BOM view supports Multi-Level and Parts Only views.
  + To change the BOM view, click the view icon (either ![](../images/icon-newthinclient-multilevelbom.png) or ![](../images/icon-newthinclient-partsonlybom.png), depending on the current view) in the upper-right corner of the table.
* Where Used Tab
* Associated Files Tab
* Change Order Tab

Note: In the Administrator Settings dialog, if the **Show released files only** option is toggled on, for an item, the associated files in released and non-released state are displayed in the "Associated Files" tab.

To view the details of an item:

1. Select the Items workspace in the navigation panel.
2. Scroll through the items list to find your item. Alternatively, you can [search the vault](GUID-D44E6840-2CF2-4A78-A576-E7F6245279AD.htm) to find the item using the search bar.
3. Click the item name in the data table.

To view the associated files details:

1. In the Associated Files tab, hover over the file and select the Ellipsis icon of the file.

   * Download: Download a local copy of a file from the vault.
   * Share: Generate a link that you or others can open in the Vault Client or Thin Client.
   * Update Visualization: Update Visualization to get the latest DWF of a CAD file.
   * View Details: View the details of a file.
2. Click on the file name to view the file with the Viewer. The file will open in a new tab in the browser.

**Parent page:** [Vault Thin Client](GUID-A394FD9E-88EB-4592-B6F9-B41D31C14F7D.htm)


### Thin Client - Change Orders

# Thin Client - Change Orders

Learn how to find change orders and view change order details in the Thin Client.

## The Change Orders Workspace

The Change Orders workspace displays change orders in your vault.

Change Orders are listed in a data table. Click the Configure Columns icon ![](../images/icon-newthinclient-configure-columns-small.png) to modify the column headers in the Change Orders workspace. You can re-order or add user- and system-defined headers to the data table in the Configure Columns drop-down menu. The default order contains headers for the following data:

* Number (required)
* State
* Due Date
* Vault Status
* Title (Item,CO)
* Number of File Attachments

## Change Order Details

The change order details view contains several tabs that display change order information.

To view the details of a change order:

1. Select the Change Orders workspace in the navigation panel.
2. Scroll through the change orders list to find your change order. Alternatively, you can [search the vault](GUID-D44E6840-2CF2-4A78-A576-E7F6245279AD.htm) to find the change order using the search bar.
3. Click the change order number in the data table.

The following tabs are available in the details view of a change order:

* Properties Tab
* Records Tab
* Attachments Tab

## Customize the Change Order View

You can filter the view to only show change orders that are in Open state (Create, Open, Work, Review, Approved, Rejected) or select All States to list all change orders including Closed or Cancelled states.

![](../images/filter-states-changeorders.jpg)

To customize the change order view:

1. Click the filter icon in the upper right corner of the Change Orders workspace.
2. Select the "Open States" or "All States" filter. If the Open States filter is selected, all change orders in Closed or Cancelled state are hidden from the view.

   Note: The Open States include all change orders that are in Create, Open, Work, Review, Approved, and Rejected. All States include change orders in Open state as well as in Closed or Cancelled states.

By default, the Open States filter is selected.

**Parent page:** [Vault Thin Client](GUID-A394FD9E-88EB-4592-B6F9-B41D31C14F7D.htm)


### Thin Client - The Viewer

# Thin Client - The Viewer

The Thin Client includes a browser version of the viewer, Autodesk's tool for exploring, examining, and reviewing the contents of CAD files.

The Thin Client viewer implements the same controls and features as the viewer available in the Vault Client.

For a detailed description of viewer functions, view the topic [View a File](https://beehive.autodesk.com/community/service/rest/cloudhelp/resource/cloudhelpchannel/guidcrossbook/?p=VAULT&l=ENU&accessmode=live&v=2026&guid=GUID-B5B204B1-5219-4EA2-AC58-5E20F375E345).

To open the viewer in the Thin Client:

1. Select the Files workspace in the navigation panel.
2. Navigate the folder tree to find your file. You can click folders in the workspace navigation pane or in the data table. Alternatively, you can [search the vault](GUID-D44E6840-2CF2-4A78-A576-E7F6245279AD.htm) to find the file with the search bar.
3. Do one of the following:

   * Select the file by clicking, or tapping on touchscreen devices, the checkbox to the left of the file name. The file is selected when its checkbox is marked. Select the View icon ![](../images/icon-newthinclient-view-small.png) above the data table.

     Note: You can select multiple files to open at once.
   * Hover over a row and select the Ellipsis icon of the file. Select View to open the file in the browser.

     Note: On touch screen devices, tap a row to the right of the file name to reveal the Ellipsis icon.
   * Hover over a row and select the Ellipsis icon of the file. Select View Details and select the View tab to open the viewer.

If a file's visualization needs to be updated, select Update Visualization. See Update File Visualization in the topic [Thin Client - Work with Vault Data](thin-client-work-with-vault-data.html#update-file-visualization).

You can view the image file on the View tab directly without a need to download it. For non-design files, if the file extension is supported in the browser, you can open the file in the browser. Otherwise, the file is downloaded on the machine. The "Open File in Browser" command is available in the View tab on the file's details page.

![](../images/icon-openinbrowser-updatevisualization.png)

**Parent page:** [Vault Thin Client](GUID-A394FD9E-88EB-4592-B6F9-B41D31C14F7D.htm)


### Thin Client - Work with Vault Data

# Thin Client - Work with Vault Data

Share links to vaulted data, download files, view file contents, and more.

## Print a Page from the Thin Client

For information on viewing files, view the topic [Thin Client - Print](GUID-A8B9C67E-175B-4439-A1C0-A0F51688A8DE.htm).

## Display a File in the Viewer

For information on viewing files, view the topic [Thin Client - The Viewer](GUID-E7707879-4505-434A-AEAA-761794F720F2.htm).

## Download a File

When downloading multiple files at once, the Thin Client limits the download to 500 mb. Downloading files individually doesn't have a maximum limit.

To download a local copy of a file from the Vault:

1. Select the Files workspace in the navigation pane.
2. Navigate the folder tree to find your file. Select folders in the navigation pane or in the data table to view their contents. Alternatively, you can [search the vault](GUID-D44E6840-2CF2-4A78-A576-E7F6245279AD.htm) to find the file using the search bar.
3. Select the file name to view its details or select the checkbox to the left of the file name.

   Note: You can select multiple files to download at once.
4. Select the Download icon ![](../images/icon-newthinclient-download-small.png) to display a drop-down menu with the following options:

   1. Select **Download File** to download a local copy of the file.
   2. Select **Download Visualization File** to download a local DWF of the file.
5. Click the notification icon to view download progress. ![](../images/icon-newthinclient-notifications.png).

## Share a Link

To generate a link that you or others can open in the Vault Client or Thin Client:

1. Select a workspace in the navigation pane.
2. Navigate the data table to find the object to share. Alternatively, you can [search the vault](GUID-D44E6840-2CF2-4A78-A576-E7F6245279AD.htm) using the search bar.
3. Select the object name to view its details or select the checkbox to the left of the object name.

   Note: You can select multiple files to share at once.
4. Select the Share icon ![](../images/icon-newthinclient-share-small.png).
5. Select the Desktop Client tab or the Web Client tab in the Share window.

   Note: Links for the Vault Client and the Thin Client are not interchangeable. The type of link that you select can only be viewed in the specified client.
6. To share the link, use either of the following methods:

   * Enter an email address in the open field and select **Send**. An email is automatically generated by your computer's default email client.
   * Select **Copy Link** to copy the link to your clipboard.

## Update File Visualization

Visualization files can be updated so that the latest DWF of a CAD file is available. When a visualization file is updated, the job is sent to the job server for processing. The Update Visualization file command is only available if the job server is enabled and turned on.

1. Select the Files workspace in the navigation pane.
2. Hover over a row and select the Ellipsis icon ![](../images/icon-newthinclient-object-ellipses-small.png) of the file to update.

   Note: On touch screen devices, tap a row to the right of the file name to reveal the Ellipsis icon.
3. Select **Update Visualization** to send the job to the job processor.

   ![](../images/command-ellipses-updatevisualization.png)

   Alternatively, select the "Update Visualization" command available in the file's details page.

   ![](../images/command-updatevisualization.png)

## Sort Data Tables

Select a header in a data table to sort the table. Number-based fields sort numerically in ascending or descending order. Text-based fields sort alphabetically from A-Z or Z-A. Date-based fields sort from older to newer or newer to older.

## View Historical Versions and Revisions

In object details, select the **Latest / Latest Released** drop-down menu to browse and select historical versions or revisions. You can also select past versions in the History tab.

Version and revision apply when you share a link to the Thin Client. Links redirect to the version and revision selected in the drop-down menu/History tab.

## Filter Data in the History Tab

When you’re viewing file or item details, the History tab can be filtered. Select the Filter icon to the far right of the table header to display filter options. Filter options include Show Latest Versions Only and Show All Versions.

## Modify Data Table Headers

You can modify or rearrange the display order of headers and also add system-generated or user-generated properties to the header.

![](../images/thinclient-datatableheaders.png)

Note: If the Configure Columns icon ![](../images/icon-newthinclient-configure-columns-small.png) is not visible, it means that the default columns are enforced by the administrator.

To modify table headers:

1. Select the Configure Columns icon ![](../images/icon-newthinclient-configure-columns-small.png) in the far-right of the table header.
2. Select the properties that you want to display.
3. Click, or tap and hold on touchscreen devices, to drag a header and rearrange the display order. Press Ctrl or Shift to select multiple properties.
4. To hide a header, unselect the checkbox.

You can always return to the properties originally set by the administrator.

* Click Restore default order to set the last default order set by the administrator.

For administrators:

If you are an administrator, you can configure the required columns and enforce the same for all users. Once this is enforced, non-admin users can't change the default columns in Files, Items, Change Order, and Search workspace. Currently, admin defined headers are not enforced on the search workspace.

Note: Turn on Enforce admin default properties headers option under the Administrator Settings.

![](../images/thinclient-admin-enforcedefaultheaders.png)

To modify table headers:

1. Select the Configure Columns icon ![](../images/icon-newthinclient-configure-columns-small.png) in the far-right of the table header.
2. Select the properties that you want to display.
3. Click, or tap and hold on touchscreen devices, to drag a header and rearrange the display order. Press Ctrl or Shift to select multiple properties.
4. To hide a header, unselect the checkbox.
5. Click Set default.

You can always return to the properties originally set by the previous administrator or set by the system.

* Click Restore > Default order to set the last default order set by the administrator.
* Click Restore > System default order to set the system default properties header.

### Thin Client - Search

# Thin Client - Search

Search provides a quick and convenient way to locate files and folders.

## Search Bar

Click Search in the navigation bar to expand the search field.

![](../images/thinclient-searchfield.png)

The current workspace, indicated by the drop-down menu to the left of the search field, is automatically selected when you click the Search bar. Click the menu to select a different workspace.

![](../images/thinclient-searchoptions.png)

Note: Switching the workspace clears all existing search criteria and results.

The search "Find Latest Version Only" option in the Files and Items workspace depends on the "Show latest version of file/item only" option set under the Administrator Settings.

* If the "Show latest version of file/item" option is turned on in the Administrator Settings, the "Find Latest Version Only" search option is selected and disabled.
* If the "Show latest version of file/item" option is turned off in the Administrator Settings, you can select whether to enable or disable the "Find Latest Version Only" search option.

## Basic Search

Use Basic Search to look for any property that contains the search keyword. With Basic Search, you can search objects in different workspaces.

* **Files** - a basic search locates files and folders in the current folder and/or subfolders, and optionally, searches the latest version only.
* **Items** - a basic search locates only items, and optionally, searches the latest version only.
* **Change Orders** - a basic search locates only change orders.

To perform a basic search:

* Select the search workspace.
* Select the search option - Current folder and/or Include Subfolders or Find Latest Version Only. By default, the "Include Subfolders" option is selected.

  If the "Current Folder" option is deselected, the option "Include Subfolders" is deselected by default too.
* Enter your search string in the search input field and press enter.

![](../images/thinclient-basicsearchfield.png)

When a search is performed, the main view displays the results of the search. Click Clear to clear the search input field.

![](../images/thinclient-basicsearchresult.png)

## Advanced Search

Use Advanced Search to create complex queries with multiple search criteria.

You can search objects anywhere in a vault or in different workspaces using the advanced search criteria. By default, an advanced search is initiated in the workspace from where it is launched. For instance, if you are in the Items workspace and you perform the Advanced Search, the search returns results only from the Items workspace.

To perform an advanced search you need to specify a property, a condition, and a value. You can initiate the search either clicking Search in the navigation bar, or clicking on the "Advanced" text button located next to the search field.

To perform an advanced search:

* In the Advanced Search tab, select the search workspace from the "Search for" drop-down.

  ![](../images/thinclient-advancedsearchoptions.png)
* Specify the search criteria.
* Click ![](../images/icon-search-plus.png) to add criteria as needed.
* Click Search.

  ![](../images/thinclient-advancedsearchmultipleinput.png)

  The objects matching the search criteria display on the Search Results page. The search results remain displayed until another advanced search is performed.
* Click ![](../images/icon-search-crossmark.png) to delete individual search parameters or click Clear to delete all the search parameters.

You can also edit the existing search criteria.

To edit the search criteria:

* Select the search criteria to make it editable.
* Modify the search criteria as required, and click ![](../images/icon-search-checkmark.png).
* Click Search.

![](../images/thinclient-editsearch.png)

**Save Search Criteria**

You can add the advanced search with desired criteria to your bookmark in your web browser and reuse them quickly. Just click on the bookmark to find your selection again. This can be particularly useful for complex queries that you intend to use repeatedly.

![](../images/thinclient-savesearchbookmark.png)

**Expand/Collapse Search Panel**

You can expand or collapse the Advanced Search panel to suit your use. By default, the search panel is expanded.

* Click Collapse to hide the search parameters.
* Click Expand to select/view the search parameters.

![](../images/thinclient-advancedsearchcollapse.png)

Note: The search inputs and results are maintained when you switch between the Basic Search and Advanced Search tabs.

### Thin Client - Administrator Settings

# Thin Client - Administrator Settings

Administrators can customize display settings in the Thin Client.

To configure administrator settings:

1. Log into the Thin Client using an administrator account.
2. From the account menu, click Settings.

   **General**

   The **General** tab contains options for customizing the web interface by applying a custom logo. Additionally, you can restrict users from customizing the properties headers that are displayed in the Thin Client.

   **Application logo**

   You can choose to use the default Autodesk Vault Thin Client logo or upload your custom logo. This logo is displayed to the left of the application title bar.

   The logo must be in JPEG, SVG, or PNG format, with a file size no larger than 200 KB and a maximum resolution of 250x24 pixels.

   **Default Data Table Headers**

   Turn on the **Enforce admin default properties headers** option to restrict users from customizing which properties are displayed in the Thin Client. If this option is turned off, users will see the default properties but will be able to override the defaults and customize which properties are displayed.

   **Files**

   The **Files** tab contains options to modify the file workspace display settings.

   * Turn on **Hide file workspace** option to hide the file workspace.
   * Turn on **Make default landing page** to set file workspace as the default landing page.
   * Turn on **Show released files only** option to show only the released versions.
   * Turn on **Show latest version of file only** option to display only the latest versions of files. If this option is turned off, all versions of files are displayed.

   **Items**

   The **Items** tab contains options to modify the item workspace display settings.

   * Turn on **Hide item workspace** option to hide the item workspace.
   * Turn on **Make default landing page** to set item workspace as the default landing page.
   * Turn on **Show released items only** option to display only the released items.
   * Turn on **Show latest version of item only** option to display only the latest versions of items. If this option is turned off, all versions of items and item data are displayed.

   **Change Order**

   The **Change Order** tab contains options to modify the change order workspace display settings.

   * Turn on **Hide change order workspace** option to hide the change order workspace.
   * Turn on **Make default landing page** to set change order workspace as the default landing page.
3. Click OK to apply the settings.

**Parent page:** [Vault Thin Client](GUID-A394FD9E-88EB-4592-B6F9-B41D31C14F7D.htm)


### Thin Client - Print

# Thin Client - Print

Print data tables and object details in the Thin Client.

To print a page from the Thin Client:

1. Select a workspace (files,-items,-or-change-orders). Alternatively, you can [search the vault](Thin-Client-Search.htm) using the search bar.
2. To print the data table in your current workspace:

   1. Modify the table as necessary. The page will print as it appears in your browser.
   2. Select the Print icon ![](../images/icon-newthinclient-print.png) in the upper-right corner of the page.
   3. Follow your browser's instructions to print the page.
3. To print the details of a specific object:

   1. Select the object name to view its details.
   2. Select the tab you want to print (e.g.,-history,-bill-of-materials,-etc).
   3. Select the Print icon ![](../images/icon-newthinclient-print.png) in the upper-right corner of the page. The page will print all rows, irrespective of whether they are expanded or collapsed.
   4. Follow your browser's instructions to print the page.

You can extract data from the Thin Client to an Excel spreadsheet for your reference.

To copy the data to the Excel spreadsheet:

1. On the Files, Items, or Change Orders details tab, click the Print icon.

   A preview of the tab is displayed.
2. Select the rows to copy the data to the Excel spreadsheet. If you are copying items, select BOM levels to include BOM levels in the print preview.

   The values copied and pasted to the Excel spreadsheet preserves the Thin Client layout.
3. Click Cancel on the print preview window once copied.

![](../images/print-datatoexcel.jpg)

## Vault Add-ins

# Vault Add-ins

Autodesk Vault integrates with your design software using an add-in. The add-in brings the basic file management functionality of Autodesk Vault into the designer's environment.

Note: Refer to the [Supported Vault Add-ins](https://beehive.autodesk.com/community/service/rest/cloudhelp/resource/cloudhelpchannel/guidcrossbook/?p=VAULT&l=ENU&accessmode=live&v=2026&guid=GUID-334CC890-1F12-429C-9D6A-B964327CA590) table for a complete list of products that integrate with Vault.

Autodesk Vault manages all your design and engineering files, regardless of the file type. Files can be Autodesk Inventor, AutoCAD, Revit, Moldflow, 3Ds Max, Microsoft Office, or any other file used in a design's lifecycle. You can organize all of your files and keep them in one location for easy access. All file versions are retained, so you never misplace or replace past versions. The vault stores each version of a file, along with all the file's dependencies, giving you a living history of the project as you work on it. The vault also stores file properties such as the user name, date, and comments for rapid searching and retrieving.

In a design team, all the files and associated data are stored on the server so all users have access to the information and its history. Each member of a team must have a unique login name and password. Team members check out files to prevent more than one member from editing the same file at the same time. Once a file is checked back into the vault, team members can refresh their local copies of the model file to get the latest version from the vault, so all members of the design team work together.

### AutoCAD Vault Add-in

# AutoCAD Vault Add-in

Learn about the AutoCAD Vault Add-in.

Autodesk Vault integrates with AutoCAD and AutoCAD Mechanical software using an AutoCAD Vault ARX application.

Note: Vault commands are not supported in SDI (single-document) mode. The SDI system variable must be set to '0' for vault commands to be supported.

Autodesk Vault is both a server and a client interface.

* The server provides the following:

  + **Centralized file store:** Autodesk Vault server stores the master copies of all your documents and designs and keeps the master copies of all user files in a common, secure, and centralized location. By storing all of your data in a common, centralized location, you can easily share and manage all of your information with your design team. The files are stored on the server in such a way that they can be easily retrieved using the server console. However, this file store can reside on a different drive or even on a completely different server from the vault database.
  + **Relational database:** Autodesk Vault server contains a database that stores data about the files, such as file names, user names, properties, versions, and relationships between files. The database is managed using the server console.
  + **Access and information:** The Autodesk Vault Server software provides users with access to their files and maintains information about the status of those files including which users have permission to change and update the files. When changes are made to files Autodesk Vault maintains a version history of all changes and provides a convenient mechanism for users to gain access to the latest versions as well as previous versions.
* The client consists of two components:

  + **Autodesk Vault:** Autodesk Vault is a stand-alone client providing full access to the vault. This is the user interface for managing all data within the vault.
  + **AutoCAD Vault ARX:** This is a tool that performs many of the same vault tasks as Autodesk Vault within AutoCAD and AutoCAD Mechanical.

#### Autodesk Vault and AutoCAD Vault ARX

# Autodesk Vault and AutoCAD Vault ARX

Autodesk Vault software is a client-server application. In a typical installation, you install the server portion of the software on a shared computer, and then install the client software (Autodesk Vault and AutoCAD Vault ARX) on individual workstations. During installation, you have the option to install each of the components required for each workstation and, when applicable, for each server.

The vault server stores and maintains the files and metadata that make up the vault. The server software can be installed on a server or workstation that is shared by all users or, for a single user, the server can be installed along with the client on a single, isolated workstation. The database is managed by the server console.

The vault client consists of autodesk-vault-and-autocad-vault-arx. The client is installed on all workstations that need to access the vault.

## Key Concepts for AutoCAD Vault ARX

The essential rules to remember when working with AutoCAD Vault ARX are:

1. The files in the vault are the master files.
2. You must check a file out of the vault to modify it.
3. To check out a file for editing you must use the working folder on the local disk. Each user can optionally set a local working folder (physical-location-on-disk) for the root of the vault or use the default working folder (My Documents\Vault).

## AutoCAD Vault ARX for AutoCAD and AutoCAD Mechanical

AutoCAD Vault ARX is tightly integrated into AutoCAD and AutoCAD Mechanical. You can perform vault tasks using the AutoCAD Menus, command line, or the External References palette for files containing xrefs.

Check out and check in capabilities prevent more than one user from editing a file at one time, so all members of the design team to work together. In host files containing Xrefs, you can view the status of vaulted files displayed by icons and properties in the External References palette. The status icons in the External References palette keep all members of the design team informed of the status of files.

Note: Vault commands are not supported in SDI (single-document) mode. The SDI system variable must be set to '0' for vault commands to be supported.

AutoCAD Vault ARX understands the relationship between a host file, and all files that it references so you can manage all files in a model within the External References palette.

## AutoCAD Vault ARX for AutoCAD Electrical

AutoCAD Vault ARX is tightly integrated into AutoCAD Electrical. You can perform vault tasks using the AutoCAD Menus, command line, or Project Manager.

AutoCAD Vault ARX understands the relationship between a project file, and all files that it references so you can manage all files in a model within the Project Manager. The AutoCAD Electrical project file (\*.wdp) lists all drawing files included in the project. The drawing file names are maintained with relative paths from the location of the project definition file. When you make a change in one drawing, all files related to that drawing are automatically updated as well. To maintain the relationship between the drawing files that are defined in the project file you must check out all files specified in a project file when you need to modify one or more files.

Check out and check in capabilities prevent more than one user from editing a file at one time, so all members of the design team work together. The Project vault commands do not require that the selected project is active; it only needs to be open in the current Project Manager.

**Parent page:** [AutoCAD Vault Add-in](GUID-5467B425-EF8D-4C75-A289-92154CAC9E09.htm)


#### About Inventor Link File and Autodesk Vault

# About Inventor Link File and Autodesk Vault

When an Inventor Link File is checked into the vault, the associated IPT file or IAM file is linked to the Inventor Link File (DWG) in AutoCAD Mechanical.

In Autodesk Vault , the Uses and Where Used tab display the parent/child relationship between the Autodesk Inventor IPT or IAM file and the Inventor Link file.

The following is a list of best practices to follow when working with Inventor Link files:

* The Autodesk Inventor files must be checked into the vault before creating an Inventor Link file.
* When working with a vault, you must have a copy of the Autodesk Inventor part or assembly file located in your working folder to create a link between an Inventor Link File and the part or assembly file. Copy the Autodesk Inventor part or assembly file to your working folder by performing a Refresh From Vault in Autodesk Explorer.
* In AutoCAD Mechanical , select the application menu ![](../images/icon-appmenu-acad-2014.png) .
* Next, select the New Inventor Link file. Select the part file from your working folder.

  Save the Inventor Link file to the same working folder the part files reside in.
* In AutoCAD Mechanical, save the Inventor Link file and then check it into the vault after saving the file.

Checking the Inventor Link file into the vault allows the vault to manage the relationship between the Autodesk Inventor file and the Inventor Link file.

For detailed help on how to create and update an Inventor Link file, see the AutoCAD Mechanical Help.

**Parent page:** [AutoCAD Vault Add-in](GUID-5467B425-EF8D-4C75-A289-92154CAC9E09.htm)


#### Attach from Vault in AutoCAD

Applies to 2018.2 Update and later

# Attach from Vault in AutoCAD

Use Attach from Vault to reuse and share files.

Browse through the vault and select a file, or group of files, to attach to the current drawing. The resulting attachment is a library or shared file. A file not attached from the library folder is a shared file. Only image, Inventor models, dwg, dgn, dwf, and dwfx files can be attached. You must check the host file out of the vault to attach a file from the vault.

You must be logged into the vault to attach a file from the vault.

|  |  |
| --- | --- |
| *Access:* | Use one of the following methods to attach a file to a vault:   * In the Autodesk Vault ribbon, click the Attach from Vault button. * At the command line type *vltattach* and press Enter.   Note: You must be logged into the vault to attach files to the vault. |

|  |  |
| --- | --- |
| *Look in* | Shows path of the active directory. |
| *Find* | Displays the Find dialog so you can search for any file in the vault. |
| *Locations* | Shows the top-level of the current vault database as the root. Navigate to the file you want to open. |
| *File list* | The main window shows folders defined in the active vault. Double-click a folder to show the files it contains, and then navigate to the file you want to open. |
| *File name* | Specifies the file to open, enter a file name, or select a file from the listed files. |
| *Files of type* | Filters file list to include only files of a specific type. Click the arrow to show list, and then highlight to select a file type. |
| *Revision*  Note:  Available in Autodesk Vault Professional. | Specifies the revision of the file to open. |
| *Released Biased*  Note: Available in Autodesk Vault Professional. | Indicates that the related files downloaded should be the released versions in the revision. |
| *Open options (AutoCAD and AutoCAD Electrical)* | Click the down arrow next the Open button to select an Open option. |
|  | *Open (Check Out)* Checks out the file you selected. |
|  | *Open (Check Out All)* Checks out the file you selected and all xrefs.  Note:  In Autodesk Vault Professional, the Check Out All option is disabled if any children of the selected files may not be the latest revision. |
|  | *Open Read Only* Opens the file you selected in read-only mode. |
| *Open options (AutoCAD Mechanical)* | *Open* Automatically attaches the item as a part reference.  *Open (Attach Primary File)* Attaches the file associated with the selected item as an Xref.  *Open (Create Part Reference)* Attaches an item as a Part Reference. When an item is placed as a part reference, the name (number) of the item is used as the name of the Part Reference in the BOM. If the same item is placed multiple times as a Part Reference, as long as the name and GUPI fields have the same values, the item is consolidated and rolled up. |
| *Cancel* | Cancels the file open operation and closes the dialog box. |

## Attach a File from Vault

Note: You cannot have two or more files with the same name in the same folder.

1. Select Attach from the Autodesk Vault ribbon.
2. In the Select File dialog box, locate and select one or more files to attach to the active drawing. To select multiple drawing files to attach, select the **Files of Type: Drawing (\*.dwg)** and use the Ctrl or Shift key. Multiple selection is not supported for other file types.

   Note: Insertion of Inventor models requires a download of the Inventor project file from the vault. This project file is specified within the [Vault Settings dialog](https://beehive.autodesk.com/community/service/rest/cloudhelp/resource/cloudhelpchannel/guidcrossbook/?p=VAULT&l=ENU&accessmode=live&v=2026&guid=GUID-B2E77991-E8BA-41D3-83C8-565510F3C9D1) in the Vault client.
3. Select the revision of the file from the Revision drop-down.

   Note: The Revision feature is available in Autodesk Vault Professional.
4. Select whether you want to check out one of the files, all of the files, or attach a read only version from the Open drop-down.

   The file is attached to the current open file in the CAD application.

## Attach an Item from Vault

Note: This feature is available only in AutoCAD Mechanical.

Attach files associated with items as Xrefs, or attach the item itself as a part reference.

1. Select Attach from the Autodesk Vault ribbon.
2. In the Select File dialog box, locate and select an item to attach to the current open file.
3. Select Open (Attach Primary File) to attach the file associated with the item as an Xref.
4. Select Open (Create Part Reference) to attach the item itself as a part reference.

#### Check In Settings

# Check In Settings

Configure your Check In settings to control how files are stored in a vault.

File Structure options provide a great deal of flexibility when it comes to reorganizing and rearranging files so that they are added to the vault in a vault-friendly manner.

Note: You cannot have two or more files with the same name in the same folder.

|  |
| --- |
| *Access:* |
|  | In the Check In dialog box, click the Settings button. |

These settings determine how files will be added to the vault and are only available the first time files are added to the vault.

Once the files are checked into the Vault in a manner specified below, anyone checking out those files brings this same structure down to their local working folder.

|  |  |
| --- | --- |
| *Use organized folder structure* | The root folder is the top level folder within a hierarchical folder tree. The folder structure is maintained for all folders that are at the same level or beneath the host file. All referenced files and folders existing outside the directory tree of the Host are brought into a single folder under the host. |
| *Place all files in one folder* | All xrefs and dependent files are flattened so that they exist at the same level as the host. All the files are located under the vault folder. |
| *Preserve locations if in working folder* | Maintains the file structure of files being checked in from the local working folder. As a best practice, always work within the working folder and preserve the file locations. |
| *Create Visualization Attachment* | Creates and attaches a visualization file to the design file being checked in. |
| *Apply to All Files* | Creates a visualization file attachment for all files being checked in. This option must be turned on to create visualization files for children. |
| *Include* | Indicates which of the following tabs to include in the visualization file:   * Model Tab Only * Layout Tab Only * Model and Layout Tabs * <Use Default Vault Settings> - use the settings specified on the Publish Options dialog in the vault client. |

#### Context Menu Options for the AutoCAD Vault Add-in

# Context Menu Options for the AutoCAD Vault Add-in

The context menu options are accessed from the selected node in the File Reference pane or from the background menu of the External References palette window.

The type of node selected and status of the selected node determines which commands are available.

|  |  |
| --- | --- |
| *Open* | Opens selected file in a new AutoCAD window. |
| *Attach* | Attaches a new instance of the selected file node reference into the current drawing. If the host file is not yet checked out, you are prompted to check out the file before the new reference is attached.  Note: The newly attached files are not automatically added to the vault. You must check in the newly added file reference into the vault for it to be added as a dependency of the host file. |
| *Attach from Vault* | Use to reuse and share files. Browse through the vault and select a file to attach to the current drawing. The resulting attachment is a library or shared file. The term Library File appears in the tooltip after the file name for the file that is attached from a library folder in the vault. A file not attached from the library folder is a shared file. Only image and drawing files can be attached. You must check the host file out of the vault to attach a file from the vault. |
| *Unload* | Unloads the selected file reference from memory. Unloading a file results in the drawing opening faster and using less memory. The xref definition is unloaded from the drawing file, but the pointer to the reference drawing remains. |
| *Reload* | Updates the xrefs in the current drawing. You can cancel the download by clicking the Cancel button on the progress dialog box. |
| *Detach* | Detaches selected file reference from the current file. You must check out the host file out of the vault to remove it as a file reference. |
| *Bind* | Embeds an externally referenced file into the drawing file so that it is no longer an xref. If you bind an xref into the current drawing, the xref and all its dependent named objects become a part of the current drawing. You must check the host file out of the vault to use this command. If the local copy of the xref is older than the version in the vault, you are prompted to get the latest version. |
| *Check In* | Adds a file to the vault and creates a new version of the file. |
| *Check Out* | Reserves and locks the master file. Retrieves an updated copy, if necessary. |
| *Undo Checkout* | Removes the reservation/lock from the master file. The master file is now available for others to check out. Any modifications made to the local copy are not checked back into the vault. |
| *Refresh from Vault* | Gets the correct version of the drawing from the vault and then reloads the file. |
| *Refresh All Files from Vault* (AutoCAD Electrical only) | Gets the correct version of all project drawings from the vault and then reloads the files. |
| *Get Revision*  (Available in Autodesk Vault Professional) | Checks out a specific revision of the file and copies it to the local folder. |
| *Change State*  (Available in Autodesk Vault Professional) | Modifies a file or group of files' lifecycle state to enforce certain process behaviors. |
| *Revise*  (Available in Autodesk Vault Professional) | Creates a new revision of a file or selected group of files. |
| *Show Details* (Available in Autodesk Vault Professional) | View information from vault about designs and perform vault tasks. |
| *Go to Vault Folder* (Available in Autodesk Vault Professional) | Go to a file directly in vault from within AutoCAD. |

#### Extracting File Properties

# Extracting File Properties

When a DWG is added to a vault, the property values in the DWG Property dialog box are automatically extracted from the file and stored in the vault database.

Note: When dealing with block attributes containing multi-line text, you can map into the vault only. Properties do not retain multi-line text formatting when extracted from the vault. Furthermore, when the property is written back to the title block it will not retain multi-line text formatting.

The property values in attributed blocks can also be extracted by adding the name of the attributed block to the Index Block Attributes dialog box in the server console.

Note: Only the property values in the first instance of an attributed block are extracted.

Extracting these properties makes the following available in Autodesk Vault:

* Quick reference to properties associated with the file: You can choose these properties to appear as columns.
* File sorting capabilities based on those properties: You can sort or group the data by their property value.
* Advanced file searching based on properties or file content: You can search the vault for specific file content.

A thumbnail image of the DWG file is also extracted. In Autodesk Vault you can customize your view to display any of these properties, including the thumbnail image.

Note: The RASTERPREVIEW variable must be set to 1 to extract the thumbnail image.

## Procedures

**Extract Block Attribute Properties**

Use the Index Block Attributes command in the server console to extract the property data within attributed blocks. Extracting this data, allows this information to be available to you within Autodesk Vault. You can add this data as a property field and search for files containing data within an attributed block that you have added within the server console.

Note: You must have an attributed block in a file that has been checked into the vault to extract this data.

1. In the server console, from the Tools menu, select Index Block Attributes.
2. In the Index Block Attributes dialog box, click New and enter the name of the attributed block whose properties you want to be made available in Autodesk Vault.
3. Click OK to complete the operation.

The property data within the attributed block is now available for display with Autodesk Vault. Refer to the Help in Autodesk Vault for more information on customizing and displaying fields.

**Parent page:** [AutoCAD Vault Add-in](GUID-5467B425-EF8D-4C75-A289-92154CAC9E09.htm)


#### Generate File Number

# Generate File Number

Automatic file numbering allows you to easily organize your files with systematic naming schemes.

Note: This feature is available for the AutoCAD and AutoCAD Mechanical Vault Add-ins.

When you are logged into a vault and enact the Save As function for a file, you can have the system automatically append a set of predefined characters to the file name based on the scheme configured in the Autodesk Vault client. This feature allows you to enforce file naming conventions and prevents duplicate file names from being created.

The default scheme is Sequential. Use this scheme to number files sequentially. Other numbering schemes can be designed in the Autodesk Vault client. See the Autodesk Vault client help for more information.

## Generate File Number

To generate a file number for a new file, a numbering scheme must be enabled in the Autodesk Vault client. You must also be logged into a vault before performing the Save As function.

Note: Refer to the Autodesk Vault client for more information.

1. Make sure you are logged into a vault.
2. Save the file for the first time or select the Application icon and then select Save As.

   The Generate File Number dialog opens.
3. Select the numbering scheme that you want to use from the Scheme drop-down menu.
4. Change any values in the free text Number fields or select existing options from a list.
5. Click Save to save the file with the new name.

#### Learn about the External References Palette with the AutoCAD Vault Add-in

# Learn about the External References Palette with the AutoCAD Vault Add-in

You can perform most vault tasks within the External References palette when you are logged into a vault.

You can manage the relationships between a host file and its xrefs in the vault. Standard xref operations continue to be available. The AutoCAD Vault Add-in adds vault functionality to the External References palette.

When you install the Vault add-in, the External References palette becomes a dockable Enhanced Standard Window (ESW) that supports both drawing xrefs and image files in the same window. The External References palette supports most Vault operations and status icons. The Vault commands are only available when you are logged into a vault.

Note: The Vault commands are also available from the File menu and the command line.

## External References Palette Operations

The Vault commands are available by right-clicking a file within the External References palette. The state and kind of file selected determines which commands are available.

You can use the External References palette to:

* **Check files in and out of a vault**

  You must check out the file to the working folder on your local drive to edit it. When you finish working on the file, you must check the file back into the vault so that others on the design team can view your updates.

  Tip: If you want others to view updates you made to a file and you want to continue modifying the file, select the Keep files checked out option on the Check In dialog box. This checks in the updates you made to the file and keeps the file checked out to you.

  Note: You must have all references of a host file downloaded to your working folder to edit the host file.
* **View the status of files in a design.**

  Vault status icons indicate the status of your local copy of the files as compared against the copy of those same files in the vault. The vault status icons indicate when the local copy is in sync with the vault and when it is not. Tooltips provide descriptions of the icons. Pause the cursor over a status icon to see a detailed description. The tooltips also help guide you to the next logical steps, especially when the local copy is no longer in sync.

  Note: The vault status icons are available in the list view and treeview, and only appear when you are logged into a vault.
* **Get the latest version of a file**

  The Refresh Files command compares the local file version with the version in the vault. If the local version is older than the version in the vault, the latest version is copied from the vault to the local working folder and the current drawing is reloaded.
* **Reuse and share common data**

  Attach from the vault command attaches a new instance of a file from the vault. The instance can be attached as either a library file or a shared file.
* **Attach, Detach, Unload, Bind**

  All standard xref operations remain available in the External References palette. Although the behavior of these commands are the same as when you are not logged into the vault, the following additional operations are required:

  + **Attach:** You must check out the host file to attach a new file. Newly attached files are not automatically added to the vault. You must check in a newly added file references to the vault for it to be added as a dependency of the host file.
  + **Detach, Unload and Bind:** You must check out the host file to complete the operation.

  Note: Refer to Xrefs in the AutoCAD help topics index for information on standard Xref concepts.

## Library Files

Most organizations have either created or purchased a collection of part and assembly files that are commonly used in design, for instance, fasteners, electrical component, and pneumatic components. These library files are typically static in nature, are reused often in many different designs, and are standard within an organization.

You can attach a library file directly from the vault to your current drawing. A file becomes a library file by checking the file into a library folder in the vault.

Note: Only host library files can be checked out from the AutoCAD Vault ARX. You must use the Autodesk Vault client to check out XREF library files.

Library files are not identified by a particular icon. Instead, the term is inserted [Library File] in the tooltip after the file name.

Note: If the host file is a library item, the library icon will appear as the file type.

Access to vault folders depends upon the permissions you have been granted. You cannot see files or folders you do not have permission to view.

## Basic External Reference Palette Tasks

The behavior of the External References palette is the same when you are logged in to a vault as when you are not logged into a vault. Refer to "Xrefs" in the AutoCAD Help topics index for information on standard Xref concepts and procedures.

The workflow for using the External References palette on a system that has AutoCAD Vault ARX installed is different than the workflow for using External References palette on a system that does not have AutoCAD Vault ARX installed.

**Access the External References Palette**

Use the External References palette to perform most vault tasks. You must be logged into the vault to perform vault tasks in the External References palette.

Note: The External References palette and standard xref commands are available when you are not logged into the vault.

|  |

#### Sheet Set Manager Integration

# Sheet Set Manager Integration

Learn about the Sheet Set Manager Integration with Vault.

Note: Sheet Set Manager integration is only supported in Vault Professional.

A sheet set is an organized collection of sheets from several drawing files. A sheet is a selected layout from a drawing file.

Sets of drawings are the primary deliverable for most design groups. Sets of drawings communicate the overall design intent of a project and provide the documentation and specifications for the project. However, managing sets of drawings manually can be complicated and time consuming.

The Sheet Set Manager integration lets you store your sheets in a vault. You can also work on vaulted sheet sets online or offline.

## Who Can Work with Sheet Sets?

* Edit folder user-defined properties to check sheet sets into a vault
* File rename permission to rename and renumber sheet sets in the Sheet Set Manager
* File move permissions to move sheet sets in the Sheet Set Manager

## To Change the Sheet Set Automatic Check In Visualization Attachment Options

1. Exit AutoCAD.
2. Open the file ‘Preferences.xml’ at ‘%appdata%\Autodesk\AutoCAD [Version] Vault AddIn\Objects’ with any text editor.
3. Under the respective AutoCAD profile ‘CheckIn On Auto Checkin SheetSet Options’, look for .
4. Replace the default value, 'No DWF', with one of the following:

   * 'Create DWF locally' to create visualization during Check In
   * 'Create DWF using Job Server' to send to the Job Server

## Important Rules Regarding Sheet Set Behavior

There are a few rules regarding working with vaulted sheet sets.

* Any moves or rename events of sheet set data files (dss, dsu and dsh) in Vault Client are ignored when the changed sheet set is opened in SSM. To get the updated sheet set, perform an 'Open Sheet Set from Vault' on the affected sheet set. When the sheet set is downloaded, all changes are reflected.
* Only the leading, or tip, version of the current revision is retrieved when you Refresh from Vault from the Sheet Set Manager.

##### Understanding Sheet Sets and Vault

# Understanding Sheet Sets and Vault

Sheet Set Manager (SSM) integration allows you to check in sheet set data into vault, and utilizing Vault existing capabilities.

Once you start working on a Sheet Set in vault environment, there are some changes to how certain Sheet Set commands work.

## Resave All Sheets

When you work on a sheet set with vault, youa re working in a collaborative environment. When you resave all sheets, you will notice some differences when:

* Working in a shared sandbox environment, you can Resave All as long as none of the sheets/files involved is currently checked out by other users. The Resave All command will be aborted if there are files that cannot be checked out and, therefore, saved. A file may not be available for check out if it is currently checked out to another user or if vault constraints restrict access to the file.
* Working in a non-shared sandbox environment, you can Resave All even if some of the files are checked out by other users. You will get a list of files that are not available for saving when the sheet set command is completed.

## Remove Sheet or Sheet Subset

When you remove a sheet or subset from a vaulted sheet set, its equivalent vaulted copy will NOT be removed automatically. As a result, if you were to re-use the same sheet or sheet subset name, you will be informed that the files already exist in the Vault.

If the removed sheet or sheet subset files are expired or redundant, you may remove them via Vault Client.

Note: Historical references from sheets or sheet set files are lost when they are removed with Vault Client.

## Move, Rename, and Copy Design in the Vault Client\*\*

Move, Rename, and Copy Design changes made in the Vault Client are ignored when you open the edited sheet set in SSM.
