### Publish Files

# Publish Files

Configure lifecycle definitions and file options to publish CAD files.

Note: You must have administrative access to perform these tasks.

1. Create a user with access to Released files. See [Assign Roles to Users](GUID-AC787E21-D7D1-4FC9-B760-54D8BC614D38.htm) for more information.
2. Configure lifecycle definitions.

   1. Click Tools > Administration > Vault Settings.
   2. On the Vault Settings dialog, select Behaviors > Lifecycles.
   3. Select the definition to be modified > Edit.
   4. On the Lifecycle Definition dialog, select the Transitions tab > Work in Progress to Released > Edit.
   5. On the Transitions dialog, select the Actions tab.
   6. From the drop-down,

      * Select Synchronize properties and update the selected file types using Job Server.
      * Click on the ellipses (...) button and select the file type.

      Note: Selecting the option from the list does not automatically select the check box as well. Make sure to select the check box beside the option, too.
   7. From the Security tab, add the user created in Step 1, and allow Modify access under the Released state.
   8. On the Lifecycle Definition dialog, select Design Representation Process > Edit.
   9. On the Lifecycle Definition dialog, select the Released state.
   10. Select the Security tab, add the user created in Step 1 and assign it Modify access. See [Edit Lifecycle State Security](GUID-EEC9F632-6ED8-4671-8487-69436A0E1AD0.htm) for more information.

   Note: You can create PDF, DXF, or STEP file at any lifecycle state.

   Sync state job fails if you do not have adequate permission for a particular state to be set on a file, for example, you do not have the modify access on the Released state.
3. To enable the job server, click Tools > Administration > Global Settings > Integrations tab > Enable Job Server.

   Note: For Job Processor to generate DWF and 2D PDF files, launch AutoCAD DWG Trueview at least once on the Job Processor.
4. Click Tools > Administration > Vault Settings

   * PDF - PDF Options > Options to launch the PDF Options dialog and [configure the PDF publishing options](GUID-8EE12D8F-2381-4EE1-BAB0-D080F692500B.htm).
   * DXF - DXF Options > Options to launch the DXF Options dialog and [configure the DXF publishing options](GUID-57BC9F5B-FBAC-4003-80BA-8C7A352DD503.htm).
   * STEP - STEP Options > Options to launch the STEP Options dialog and [configure the STEP publishing options](GUID-BE2CA612-EB3A-40BE-ACB3-DB530E5926D2.htm).
5. Publish a PDF, DXF or STEP file from a CAD file.

   1. Select any AutoCAD DWG file or Inventor CAD file.
   2. Click Change Category. On the Change Category dialog, select the Engineering category. Click OK.
   3. Click Change State. On the Change State dialog, select Released from the lifecycle state drop-down. Click OK.

This generates a PDF, DXF, or STEP file as an attachment to the selected file. Also, a thumbnail for the file displays in the Preview tab.

Note: To synchronize the revisions of the drawing file and CAD file, set each file's lifecycle revision to be the same.

Note: To verify the Design Representation classification, click Tools > Administration > Vault Settings > Behaviors > Rules. On the Assignment Rules dialog, view the Rule Criteria for Design Representation.

## File Naming

You can affect the output file names by editing the Job Processor configuration file: JobProcessor.exe.config. The following are supported:

* Remove the source file's extension, such as .idw or .dwg, from the file name
* Add a prefix (static text)
* Add a suffix (static text)
* Add a property value
* Add a date property

1. Navigate to the <install dir>\Autodesk\Vault Client <year>\Explorer\ directory and open the JobProcessor.dll.config file with Notepad.

   Important: Create a backup copy of the file before making any changes.
2. Find the "<add key=>" section in the file.
3. Add a line using the format \*<add key="DesignRepresentation.Naming" value=\*.

There are three special keys in the naming:

* `&lt;`\_name\_`&gt;` is replaced by the file name
* `&lt;`\_ext\_`&gt;` is replaced by the file extension
* `&lt;`\_underscore\_`&gt;` is replaced by character "\_"

See the examples for the file, *Flower.idw*, shown below.

Note: The table below displays result for PDF file. Similar results are generated for DXF and STEP file too.

| Key | Result |
| --- | --- |
| <add key="DesignRepresentation.Naming" value="\.(idw)$/&lt;\_name\_&gt;"/> | Flower.pdf |
| <add key="DesignRepresentation.Naming" value="\.(idw)$/Prefix&lt;\_name\_&gt;"/> | PrefixFlower.pdf |
| <add key="DesignRepresentation.Naming" value="\.(idw)$/&lt;\_name\_&gt;Suffix"/> | FlowerSuffix.pdf |
| <add key="DesignRepresentation.Naming" value="\.(idw)$/Prefix&lt;\_name\_&gt;Suffix"/> | PrefixFlowerSuffix.pdf |
| <add key="DesignRepresentation.Naming" value="\.(idw)$/&lt;\_name\_&gt;&lt; \_underscore\_&gt;Suffix"/> | Flower\_Suffix.pdf |
| <add key="DesignRepresentation.Naming" value="\.(idw)$/&lt;\_name\_&gt;.&lt;\_ext\_&gt;"/> | Flower.idw.pdf |
| <add key="DesignRepresentation.Naming" value="\.(idw)$/&lt;\_name\_&gt;&lt;Revision&gt;"/> | FlowerB.pdf where Revision=B |
| <add key="DesignRepresentation.Naming" value="\.(idw)$/&lt;\_name\_ &gt;&lt;Provider&gt;"/> | FlowerAutoCAD.pdf where Provider=AutoCAD |
| <add key="DesignRepresentation.Naming" value="\.(idw)$/&lt;\_name\_ &gt;&lt;DateVersionCreated&gt;"/> <add key="DesignRepresentation.Naming.DateFormat" value="dd-MM-yy"/>  Note: Add both lines. Use dd=day, MM=month, and yy=year to format the date. (MM must be uppercase) | Flower27-10-17.pdf where the Date Version Created is October 27, 2017 |

Note: Some editors automatically convert `&lt;` to `<` and `&gt;` to `>`. This may cause the Job Processor to fail. It is recommended that you use an editor that maintains `&lt;` and `&gt;`, such as Notepad. The line can contain only the "<" at the beginning and the ">" at the end.

You can add only one line for Design.Represenation.Naming, so combine rules as needed, separating each with a slash (`**/**`). For example:

`<add key="DesignRepresentation.Naming" value="\.(dwg)$/&lt;_name_&gt;&lt;Provider&gt; **/**\.(idw)$/&lt;_name_&gt;&lt;Revision&gt;"/>`

Note: To add other property values, such as Provider, Company, etc, look up the System Name/Display Name of the property. For Vault System Properties, use the System Name and for User Defined Properties, use the Display Name.

Note: If you have configured the output file naming, then the existing output file in vault, if any, may not be updated and a new output file will be created with the edited file name. For instance, if you append "Revision" to the output file name, then the output created for a revised drawing file will be a new file in vault. You won't be able to use and update the previous output file.

#### Configure PDF Publishing Options

# Configure PDF Publishing Options

Select the settings for 2D AutoCAD and 2D Inventor PDF printing.

Note: You must have administrative access to perform these tasks.

1. Click Tools > Administration > Vault Settings.
2. Under PDF Options, click the Options button to launch the PDF Options dialog and configure the PDF publishing settings.
3. Select an application and check the desired settings.

![](../images/vault-pdf-options-dialog.png)

Check the **Enable Manual PDF Creation** box to be able to create a PDF without going through lifecycle state change for a drawing file. The [Create PDF](GUID-EE6877E0-BBEB-4FB2-8B08-F9052F6FCB32.htm) command is available in the toolbar, context menu, and the Actions menu.

These tables describe the settings on the PDF Options dialog for 2D AutoCAD and 2D Inventor publishing.

|  |  |
| --- | --- |
| *2D AutoCAD PDF Publishing Options* | |
| Add As An Attachment | Shows the published PDF file as an attachment to the file. |
| Upload to Source File Location | Automatically stores the published PDF file to the selected file location. |
| Upload To Selected Vault Path | Defines a specific location (using Browse) to store the published PDF file. |
| Sync Lifecycle State and Revision As Source | Allows both the published PDF and its source file to have the same lifecycle state and a revision value. |
| Use Page Settings From User DWG | Eliminates the need to reconfigure page settings in Vault if previously done in the native application. Checked and cannot be unchecked. |
| Include Model Space | Enables the published PDF file to contain the model space view. |
| Include Layouts | Enables the published PDF file to contain layout space views. |
| Include Layer Info | Enables the published PDF file to contain layer information. |
| Initialize Layouts | Supports legacy files. |
| Include Font Handling | Enables publishing a PDF file with font styles. |

|  |  |
| --- | --- |
| *2D Inventor PDF Publishing Options* | |
| Add As An Attachment | Shows the published PDF file as an attachment to the file. |
| Upload to Source File Location | Automatically stores the published PDF file to the selected file location. |
| Sync Lifecycle State and Revision As Source | Allows both the published PDF and its source file to have the same lifecycle state and a revision value. |
| Upload To Selected Vault Path | Defines a specific location (using Browse) to store the published PDF file. |
| Vector Resolution | Set as 400 DPI for managing large PDF file size and appropriate details. |
| Plot Object Lineweights | Enables the published PDF file to display a consistent lineweight for object and consistent lineweight for linetypes. |
| All Sheets | Prints all the sheets in the drawing. To print sheets for which the Exclude from Printing option is checked in the Edit Sheet dialog box, select Print Excluded Sheets. |
| All Colors As Black | Prints the drawing in black and white. Embedded images and shaded views are still printed in color. |

#### PDF Publish Location

# PDF Publish Location

Create PDF for 2D CAD files and specify a desired location outside of Vault Client.

Note: You must have administrative access to perform these tasks.

1. Click Tools > Administration > Vault Settings.
2. In the Vault Settings dialog box, click the Files tab.
3. In the PDF Options area, click Define... to open the PDF Publish Location dialog.
4. In the PDF Publish Location dialog select the desired option:

   1. **Save in Vault (local copies will not be created)**: Disables to publish PDF files locally. Automatically generated PDF files are still created in the Vault Client.
   2. **Save on a local drive in one folder**: Select to store all the PDF files in a single folder on the local computer.
   3. **Save on a local drive using the Vault folder structure**: Select to store local copies of the files in a folder structure that duplicates the structure used in Vault Client.
5. If you select Save on a local drive in one folder or Save on a local drive using the Vault folder structure, click the Browse button and select a shared network folder which is accessible to all users.
6. Click OK.

## Project Sync Administration

# Project Sync Administration

Administrators can configure synchronization settings between Vault and Autodesk cloud drives, and manage mappings.

Note: This feature is available only in Vault Professional. You also need to subscribe to [Autodesk Docs](https://help.autodesk.com/view/DOCS/ENU/?guid=About_Autodesk_Construction_Cloud_Docs) or [Fusion Hub](http://help.autodesk.com/view/FSNT/ENU/?guid=GUID-8C18EED5-0C11-4AD7-89C5-85A81EF8906C) to use Project Sync.

The Project Sync feature provides file and folder synchronization between Vault and supported Autodesk cloud drives. This capability enables Vault users to either automatically or manually synchronize files from a folder in Vault with a folder in a cloud drive. The synchronization can be configured to work in either direction or both directions providing simple and reliable two-way communications between project team members.

The Project Sync utility can be configured to perform synchronization in ways that best suit your needs. A synchronization can occur at a scheduled time each day, at specific time intervals, or on demand. Use the filter options to have even more control over which files are uploaded.

## Bi-Directional Sync

If bi-directional sync is defined for a cloud drive mapping, any changes to the data in the vault are updated to the cloud drive first. After changes have been updated from Vault to the cloud drive, any remaining changes on the cloud drive are updated to Vault.

## Supported Cloud Drives

* [Fusion 360](http://www.autodesk.com/help-fusion-about-enu)
* [Autodesk Docs](https://help.autodesk.com/view/DOCS/ENU/?guid=About_Autodesk_Construction_Cloud_Docs)

To access the Autodesk Docs or Fusion Hub, you must install [Desktop Connector](http://www.autodesk.com/connect-help-about-enu).

Important: Using the Autodesk Docs with Project Sync, we are unable to support the following applications:

* Inventor references/relationship
* Revit references/relationship
* Microstation references/relationship

## Enable the Job Server

Since the Project Sync functionality depends on the Vault Job Processor to pull jobs from the Job Server queue, make sure that the [Job Server](GUID-41C25A0B-81DC-4E5B-B98B-3EA7B280CD97.htm) is enabled.

You must be an administrator in Vault to enable the Job Server.

## Vault Support for Desktop Connector 16.x

Vault now supports Desktop Connector version 16.4 and higher.

Desktop Connector version 16.x introduces many exciting new capabilities. There are some key differences when compared to 15.x versions that should be considered before choosing to install, learn more by referring to [Desktop Connector 16.x FAQ](https://help.autodesk.com/view/CONNECT/ENU/?guid=Version_Comparison_Desktop_Connector).

**Using Desktop Connector v16.4+ with Vault**

If you have previously configured Vault Sync with Desktop Connector v15.x or earlier and plan to [upgrade to Desktop Connector v16.x](https://help.autodesk.com/view/CONNECT/ENU/?guid=Version15x_Version16x_Upgrade), you will need to take action to avoid disruptions in syncing.

The default workspace location has been changed to “C:\users\USERPROFILE\DC” with Desktop Connector v16.x. This change could cause the Job Processor to error on Project Synchronization jobs. An error may also be shown when opening the Project Sync configuration dialog.

To avoid these errors after installing Desktop Connector 16.x, [edit all Cloud Drive mappings](GUID-4782F796-078A-42FC-B6BF-DF49FBF04EB0.htm) (Docs & Fusion) in the Vault Client.

1. Go to Tools > Administration > Vault Settings > Collaborate > Configure.
2. Select a mapping and choose “Edit”.
3. Update the “Cloud Drive folder” to point to the new workspace location. This may automatically get updated upon editing, be sure to click Ok when exiting the dialog.

Important: If you are using multiple Job Processors, all Job Processor machines should be on the same version of Desktop Connector.

**Known Issues or Limitations**

* Inventor workflows with Autodesk Docs require creating a project file using the Desktop Connector’s workspace location. This is only required for those users not using Vault and a Vault Inventor Project file.
* If you are syncing Autodesk Inventor 2024 data, you will need to upgrade to Desktop Connector 16.x. Desktop Connector 15.x does not provide reference support for Autodesk Inventor 2024.

### Manage Cloud Drive Mappings for Project Sync

# Manage Cloud Drive Mappings for Project Sync

Create, edit, or delete a cloud drive mapping for Project Sync.

## Add a Cloud Drive Mapping

1. In Vault Client, select Tools menu > Administration > Vault Settings.
2. In the Vault Settings dialog box, select the Collaborate tab.
3. In the Project Sync Management section, click Configure.
4. Click New to create a cloud drive mapping.

   The Cloud Drive Mapping - New Label opens.
5. Enter a name for the mapping.
6. Browse to the Vault folder you want to map to a cloud drive.
7. Browse to the cloud drive.
8. Check Enable Manual Sync to allow manual uploading or downloading for this cloud drive mapping.
9. Check Include design documentation files to automatically include design documentation for both manual and scheduled syncs.
10. If you want to give preference to files that have a Released version, check Upload Files based on Released bias.

Optional: you can schedule automatic syncing as described in [Manage Cloud Drive Folder Mappings for Project Sync](GUID-AA285C68-B867-4B3E-8C32-D7D705CA1460.htm).

## Edit a Cloud Drive Mapping

1. In Vault Client, select Tools menu > Administration > Vault Settings.
2. In the Vault Settings dialog box, select the Collaborate tab.
3. In the Project Sync Management section, click Configure.
4. Select an existing cloud drive mapping and click Edit.

   The Cloud Drive Mapping - New Label opens.
5. Schedule automatic syncing as described in [Manage Cloud Drive Folder Mappings for Project Sync](GUID-AA285C68-B867-4B3E-8C32-D7D705CA1460.htm).

## Delete a Cloud Drive Mapping

1. In Vault Client, select Tools menu > Administration > Vault Settings.
2. In the Vault Settings dialog box, select the Collaborate tab.
3. In the Project Sync Management section, click Configure.
4. Select an existing cloud drive mapping, click Delete, and confirm the removal.

   The cloud drive mapping, along with any specific folder mappings and sync settings are removed.

## Delete a Folder Mapping

1. In Vault Client, select Tools menu > Administration > Vault Settings.
2. In the Vault Settings dialog box, select the Collaborate tab.
3. In the Project Sync Management section, click Configure.
4. Select an existing cloud drive mapping and click Edit.
5. Select the folder in the Mapping section.
6. Click X.

### Manage Cloud Drive Folder Mappings for Project Sync

# Manage Cloud Drive Folder Mappings for Project Sync

Create, edit, or delete a cloud drive folder mapping and define automatic sync settings.

## Add a Cloud Drive Folder Mapping

Once you [set up a cloud drive mapping](GUID-4782F796-078A-42FC-B6BF-DF49FBF04EB0.htm), you can set up folder mapping and automatic sync settings.

1. Click + to add a folder mapping.
2. Browse to the specific Vault folder you want to set up a sync schedule for.
3. Select the sync action you want to use for this folder.
4. Click OK.

Optional: you can schedule automatic syncing as described in the following section.

## Define Sync Schedule

1. Select an existing cloud drive folder mapping.
2. Click the Schedule tab and select from the available sync settings.

   * **Daily at–**Automatic synchronization between Vault and the cloud drive takes place each day at the specified time.
   * **Every–**Automatic synchronization takes place at the interval specified.
   * **None–**Automatic synchronization is disabled with this setting. Synchronization occurs when you click Download from Cloud Drive or Upload to Cloud Drive in the Vault client.

   Note: If bi-directional sync is defined for a cloud drive mapping, any changes to the data in the vault are updated to the cloud drive first. After changes have been updated from Vault to the cloud drive, any remaining changes on the cloud drive are updated to Vault.

## Define a Filter for Automatic Sync Uploads from Vault to a Cloud Drive

If you are scheduling an upload or bi-directional sync you can define a filter to upload only files that meet the criteria. For example, you may want to upload only files in a Released state.

1. Add or edit a specific folder mapping.
2. Select the Filter tab.
3. Add each filter definition following these steps:

   * Select the Property you want to use for the filter.
   * Select the Condition for that Property.
   * Select a Value if appropriate for the selected Property and Condition.
   * Click Add.
4. Replace a filter definition following these steps:

   * Select the existing filter definition.
   * Select the Property you want to use for the filter.
   * Select the Condition for that Property.
   * Select a Value if appropriate for the selected Property and Condition.
   * Click Replace.

## Delete a Cloud Drive Folder Mapping

1. In Vault Client, select Tools menu > Administration > Vault Settings.
2. In the Vault Settings dialog box, select the Collaborate tab.
3. In the Project Sync Management section, click Configure.
4. Select an existing cloud drive mapping and click Edit.
5. Select the folder in the Mapping section.
6. Click X.

### Key Terms You Should Know Before Fine-Tuning Your Vault Performance

# Key Terms You Should Know Before Fine-Tuning Your Vault Performance

Before fine-tuning your Vault's performance, Autodesk recommends that you learn the following key terms.

| Key Terms | Definition |
| --- | --- |
| Performance Tuning | Monitoring and analyzing the performance of a system and adjusting its configuration to obtain optimum performance. |
| Operating System | The software that the rest of the software depends on to make the computer functional. On most PCs this is Microsoft Windows or the Mac OS. |
| Memory | It is a set of storage locations on the main circuit board of a PC. |
| Disk Defragmentation | A utility included with the Windows operating system that coalesces files on the hard drive, freeing up disk space. |
| Anti-virus Program | A program that searches for viruses and removes any virus that it finds. |
| Proxy Server | Existing between a client Web browser and a real server, a computer that caches common and often requested Web pages and holds them for easier access by users. |
| Customize View | A command in Autodesk Vault to customize the information shown in the display grid. |

### Fine-Tune Vault Client Performance

# Fine-Tune Vault Client Performance

Certain settings in the Vault client application can affect performance in the client as well as the Vault add-ins.

## Customize the View Command

This is a commonly used setting in the Vault client program. It is used to add information to display grids. Usually, this does not have much additional impact on performance. However, some display fields, such as the thumbnail property, may take a longer to display. Enabling these settings only on an 'as needed' basis can help to improve day-to-day performance.

## Memory

Add-ins for design applications consume additional memory. The amount of memory they consume is typically small, but in certain circumstances, it makes sense to review the memory usage on the client. The most common problems occur when the original client CAD model uses most of the available memory of a computer before introducing a vault into the workflow. Please refer to the Server Memory section for additional instructions on how to review the memory usage on your systems.

## Disk Performance

Like the server, client computers can suffer from disk fragmentation as well. The concept of analyzing disk fragmentation is the same for both clients and servers.

### Fine Tune Vault Server Performance

# Fine Tune Vault Server Performance

Fine-tune a number of factors to get optimal performance from the Autodesk Vault server.

## Operating system

A dedicated server operating system such as Windows server 2016 or Windows Server 2019 is preferable to workstation operating systems.

### Server memory

In order to determine whether the server has enough available memory, some key factors must be considered: the size of your data and the number of users concurrently accessing the Vault server.

**View memory usage**

1. Invoke the Task Manager by right-clicking in the taskbar or pressing CTRL.

   ![](../images/task-manager-performance.png)

   If the Commit Charge Total regularly exceeds the total amount of physical memory, it is likely that many of the programs and processes on the server are using the disk-based swap file excessively. Using the swap file is much slower than using physical memory. Windows uses the swap file for many tasks, so a small amount of swap file usage will not cause any problems.
2. If you suspect that your server has an inadequate amount of memory, check the Commit Charge Total value. Clicking the Processes tab reveals more details on the memory usage of all programs or processes.

   Initial memory usage by Autodesk Vault server.

   1. IIS Web Server process (there may be many of these running).
   2. Autodesk Vault server notification process.
   3. Microsoft®SQL server process.
   4. IIS main Web server process.

   ![](../images/task-manager-processes1.png)

   Memory usage after adding a large Inventor drawing and associated files.

   ![](../images/task-manager-processes2.png)

In general, SQL Server memory grow over time. This is because the database server is using memory as fast cache buffers for frequently used queries. As other programs request memory on the server, SQL Server releases memory as needed. Similarly, the IIS worker process (w3wp.exe in Windows 2003 server) reserves memory for caching as well. When the system starts running low on physical memory, the operating system reclaims some of this memory. In general, unless you have a large site with many users or large models, this will not need to be changed.

## Disk performance

Using multiple disks generally enhances system performance. There are many types of disk technologies available, such as the Redundant Array of Inexpensive Disks (RAID). Choosing which type of disk technologies depends on the number of users, vault size, frequency of updates, and so on.

Disk fragmentation can also greatly affect Autodesk Vault server performance. Most Windows editions provide a disk tool that measures how the files on your computer are stored on disk.

Run the disk defragmenter

1. Click Start ► All Programs ► Accessories ► System Tools ► Disk Defragmenter.

   ![](../images/disk-defragmenter-dlg.png)
2. Choose a disk (volume) and click Analyze. Following analysis, a report appears.

   ![](../images/analysis-report-dlg.png)
3. Click the Defragment button.

   ![](../images/disk-defrag-defragmenting-dlg.png)

## Aggressive anti-virus programs

Some types of Anti-virus programs scan data coming from the network and data being written to the file store. If your anti-virus software appears to be engaged for too long on vault operations, such as uploads, adjusting the scanner settings may help.

There is, of course, a trade-off between security and performance. Because of this, performing some test cases and benchmarks on your own data and server is recommended.

## CPU

Faster or multiple CPUs can improve vault performance. Since this option is typically more expensive than the others, consider it after you review the other areas.

### Resolve Common Vault Server Installation Issues

# Resolve Common Vault Server Installation Issues

This topic contains solutions for installation problems that sometimes occur if the Autodesk Data Management Server (ADMS) is not properly configured.

## Error 404: File Not Found

During the pre-checks of the data management server installation, you receive this message:

This error sometimes occusr if the ASP.NET Web service Extension is not allowed to run in Internet Information Services (IIS).

Solution:

1. Open the Internet Information Services Manager.
2. Expand the Web Services Extension Folder.
3. In the right pane, select ASP .NET v4.0.30319.
4. Select the ASP .NET extension in the right pane.
5. Click Allow.
6. Restart the pre-checks.

## Error: ASPX failed to run

During the pre-checks of the data management server installation, you receive the message "Error ASPX failed to run ASP .NET filter is prohibited."

Solution:

1. Open the Internet Information Services Manager.
2. Expand the Web Services Extension Folder.
3. From the right pane, select ASP .NET v4.0.30319.
4. Select the ASP .NET extension in the right pane.
5. Click Allow.
6. Restart the pre-checks.

## Error: ASPX file failed to run

During the pre-checks of the data management server installation you receive the message "ASPX failed to run at URL: http:// localhost/TestASPNet.aspx."

The cause of this error can be if .NET 2.0 is installed prior to installing Internet Information Services (IIS) and ASP >NET account does not have the proper permissions on the iis Metabase.

Solution:

1. Open a windows command prompt and navigate to the %systemroot%\microsoft.net\framework\v4.0.30319\ directory.
2. Enter aspnet\_regiis.exe -ga "%computername%\Network Service" for windows Server 2003 operating systems.
3. Enter IISRESET
4. Restart the pre-checks.

## Error 29001 - Performance counter

During the pre-checks of the data management server installation you receive the message "Error 29001. Performance counter installation error. Input string was not a correct format."

This error sometimes occurs when the installation attempts to add performance counters for the data management server.

Solution:

To check the current state of the performance counters:

1. Click Start (Windows) ► Run.
2. In the Run dialog box, enter Perfmon.
3. Verify that you can add performance counters to the list to be monitored.

An inability to add performance counters indicates that system files are corrupted.

To repair these files:

1. Using windows Internet Explorer, browse to C:\WINDOWS\system32
2. Rename the perfc009.dat and perfh009.dat files to perfc009.dat.OLD and perfh009.dat.OLD, respectively.
3. Click Start (Windows) ► Run.
4. In the Run dialog box, enter lodctr /r:PerfStringBackup.ini.
5. Export a copy of HKEY\_LOCAL\_MACHINE\Software\Microsoft\windows NT\Current Version\Perflib\009 from the system registry of a working computer and transfer it to your computer.
6. Change the Data Values of the Last Counter and Last Help keys so that they are the same as in the system registry of the working computer.
7. Restart your computer.

## ISAPI Filter error while running

While running the data management server on the 64-bit version of windows server 2003 you notice an Event ID 2274 error in the Event Viewer Application log, indicating a problem with ISAPI filter.

Solution:

Refer to the following Microsoft Knowledge Base article: <http://support.microsoft.com/kb/894435/en-us>.

### Troubleshoot Vault Server Performance with the Vault Server Diagnostics Tool

# Troubleshoot Vault Server Performance with the Vault Server Diagnostics Tool

Learn how to use the Autodesk Server Diagnostics Tool or the Autodesk online Knowledge Base to solve problems that might occur when installing or using Autodesk Data Management Server.

It is helpful if you understand these terms before moving through the topics in this section.

| Key Terms | Definition |
| --- | --- |
| Autodesk Server Diagnostics Tool | A program that can perform a series of checks to identify possible Autodesk Vault server problems and gather system information to help diagnose the problem. |
| Autodesk Knowledge Base | An online support for all Autodesk products. |
| Autodesk Vault server | The server used in conjunction with Autodesk Vault and Content Center for storing files and version data. |
| Log file | A text file generated by the Autodesk Server Diagnostics Tool containing important system configuration information. |

Changes to the server machine configuration over time can interfere with the Autodesk Vault server. The Autodesk Server Diagnostic Tool performs a series of tests to identify possible Autodesk Vault server problems and compiles system information to help diagnose the problem.

## Run the Autodesk Server Diagnostic Tool

1. On the Windows Start menu, select Programs ► Autodesk ► Autodesk Data Management ► Tools ► Autodesk Server Diagnostics Tool.

   The diagnostic tool automatically performs a check. The results of the diagnostic tests display in a list, indicating which of the checks passed successfully, generated a warning, or failed.

   * If a warning is returned, click the link in the Warning list to get more information.
   * If any of the checks fail, click the link displayed under the Action Required list to learn more about the error.
   * When the diagnostics are complete, click Close and then click Open Log Files to open the directory containing the log files.

Learn more about errors and corrections:

* In the Review Your Results list, click the error information under the Action Required list. It is linked to the corresponding pages of Autodesk Vault server installation help.

### View Diagnostic Log Files

The diagnostic log file lists the name of each condition that is checked along with its information and test results. This includes the version of the operating system, the IIS information, the firewall, and any other related configuration information. Other log files are also created during the installation. The log files are stored in the EDMLog folder located in C:\Documents and Settings\Administrator\Local Settings\Temp.

Access the log files using one of the following methods:

* In the Diagnostics Tool dialog box, click Open Log File. The EDMLog directory containing all the log files is opened. Select a log file to open.
* Once you run the diagnostic checks, click View Log File to display the diagnostic log file.

If it is necessary to seek assistance, forward log files to your IT personnel or to Autodesk Technical Support.

### Recheck Operating System Environments

After you correct all the errors according to the log files or the Help, click Recheck. The Diagnostics Tool checks the operating system again. Repeat this process until the all of the errors are corrected.

## Advanced Troubleshooting

Additional troubleshooting resources for the Autodesk Data Management Server can be found online. They include a searchable Knowledge Base available on the Autodesk support page. You can access the Autodesk Knowledge Base online at [www.autodesk.com](http://www.autodesk.com).

### Why Manage Items and BOMs with Vault?

# Why Manage Items and BOMs with Vault?

The top workflow waste that managers want to eliminate is the need manually enter information from one system into another. This is often the case with BOM data in AutoCAD Mechanical. Vault streamlines that workflow by integrating with AutoCAD Mechanical and automatically updating BOM data.

For example, if a change is made to a BOM in AutoCAD Mechanical, the change is automatically captured by Vault. Similarly, if an item update in Vault generates new BOM values, the changes are also shown in the relevant BOMs in AutoCAD Mechanical.

Item and BOM Management Benefits with Vault

With Vault, you can:

* Create and maintain BOMs directly from CAD models, including structure (assemblies), quantity, and position numbers.
* Edit BOMs in Vault by adding and removing rows, ungrouping rows, reordering rows, and modifying positions.
* Release and publish BOM data to ERP Systems
* Synchronize promoted items with latest file versions
* Attach new drawings to an item automatically
* Ensure DWF files are up-to-date for viewing
* Start procurement before the design is complete.

#### Enforce Consistent File and Item Names

# Enforce Consistent File and Item Names

Ensure your data is organized with logical names by incorporating Vault numbering schemes. In addition, Autodesk recommends using a Data Standard sheet to standardize how file data is provided in AutoCAD and the Vault client.

## File Numbering and Data Sheets

Use a default or customized numbering scheme to ensure that all files in a vault are named in a consistent format. This will help with file organization.

Autodesk recommends that you use [Data Standard](http://help.autodesk.com/view/vault/2015/enu/?guid=guid-5030830e-69f8-4a57-abe4-d1d430c58f95) sheets to leverage the numbering scheme capabilities in Vault.

![](../images/dialog-2015r2-new-dlg-ds-cad-new-file.gif)

The Data Standard sheet should be customized to define these behaviors:

* The file name
* Where the file is saved
* If the Vault Check-in dialog is displayed
* Which AutoCAD TitleBlock properties are synchronized with the Data Standard entries.

```
See [Map AutoCAD DWG Properties in Data Standard](http://help.autodesk.com/view/vault/2015/enu/?guid=guid-828ec987-3e70-4132-815a-55646e4f31b7) for more information.
```

These settings ensure that all AutoCAD Mechanical files adhere to the same numbering scheme and are saved in the same location, and that all title block properties are automatically synchronized.

A standardized workflow creates a familiar, reliable path for users to check files into a vault from AutoCAD Mechanical, and it eliminates the risk of user error.

## Item Numbering

When an item is created, the default numbering scheme is used to generate the item number.

Use the out-of-the-box numbering scheme or create your own to reduce user workload and standardize the item numbering process.

For example, if a numbering scheme requires user input, users are immediately prompted to fill in the required values so there is no need to go back and edit the item record later.

**Parent page:** [Key Vault Administration Settings](GUID-2F48F2C5-63DE-4A38-949E-CAFA51382B45.htm)


#### Configure Item Settings

# Configure Item Settings

Make the most of your AutoCAD Mechanical Item and BOM workflows by configuring these settings in Vault.

## Use Validation Options in Item Lifecycles

When setting up [lifecycle state transition](http://help.autodesk.com/view/vault/2015/enu/?guid=guid-b4443a39-a621-4e14-8a11-484efbf3db90) criteria for your items, be sure to take advantage of the automatic validation options available. Validation options are a great way to ensure that items meet certain requirements before changing state.

For example, you can require that items meet these criteria before they can change state:

* Linked items are released
* Children items are not Obsolete
* Children items are released
* Associated item file links are up-to-date
* Associated item file links are released

## Suppress the Associated Items Dialog for a Faster Workflow

By default, when you link an item to an AutoCAD Mechanical file and jump to the item, the Associated Items Dialog displays. This dialog lists all items that are currently linked to the file. Since some files may have many item links (part-references), this list can be quite long.

Autodesk recommends suppressing this dialog in your Vault Options so that you go straight to the newly-linked item in these situations.

## Leverage the Flexible Sub-component Links Feature to Suit Your Design Process

Control the link type for sub-components by configuring whether Primary and Secondary or Standard component links are used during an Assign Item or Update Item event.

![](../images/dialog-bp-configureitemsettings.png)

**Parent page:** [Key Vault Administration Settings](GUID-2F48F2C5-63DE-4A38-949E-CAFA51382B45.htm)


#### Prepare Your Title Blocks

# Prepare Your Title Blocks

Follow these best practices for preparing your title blocks for synchronization with Vault.

## Be Consistent with Title Block Names

Use consistent and clear naming conventions with your title blocks. This makes it easier to recognize your title block names in a long list.

## Use Concise Descriptions

Make sure title blocks have concise descriptions. These descriptions will be visible as properties in Vault and can provide a quick way to identify the drawing.

## Use Title Block Properties Instead of Attributes

Autodesk recommends that you use properties with your title blocks instead of attributes. Vault mapping is most reliable with AutoCAD title block properties.

## Know Your Title Block Names

Record the title block names that are used in your drawings. These names must be enabled in Vault before you can map them. The names must match exactly for mappings to succeed.

![](../images/bp-acadm-titleblock.png)

**Parent page:** [Key Vault Administration Settings](GUID-2F48F2C5-63DE-4A38-949E-CAFA51382B45.htm)


#### Enable AutoCAD Block Property Values in Vault

# Enable AutoCAD Block Property Values in Vault

Block attributes must be enabled in Vault before you can map them.

## Do Not Extract Attribute Prompts

When enabling your AutoCAD Block Properties in the ADMS Console, Autodesk recommends that you turn off the **Extract attribute prompt when available** check box. AutoCAD Mechanical attribute names are checked only if they are unique, and prompts are not always unique.

#### Sync ERP ID Numbers with AutoCAD Mechanical ID Numbers

# Sync ERP ID Numbers with AutoCAD Mechanical ID Numbers

Synchronize your ERP ID Numbers with your AutoCAD Mechanical ID Numbers to automate your item numbering process and eliminate unnecessary duplications.

There are three parts to configuring your ERP ID numbers to synchronize with AutoCAD Mechanical ID Numbers.

* Configure Content in AutoCAD Mechanical
* Add PSEQUIVALENCE to the AutoCAD Template (dwt)
* Set the Equivalence Values in Vault

Configure Content in AutoCAD Mechanical

Configure AutoCAD Mechanical file properties so that they can be synchronized with Vault.

1. Open AutoCAD Mechanical and click Content Manager on the AutoCAD Mechanical ribbon.

```
![](../../images/ribbon-acadm-contentmanager.png)
```

2. Right-click on the file in AutoCAD Mechanical for which you want to synchronize ID numbers and select Edit.

```
![](../../images/screenshot-acadm-contentmanager.png)

Note: You may see a disclaimer stating that Standard Content can only be edited for size or BOM properties in Family Table. This means that there are limitations on the content you can change and does not impact the changes you will make. Click Close to continue.
```

3. De-select all columns.
4. Click the Show icon and select Show Status and ID Columns.

```
![](../../images/screenshot-acadm-showstatusandids.png)
```

5. Add the ERP ID numbers (item-numbers) in the ID Column and select one of the listed values.

```
For example, you could set USERID, which is an internal name, to be the ID Number.
```

6. Save your changes and close the Content Manager.

Add PSEQUIVALENCE to Your Company Template (dwt)

To avoid parts which are inserted mor than once or are assigned to another item number in a vault, add the PSEQUIVALENCE property to your dwt template.

1. In AutoCAD Mechanical, enter `ACM options` in the command line to open the Options dialog.
2. Select the AM:Standards tab.
3. Double-click BOM in the Standard elements list to edit it.

```
![](../../images/dialog-acadm-options-editbom.png)
```

4. Click the More button on the right side and add the new ID number property you created in the previous section.

```
This property was called USERID in our previous example.
```

5. Create a new property called PSEQUIVALENCE and give it a Caption of PSEQUIVALENCE.
6. Give the new PSEQUIVALENCE Property a Value equal to your ID Number property name. In our example, this would be a value of .

```
![](../../images/screenshot-acadm-psequivalence.png)
```

7. Drag and drop USERID and PSEQUIVALENCE to the following areas:
   - Component Properties Tab
   - BOM Tab
   - Parts List Tab (as-option-only).
8. Click OK to save your changes.

Set the Equivalence Values in Vault

After you have set up your AutoCAD Mechanical ID number property and PSEQUIVALENCE property, you can map the Equivalence values to Vault properties.

1. In the Vault Client, go to Tools > Administration > Vault Settings.
2. Select the Behaviors tab and click Properties.
3. In the Property Definitions dialog box, select the Equivalence Value property from the list, and click Edit.
4. Select the Mapping tab to see associated property mappings.
5. Configure the Equivalence Value mappings as shown in this image.

```
![](../../images/dialog-editproperties-equivalence.png)
```

6. Click OK to save your changes and return to the Edit Property dialog.
7. On the Edit Property dialog, select the (item) Number property and add the ID Number from the DWG as the initial value, as shown in the following image.

```
![](../../images/dialog-editudp-itemnumber.png)
```

8. Select the Mapping tab for Number and map the (item) Number property back to AutoCAD Mechanical, as shown.

```
![](../../images/dialog-editudp-number-mapping.png)
```

9. Click OK to save your changes and close the Edit Property dialog.

```
New item numbers will now be written back to the Part Reference in AutoCAD Mechanical.
```

**Parent page:** [Key Vault Administration Settings](GUID-2F48F2C5-63DE-4A38-949E-CAFA51382B45.htm)


### Creating Items and BOMs with AutoCAD Mechanical File Data

# Creating Items and BOMs with AutoCAD Mechanical File Data

Keep these practices in mind when creating items and BOMs with AutoCAD Mechanical data.

## Use Item Versions to View Item Changes

See item versions by selecting View > Show All Item Versions. Item versions can then be viewed on these tabs:

* General Tab
* History Tab
* BOM
* Where Used

## Use the Update Item Command to Automatically Create New Items for New Associated Files

Updating an item linked to an assembly file creates a new item for each new file associated with it. If any drawing files that were originally associated with the CAD files are removed, their association with the item is also removed when the item is updated.

Note: Once a file is saved and checked in using AutoCAD Mechanical it will need to be only opened and checked in from AutoCAD Mechanical to continue to send item data. Saving an AutoCAD Mechanical DWG using AutoCAD or AutoCAD LT will remove any existing item data from the DWG and cause item assignment to fail.

**Parent page:** [Best Practices: AutoCAD Mechanical and Vault (items-and-boms)](GUID-7CD64749-FFC6-49CF-B1B0-CE5378367B82.htm)


### Assigning Items

# Assigning Items

Make the most of the Assign Item command with these best practices.

## Drag-and-Drop or Copy-and-Paste File and Item Links

Use the drag-and-drop or copy-and-paste features to:

* Assign files to items
* Assign an item to another item
* Assign a component to an item

## Create Long Lead BOMs to Start Procurement Before a Design Is Complete

Some components take longer to procure due to complexity, quantity, or availability. Use Assign Item to create a partial BOM so you can start procurement before the design is complete.

## Know Your Links

It is essential to understand how Vault treats different link types so you can make the best decisions for your design process.

| Link Type | Read/Write Properties | Old Link Prevents State Change to Release | Create the Link Automatically | Update Item |
| --- | --- | --- | --- | --- |
| *Primary* | Yes/Yes | Flexible | Yes | Yes |
| *Secondary* | No/Yes | Flexible | Yes | Yes |
| *Standard Component* | No/Yes | Flexible | Yes | No |
| *Automatic Tertiary* | No/Yes | Flexible | Yes | Yes |
| *Primary Sub-component* | Yes/Yes | Flexible | Flexible | Yes |
| *Secondary Sub-component* | No/Yes | Flexible | Flexible | No |
| *Attachment* | No/No | No | No | Yes |

**Parent page:** [Best Practices: AutoCAD Mechanical and Vault (items-and-boms)](GUID-7CD64749-FFC6-49CF-B1B0-CE5378367B82.htm)


### Updating Items and BOMs with AutoCAD Mechanical File Data

# Updating Items and BOMs with AutoCAD Mechanical File Data

Update Items and BOMs in Vault automatically when you make changes to your file data from AutoCAD Mechanical.

## Synchronize Changes to Title Blocks in AutoCAD Mechanical with Vault

If you make changes to a title block in AutoCAD Mechanical, check the file back in to synchronize the changes with Vault.

Tip: Be sure to select the Keep File Checked Out check box if you plan to continue working on the file.

In addition, entering data directly into your AutoCAD Mechanical BOM and checking the file back in will also synchronize changes with Vault.

**Parent page:** [Best Practices: AutoCAD Mechanical and Vault (items-and-boms)](GUID-7CD64749-FFC6-49CF-B1B0-CE5378367B82.htm)


### Updating AutoCAD Mechanical BOM Data Using Vault

# Updating AutoCAD Mechanical BOM Data Using Vault

## Use Update Item Command to Synchronize Items with Associated Files

Update synchronizes items with the properties of the associated file versions in the vault. An item can be updated even if the associated file has not been changed so as to update any properties that have been globally added since the last update.

Updating an item linked to an assembly file creates a new item for each new file associated with it. If any drawing files that were originally associated with the CAD files are removed, their association with the item is also removed when the item is updated.

## Write Back Item Properties

Use the Synchronize Properties command to write item and BOM properties back to the title blocks in AutoCAD Mechanical.

You can write back data such as the item number, the revision, or the description, amongst other properties.

## Quickly Modify Multiple Title Block Properties with the Property Grid in Vault

A fast way to update title block properties in bulk is to use the [Properties Grid](http://help.autodesk.com/view/vault/2015/enu/?guid=guid-ad7174e2-b36c-40c2-9608-2d7a7965bd40). This workflow is especially useful if you have the drawing already open in AutoCAD Mechanical but want to quickly update all of the Title Block properties.

1. Select the drawing in Vault for which you want to change the property values.
2. Select the properties in the Properties Grid and click Edit.
3. Enter your values for each property selected.
4. Click OK.
5. Return to the open drawing in AutoCAD Mechanical and click Refresh to get the latest values from Vault. The Title Block is automatically updated.

## Add the Row Type Field to Your BOM View

Add the **Row Type** field to your BOM view so you can see if a row was manually created or created by CAD. This makes it easier to see the source of your data and determine which content will be overwritten from the CAD application during an update.

See Customize the BOM View for more information.

## Adjust CAD Position Numbers in Item BOMs to Suit Process Needs

Add [position numbers](http://help.autodesk.com/view/vault/2015/enu/?guid=guid-68d49b60-7f76-4fd5-8a1e-60295400c9f5) for manual BOM rows or modify existing CAD positions for greater control over your downstream processes.

Important: If the BOM row was imported from AutoCAD Mechanical or another CAD application, the position may be overwritten if the values change on the CAD side.

The Position Number field will turn yellow for any duplicate position numbers, making it easier for you to identify conflicts.

**Parent page:** [Best Practices: AutoCAD Mechanical and Vault (items-and-boms)](GUID-7CD64749-FFC6-49CF-B1B0-CE5378367B82.htm)


## Best Practices: Manage iParts and iAssemblies with Vault

# Best Practices: Manage iParts and iAssemblies with Vault

This best practices guide establishes a baseline for using Autodesk Inventor iPart and iAssembly with Autodesk Vault.

## Statement of Scope

This guide is intended to highlight best practice workflows. Only where necessary will configuration and administration settings be highlighted, such as critical settings that enable suggested workflows.

Startup workflows such as installation, Vault configuration, and data loading are not highlighted.

## Customer Experience

This guide assumes that you are a key user responsible for creating and maintaining component families. In some cases, you must be an administrator to perform certain configurations.

As a key user, you should have basic knowledge of:

* Inventor iPart and iAssembly workflows
* Factory/Member file and item management
* Revision Tables
* Copy Design workflow
* Item and file configuration
* Vault revision and numbering schemes
* Vault categories
* Vault rename and move workflows.

### Why Manage iParts and iAssemblies with Vault?

# Why Manage iParts and iAssemblies with Vault?

Vault differentiates between family and member revisions, making data management more precise.

This guide shows you how to:

* Create a consistent workflow for family creation up to item management, including all component family members
* Revise component families and reduce revision efforts to affected members only; in particular how to partially revise dedicated variants of a family
* Leverage and expand Inventor functionality when creating and maintaining component families in a Vault environment
* Incorporate naming conventions of component families to allow full support for rename, move, and copy activities through the lifecycle of a component family.

**Parent page:** [Best Practices: Manage iParts and iAssemblies with Vault](GUID-3AC6DDCF-A25C-4D92-9A26-04CF1719AB7E.htm)


### Creating Factory Members

# Creating Factory Members

Use these best practices to create factory members.

## iAssembly Workflows

When creating factory members, use the following workflow to avoid assembly updates when opening or placing an iAssembly or iPart.

![](../images/ipart-creatfactoryworkflow.png)

## Handling Part Numbers

Apply file numbering schemes to Factory members to automate part number creation.

**Recommended:** Use Vault Data Standard to apply numbering schemes and enforce user input for certain properties. Administrators can configure Data Standard to reserve a number range for parts.

![](../images/ipart-reservenumbers.png)

This is the best way to standardize the creation process and ensure that related parts are grouped by number.

## Share Numbering Schemes for Items and Files

Optimize data management of related items and files by sharing numbering schemes. Use Data Standard to reserve number ranges.

When creating a new iPart, perform these steps:

1. Go to the Add Member table, copy the file name, and paste it into the Member field.

```
![](../images/ipart-filenamemembername.png)
```

2. Insert rows for additional members as needed.
3. Modify the values for the added member rows.

```
![](../images/ipart-addmembers.png)
```

4. Use Data Standard in Vault to reserve a range of numbers.

```
![](../images/updatinghandlingimage.png)
```

5. Copy the reserved numbers and paste them into the Part Number column in the member table.

```
![](../images/ipart-rangepartnumbersinmembertable.png)
```

6. Right-click on the new members in the Model Browser and select Generate Files.
7. Check the new member files into Vault.

## Avoid Pending Updates in Top Level iAssemblies with These Steps

* Use Bottom Up approach to populate all changes to the top level iAssembly.
* Test your members before releasing.
* Use rebuild all on persistent dirty files.
* Don't Use Administrative override.

### Releasing Families and Family Members

# Releasing Families and Family Members

Follow these tips to optimize the family and member release process.

## iPart and iAssembly Release Overview

1. Create Family.
2. Check family into Vault. Select the option to keep the family checked out.
3. Synchronize/Update iPart family file properties.
4. Test family.
5. Generate members.
6. Check in Factory and Members.
7. Synchronize member properties in the Vault client.
8. Test members.
9. Release iFactory and Members (see-next-sections-for-more-details).

```
Note: Select direct parents to include members when releasing the factory.
```

## Release iFactory

* Members derive from iFactory.
* iAssembly Factory may contain normal parts/subassemblies as well.
* Check Member option.

![](../images/ipart-release1.png)

## Release Members

* Check member option.

```
![](../images/ipart-release2.png)
```

* Check that all members are up to date before releasing.
  1. Get all latest version of the children.
  2. Open members separately.
  3. Place in empty assembly.
* Use quick-change if updates appear after releasing the members.

**Parent page:** [Best Practices: Manage iParts and iAssemblies with Vault](GUID-3AC6DDCF-A25C-4D92-9A26-04CF1719AB7E.htm)


### Revising and Updating Factory and Member Files

# Revising and Updating Factory and Member Files

Use these best practices to revise and update factory and member files.

## Revise Only Affected Members

1. Change state and check out Factory only.
2. Modify iPart/iAssembly and synchronize properties.
3. Generate Members and remove the read-only setting for iAssembly members.
4. Review changed members in the Vault client. Make sure the Add (+) status modifier is displayed.

```
![](../images/ipart-addmodifier.png)
```

5. Change state on affected members only.
6. Check-in Factory.

```
Members are automatically checked-in.
```

7. Get latest members.
8. Test members.
9. Release factory and members in the Vault client.

## Update Factory

Note: When updating, be sure to follow the tips in [Creating Factory Members](GUID-39D2F2F2-4F7B-4450-8FC4-EF988B30290B.htm).

![](../images/ipart-factoryupdateoverview.png)

**Parent page:** [Best Practices: Manage iParts and iAssemblies with Vault](GUID-3AC6DDCF-A25C-4D92-9A26-04CF1719AB7E.htm)


### Renaming Factory and Members

# Renaming Factory and Members

Use these best practices to rename factory and member files.

## Rename Factory

Name subfolders containing member parts the same name as the Factory file name. This is so that when you rename a factory, the subfolder automatically updates as well.

![](../images/ipart-factory-rename.png)

If the subfolder for member parts is not set to the factory file name, Vault allows you to rename the subfolder. However, once the subfolder is named the same as the Factory file name, you cannot rename the subfolder again.

## Rename Members

Standard and custom members are secure. Manually renaming them can cause issues with Inventor.

![](../images/ipart-memberrenamenotallowed.png)

If a member file needs to be renamed without maintaining the family relationship, use Inventor to break the member's link before renaming the file.

![](../images/ipart-inventorlinkbreakformember.png)

**Parent page:** [Best Practices: Manage iParts and iAssemblies with Vault](GUID-3AC6DDCF-A25C-4D92-9A26-04CF1719AB7E.htm)


### Moving Factory and Members

# Moving Factory and Members

Use these best practices to move iPart Factory, iPart Members, and related folders.

## Moving iPart Factory

Name subfolders containing member parts the same name as the Factory file name. This is so that when you move a factory, the subfolder and members are automatically moved as well.

Now, when you move the factory, you move the complete family.

![](../images/ipart-movefactory.png)

## Moving iPart Members

By default, Vault prevents the move of standard and custom members. Generally, iPart families should be managed as a whole, as described in the above section.

However, if you must move a particular member without moving the entire family, Inventor must break the link first.

![](../images/ipart-inventorlinkbreakformember.png)

## Moving iPart Members Folders

Avoid moving design files into members folders. Vault will display a warning message; this is because if your factory subfolder is set up according to best practices in this topic, when you move a factory, all files in the members folder are moved as well.

**Parent page:** [Best Practices: Manage iParts and iAssemblies with Vault](GUID-3AC6DDCF-A25C-4D92-9A26-04CF1719AB7E.htm)


### Using Copy Design with Factory and Members

# Using Copy Design with Factory and Members

Use these best practices to copy your factory and member files.

The usual design intent of component families is for reuse. Therefore, a copy consuming family members is expected to reuse family members or to replace family members by others. In case you need to copy family member anyway, be aware that Copy Design has to remove the member's link to the family.

## Copying Members in an Assembly

As a best practice, do not copy Factory or Members when copying an Assembly. Doing so will break the links to the factory.

## Copying iPart Factory

Derive a new iPart from an existing iPart Factory with the following workflow. This is essentially performing a Save Copy As.

1. Copy iPart Factory.
2. Edit Factory table.
3. Rename members.
4. Make modifications.
5. Save Factory in up-to-date state.
6. Generate new members.
7. Check-in.

## Copying iAssembly Factory

Use these practices when copying an iAssembly Factory.

Bottom Up Approach

* iParts first
* Nested iAssemblies

Copy iParts Factory separately

* Regenerate members with new file names.

Copy iAssembly

* Replace with new iParts/iAssembly members during Copy Design.
* Regenerate Members with new File Names.

**Parent page:** [Best Practices: Manage iParts and iAssemblies with Vault](GUID-3AC6DDCF-A25C-4D92-9A26-04CF1719AB7E.htm)


### Itemizing and Documenting Member Details

# Itemizing and Documenting Member Details

For part family drawings that require many pages to detail, create multiple sheets and link them to the top-level iFactory rather than the individual iMembers. In other words, start by creating one drawing number with all revision data and the table of represented parts on sheet 1, then provide additional details, such as differences, on the other sheets.

![](../images/ifactoryimembers.png)

For the preceding iPart members illustration, follow these steps to document their details in multiple sheets.

1. Document all iPart members within an IDW drawing or series of drawings linked to the entire iFactory.
2. Include a table of the parameter values that differentiate the iFactory members.
3. Link one or more sheets to the IDW to represent each iPart member as needed.
4. Create an item from any iPart member.

Autodesk does not recommend creating a tabulated IDW from individual iPart members.

**Parent page:** [Best Practices: Manage iParts and iAssemblies with Vault](GUID-3AC6DDCF-A25C-4D92-9A26-04CF1719AB7E.htm)


### Migrate iPart and iAssembly Files

# Migrate iPart and iAssembly Files

Migrate your files in this order to ensure a trouble-free migration.

1. Use Task Scheduler > Migrate folder or project.
2. Migrate your files in this order:
   - iPart Factory
   - iPart Members
   - Parts
   - Standard parts
   - Subassemblies
   - iAssembly Factory (lowest-level-first)
   - iAssembly Members (lowest-level-first)
   - Assemblies
   - Presentations
   - Drawings

**Parent page:** [Best Practices: Manage iParts and iAssemblies with Vault](GUID-3AC6DDCF-A25C-4D92-9A26-04CF1719AB7E.htm)

### Installation Overview

# Installation Overview

Learn about how to install the Autodesk Vault Server and Vault client, as well as customize your installation to meet your design needs. You can install Vault for a single site environment or establish a multi-site environment. You can also install supporting components that integrate with Autodesk Vault to further streamline your design experience.

It is important to have a fundamental understanding of Vault before installing and customizing Vault for your particular environment. If you are new to using Vault, see the About Vault section in the online help to learn more about the Vault architecture, Vault Add-ins, and Vault editions.

Review the Vault Requirements

Before installing Autodesk Vault, review the [Installation and System Requirements](https://www.autodesk.com/vault-system) for your Vault edition.

Plan Your Deployment

A Vault implementation can be as simple as installing all components on a single computer, or as complex as installing components on several computers in different locations. The more complex the Implementation, the more information there is to consider. Review [Planning Your Deployment](GUID-590CC16D-0CA4-47A2-AA4E-713B8116DEAC.htm) to help you determine how best to implement Vault for your work environment.

Note: Learn how to plan, create, and distribute an Autodesk deployment to standardize installation across many computers. See Installation for administrators.

Install the License Manager (professional-only)

If you are installing Vault Professional, you must install the License Manager.

Follow the steps in [Vault Licensing](GUID-30A964D6-E937-4271-B6AC-C515D9091DEE.htm) to install the License Manager for Vault.

Install the Vault Server

You must install the Vault Server before installing the Vault Client or any supporting components. During the installation process, the installation wizard performs several [Pre-checks](GUID-CCA5719F-4BE6-4BC9-AC46-42DB83D8DB52.htm) to make sure that the system on which the Vault Server is being installed meets the system requirements.

There are three types of server installations:

* **[Quick Start Installation](GUID-E43F824E-1308-4DBC-9C4E-EA142103EB03.htm)** –A step-by-step walkthrough with a default configuration. If this is your first time installing the Vault Server and you will be using a single Vault environment, select this installation path.
* **[Custom Installation](GUID-C16D060C-0785-40FC-A5F7-A636E885D109.htm)** –Provides additional information about customizing your Vault server environment.
* **[Distributed Teams Installation](GUID-3561F6E4-81B2-4C9A-AD73-B74B751F9FDF.htm)** –Provides information about setting up a multi-site or replicated Vault environment.

Select the installation type that suits your work environment and follow the steps to install the Vault Server.

Install the Vault Client

After the Vault Server is installed, you must install the [Vault Client](GUID-C3D45E7C-68FA-4EE5-909D-E6D183F22F6A.htm).

Optional: Install Supporting Components

Vault integrates with additional products to help you optimize your design environment. Refer to [Install Supporting Components](GUID-F84E590B-4483-41D3-B15F-FF4A01E75DCB.htm) for Vault integration options.

**Parent page:** [Vault Installation](GUID-0CC46131-E79E-487A-B53E-3E21A28392CB.htm)


### Plan Your Deployment

# Plan Your Deployment

Before you begin your Vault installation, you should prepare for the deployment by examining your environment and gathering data to ensure an optimal installation experience.

A Vault implementation can be as simple as installing all components on a single computer, or as complex as installing components on several computers in different locations. The more complex the implementation, the more information there is to consider. The following sections detail information to consider to make the best decisions for your Vault implementation.

## Number of Users

Knowing the number of users helps prevent access problems and slow response times. For example, if you have more than ten concurrent users, use Windows® Server 2012. For more than 25 users, consider upgrading to the full standard edition or enterprise edition of SQL. Microsoft SQL Express allows only 25 concurrent connections. When implementing Vault for a single user, you can load all the components on a single computer.

## Number of Servers

When determining the number of servers, keep in mind how information flows from the client computer to the Vault server to the SQL server and back. (see-how-vault-works-for-more-information.)

## Server Hardware Specifications

Vault uses Microsoft SQL so it is more processor intensive than memory intensive like some other applications. Avoid loading Vault components on servers that already have a high CPU usage.

## Server Operating Systems

Vault Server can be loaded on several different operating systems. When deciding to use a non-server operating system, consider the limitations.

## Firewalls

Firewalls can block incoming requests. During the Vault Server installation, the server is checked for known firewalls. Firewalls can require that you configure them to allow the Vault Server to communicate correctly. Some system protection software can include firewalls. Check these tools for the existence of firewalls.

## Applications on Servers

Vault can be processor intensive. Loading the Vault Server on a server with other processor intensive applications can cause Vault to run slower than expected.

## Microsoft SQL Express

Autodesk Vault requires a minimum of Microsoft SQL Express. See [Installation Requirements](https://knowledge.autodesk.com/support/vault-products/troubleshooting/caas/sfdcarticles/sfdcarticles/system-requirements-for-autodesk-vault-products.html).

If your Vault implementation requires more capacity than SQL Express, set up the Vault server using the Standard or Enterprise versions of SQL.

If your computer/domain is set up to require strong/complex passwords, you will not be able to use the default SQL SA password used by the Autodesk installer. Visit [SQL Administration Tasks for Autodesk Vault](GUID-6E35739D-CBCC-4211-9051-E451EBE3360C.htm) for information about setting an appropriate SA password. Check with your IT administrator to learn the requirements for a strong/complex password.

Autodesk Vault 2025 installs SQL Express Adv 2017 using the Network Service account for SQL services. SQL Express Adv 2017 cannot be installed on a domain controller under a local service account or a network service account.

For security reasons, Microsoft recommends that you do not install SQL Server on a domain controller. Visit [Hardware and Software Requirements for Installing SQL Server](https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/ms143506.aspx) to learn more.

## SQL Failover Clustering

Autodesk Vault functions in a SQL failover cluster configuration in which it is unaware of the cluster and does not require reconfiguration of Vault if and when a failover occurs. This is known as the AlwaysOn Failover Cluster Instances (fci). More information about this configuration can be found at [Always On Failover Cluster Instances](https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/ms189134.aspx). Before configuring this feature, Windows Server must be configured for [Windows Server Failover Clustering (WSFC) with SQL Server](https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/hh270278(v=sql.130).aspx). When Vault is used within a SQL failover cluster environment, workflows occurring during a failover may be interrupted and require repeating the workflow.​

## Access Frequency

How often the Vault Server is accessed affects the server performance. For example, a Vault implementation with 50 users and one or two users checking out one or two files a day does not tax the server much. Using the same configuration with 35 of the users accessing the vault every 10 minutes will have a greater impact on Vault Server performance since it exceeds the recommended number of concurrent users.

## Network Speed

Although network speed is commonly equated to latency, you should also consider bandwidth and throughput. Network speed is an important factor to consider when trying to get the best performance for your Vault implementation. By running tests to measure your latency, bandwidth, and throughput among all of the servers, you can gain an idea of how fast the connections are. Copy a few large files from one server to another. When performing this test, copy from Server A to Server B and then copy from server B to Server A. Data traveling from one server to another does not always take the same route when traveling back.

## Additional Considerations for Distributed Teams

If you are installing the server components for Vault Professional, you have several options to better support teams distributed across multiple locations. Vault Professional supports Multi-Site replication with a central remote database. Vault Professional also allows a single site to implement Vault with a dedicated database server.

### Multi-Site

Multiple remote sites can be configured to access the same vault data. A site comprises a dedicated Autodesk data management server and a file store. Each site accesses a shared AUTODESKVAULT SQL instance.

### Expanded Architecture

In addition to a traditional multi-site environment configuration, the multi-site architecture can be expanded by using the Autodesk Vault File Server. In this layout, a remote site hosts its filestore locally, similar to a traditional multi-site environment, while directing meta-data traffic to the Autodesk Data Management Server to which it is connected. This configuration can provide considerable performance improvements if the remote site has a poor or slow connection to the SQL server.

### Replication

Replication is the process of copying data from one server to another server usually located in two different physical locations. This process allows the setup of a Vault environment that has two different locations. Users will not have to spend time downloading large CAD files across their Wide Area Network (wan) connection.

The connected workgroup feature in Autodesk Vault Professional supports the use of multiple database servers using Microsoft SQL merge replication technology. This technology allows the replication of the SQL database at multiple locations.

## Supported Language Configurations

### Supported Client Language Configurations

Any client meeting the following criteria can work with any server of any language meeting the server criteria below. Client language and server language do not need to match.

* The Autodesk Vault client is supported on operating systems of the following languages: Brazilian Portuguese, Czech, English, French, German, Hungarian, Italian, Japanese, Korean, Polish, Russian, Simplified Chinese, Spanish, and Traditional Chinese.
* An English language Vault client is supported on all supported non-English language operating systems.
* A non-English Vault client would only be supported on the respective non-English operating system. If you install a non-English Vault client on an English operating system, the regional settings and the language should be set to the respective non-English language or region for it to work properly.

  For instance, the Spanish Vault Client would only be supported on a Spanish operating system. However, if installed on an English operating system, the regional settings and language should be set to Spanish or region with the Spanish language for it to work properly.
* Vault Basic and Vault Professional are localized into Brazilian Portuguese, Czech, English, French, German, Hungarian, Italian, Japanese, Korean, Polish, Russian, Simplified Chinese, Spanish, and Traditional Chinese.
* The language of the Autodesk Vault CAD add-in must be the same language as the CAD application.

### Other Client Language Notes

The Vault client does not support runtime language switching.

Vault add-ins do not support the switch of a CAD application's language to a configuration which does not meet the criteria outlined in the section above.

An English version of Autodesk DWG TrueView is included in all Vault client products for all languages except Japanese and French.

### Supported Vault Server Language Configurations

Any server meeting the following criteria can work with any client of any language meeting the client criteria above.

* The Vault Server is supported on operating systems of the following languages: Brazilian Portuguese, Czech, English, French, German, Hungarian, Italian, Japanese, Korean, Polish, Russian, Simplified Chinese, Spanish, and Traditional Chinese.
* An English language Vault Server is supported on all supported non-English language operating system.
* A non-English Vault Server must match the language of the operating system.
* Any case-insensitive collation and/or language of SQL may be used with any language Vault Server.
* Migrating from one Language of Vault Server to a different language of Vault Server is only supported if it is to or from an English Language Vault Server.

Note:

* Operating system date format differences between the Vault Server and Client can occur if the date format in the locale does not match. Vault does not support mixing locale settings in this way. Vault client and server date\time settings should be the same.
* Mapping Text with Number or Text with Date works well when all clients and the server are in the same language locale. If mixed locales are used, values may convert in a manner that is not intuitive and may produce an undesirable result. Therefore, mapping Text with Number or Text with Date is only recommended when the server and all clients are set up to work in the same locale.
* For property mappings, some datatypes require the same client language.

### Other Vault Server Language Notes

Restoring a backup from a different SQL collation other than the collation currently being used will result in the backup's collation being used.

### Supported Connected Workgroup Server Language Configurations

Any server meeting the above criteria can work with any other server of any language meeting the above criteria.

### Other Replication-Related Language Notes

The publisher's SQL collation/language determines collation/language in a replicated environment regardless of the installed SQL language of subscribers.

Autodesk recommends all SQL installations in a replicated environment be the same language.
